Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Shells, thanks for the pointer regarding battery replacement.    Wanda, Marcin and Ryan, thanks for your comments.  I think you'll be very happy when your new Kindle arrives!

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Hi Lael,   I prefer the white, my wife prefers the graphite.  Many reviews of the Kindle DX and the new graphite K3 say that text seems to "pop" or stand out more due to the psychological effect of having a dark "frame" around the "page."  My wife agrees with that.  I set them side by side and I cannot tell the difference, honestly, but so many people can, there must be something to it.    Since I can't tell the difference, I chose white for very superficial reasons.    1) I think the white kindle looks better with most of the colors of Amazon cases. for example I put my wife's graphite K3 in my green Amazon lighted case and I just didn't like the color combination.  I also cannot imagine pairing the graphite K3 with one of the warmer color cases, like burnt orange or brown.  But that's totally subjective, everyone has different tastes and mine are not better than anyone else's.    2) I believe that most people will now buy the graphite (DX and K3-wifi only come in graphite; K3-3G comes in both but graphite is new and "sexy", apparently), and therefore white will soon be the more "rare," unique color.  I like having something different than everyone else.  (Of course, my K3 is the same color is the millions of K2s out there, so it's not THAT unique!)

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Thanks to all commenters for reading my review.    More and more ex-nook users are coming out and saying that borrowing books from the library in ePub format has not worked well for them.  People are saying that the selection of ePub books available to be borrowed from public libraries is extremely limited, and one person said there was a 39-week wait to borrow a particular book.  (The technology exists to allow a library to loan a single ePub book to many users at the same time, but publishers typically don't allow this because they fear it will reduce their sales.)  Bottom line, the nook's ability to borrow library books seems too limited and problematic to be a worthwhile reason to choose nook over kindle.

Author: Adam N. Lamar
Comment: Great review! Was thinking about it as well. I sneered when Kindle first came out. I didn't like the first device (I never buy new tech anyway anymore - let the suckers put up with the bugs) and I thought the price of books was too high. A friend though pointed out that with printing costs virtually nil, when I purchase a hard copy, most of what I am paying for is marketing, production and royalty - so there is little difference in cost between the hard and digital - made sense. Enough for me to download Kindle and start using it on my BlackBerry (great for flights). Also, I like the lack of limitation in hardware - I can read the same purchase on my iMac or BlackBerry - so can re-download to the new device I am buying without repurchasing the book! I in fact cut the cord on a recent trip and didn't carry any paper books with me - using my BlackBerry for one solid week. I managed but it left me thirsting for a much better reader. As good as my Bold 9700 is, I get tired of looking at a lighted (and small) screen.  The combination of the improved quality and the lower price weakened me - but the addition of WiFi and 3G put the nail in the coffin - and I have ordered the 3G version in graphite with a lighted cover case. Hopefully will come in time for my next trip.  One thing I have told friends is that so many other book programs make you pay for EVERYTHING - I like Kindle due to the vast offering of 0 cost public domain documents.

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Dear Elizabeth:  I totally share your concern.  However, I am less worried after reading some of the comments here.  First, it may be possible to replace your own battery, and at lower cost than sending your kindle back to Amazon.  One of the first comments is from someone who found a website with information on this, and I have heard of people very safely replacing batteries in their ipods (when Apple says the ipod battery is not user-replaceable and Apple mails you a refurbished ipod when you send yours in for a replacement - just like Amazon and the Kindle).    More importantly perhaps, another comment convinced me that we may never need to replace our batteries.  The batteries in Kindles are rated for a huge number of recharge cycles, equivalent to something like 6 years of usage.  I'll be lucky if I keep my kindle for 3 years before giving into the temptation of buying a newer model.    Others have said they like the idea of getting a factory refurbished kindle for the price of a new battery - I personally disagree, I would rather keep my own kindle, but I can see how people would find this appealing.  And since Amazon is a highly reputable company, I cannot imagine they would ship a scratched up, stained kindle to you and called it "refurbished."    In any case, my message here is that we probably don't need to stress too much about the battery issue.  I am grateful to the commenters above who pointed out all of this information.

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Dear Maggie in Waco, the Nook absolutely does not accept Amazon's format.  There is free software called calibre that converts e-books between the major formats, so long as they are not copy-protected.  It has gotten good reviews.  Unfortunately, Amazon's e-books for Kindle are copy-protected, so there's simply no way to read Kindle books on the Nook.   But calibre will allow Kindle owners to read e-books in the ePub format if they are not copy-protected.  If you're interested, you can learn about calibre here:   http://calibre-ebook.com/about

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Dear MeThink, I titled my review "kindle vs. nook" because I focused on the comparison between the 6" kindle and nook, which I think is what most people are deciding between.  I didn't discuss the DX much because it costs more than twice as much as the 6" kindle, so I figured few people would be deciding between them.    Amazon's web page for the Kindle 3 clearly states that it has the same "text-to-speech" feature that the DX has.  I have not used this feature on either device, so I didn't comment on it in my (already lengthy) review.   For those people deciding between a DX and Kindle 3, I'll answer your questions if I can, but first please see whether Amazon's website has the info you seek.  Forgive me if I have trouble keeping up with all the questions here, I work long hours and don't always get to my email in a timely fashion.    Thanks for reading my review, and good luck!

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: Elizabeth,   So that a freeze doesn't happen again?  That's like saying a PC will never freeze again or a Mac will hever require a force-set.      But the paper clip or anything else was for the Kindle 1 that had a recessed reset-button that is like the ones you find on your cablemodem or other electronic items today that let you reset a unit easily and effectively.  This was not actually on the battery at all of course.    It was at the back of the unit when you slide the cover off. There was no way you could "muck it up,", using the reset/restart  hole in the back (marked "reset" but it is like pressing the SMALL re-start button of  a PC rather than the main 'on' 'off' or power button.    In two years, my K1 has not failed me but in the beginning I used to push many buttons all at once, which can confuse it so it would just stop accepting 'commands' ...  I learned not to be so impatient after the beginning and it didn't happen again.      The Kindle warrantys and Amazon Kindle customer service are extremely flexible.       Since this thread includes info on the Nook, it has had a history of reboots and freezes.   Today Amazon tech support put out a fix apparently for slowdowns of page turns outdoors -- many of them reported as taking as long as a full second to turn a page, reportedly.   A few took longer but the ones that had to wait for a full second said it was not earthshaking but concerned them and was irritating. It could be that we just get too used to half-second page turns.    The fix has apparently cured that already with most of those who were upset.

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: Mary,    The models are either WiFi-only or 3G+WiFi ... so Julian's advice that it costs (about 15c) to send a personal doc direct to your Kindle device is about when you CHOOSE to do it that way (if one doesn't have a WiFi system at home that you connect with etc so you send it via 3G though there are other free ways).    A personal doc is like a Word doc you or someone wrote, which you'd like to have on your Kindle -- or a PDF info sheet or manual that you'd like to have on the Kindle or any number of interesting pieces on the web that you'd like put on your Kindle (there are various ways).    When you send such a document to [yourself]@free.kindle.com after approving your regular email to send to your Kindle device, that means Amazon will convert it (if necessary) and send you a link to download it to your computer -- so you can move it to your Kindle 'documents' folder via the USB cable that is part of your power cord -- AND they send a copy via WiFi as well, which if you are set up with WiFi at home or office or use Starbucks' or McDonald's will go to your Kindle at no cost when you log on to a WiFi network somewhere.  3G is more like a cellphone and it's all around you if there is AT&T cellphone service in your area.    It's never 3G instead of WiFi.  The only 3G model ALSO has WiFi.    Any book you purchase from Amazon has no added charges for delivery to your Kindle.  Those are more public docs or books.    A personal doc is something you created or found or that was given to you outside Amazon.  Some of us have ToDo lists or recipies and other things on our Kindles and they're personal docs also.    To see the difference between WiFi-only and 3G/WiFi model capabilities, you can read my piece at http://bit.ly/kw3gwifi which some have told me is pretty clear.  I hope so.   - Andrys

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Regarding the wifi vs. 3G debate, all of your comments have covered this issue pretty well, but I'd add just a couple minor things.    Remember, you only need internet connectivity to download content, not to read content.  (Well, except for when you want to use kindle's browser, but let's set that aside for the moment).  If you have wifi at home, then the only time you'd need 3G is to download content when you're away from home, and that's only when you can't get to a wifi hotspot.  Free wifi hotspots are getting more and more common:  many hotel chains have, all starbucks locations, many other coffee shops and libraries offer free wifi.  Also, there are definitely a fair number of dead zones around the country where 3G coverage is spotty or nonexistent.  And worse comes to worse, if you load your kindle up with content before leaving home, you might not even need an internet connection while you're traveling.  All of this argues in favor of getting the wifi only kindle and saving yourself $50.    That said, there are a couple reasons why the 3G might be worthwhile.  The main one is if you travel a lot and subscribe to a daily newspaper, then you can still get your newspaper every day, even if your hotel (or relatives' house) doesn't have wifi.  If you take the subway to work, you can surf the Amazon store and download magazines and newspapers.  Etc etc.    Another consideration is that $50 is not much to spend for lifetime 3G internet connectivity.  Granted, you can't do nearly as much on the internet with a kindle as with a smartphone or ipad.  But still, $50 is not bad.  If you own your Kindle for two years, that comes to about $2 or so per month.    The last reason, and I admit this is going to sound pretty lame, is that the 3G kindle is the only one that comes in white anymore.  The wifi only kindle comes only in graphite.  I'm guessing that the vast majority of people will buy graphite.  I personally picked white because I don't want the same color as everyone else.  (Well, of course everyone who has a kindle 1 or 2, or an older DX, has white, so I guess mine isn't THAT unique!)  Bottom line, I think the choice between 3G and wifi isn't a critical choice in the sense that, no matter which you pick, you probably won't regret it.  (Unlike nook vs. kindle, I think some people who bought one of them without first learning about their differences and respective advantages are at risk of coming to regret their decision, which is why I hope my overly long and wordy review will help people avoid that.)    Good luck!  -Ron

Author: Whitneymuse

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: It's also not true that if you have Wi-Fi in your home then you don't need 3G because it's like saying you don't need cell-phone reception if you stay home most of the time.    This e-reader has a quite capable free 3G web-browser on it and MANY of us use it outside the home to look up restaurants, theaters, phone numbers, reviews of each before deciding but it comes in handy most of all when you are *lost* and don't have a GPS with you.    No way with WiFi-only could you turn on your Kindle in a car (as a passenger or as a driver who has pulled over)) and go to Google Maps - Text version and put in where you are and where you need to be and have step-by-step directions within about 20 seconds.    See http://bit.ly/kdriving  to see how that's done.  It's not even difficult, but is a great feature that can be used almost anywhere on this globe.    Amazon's 3G is available wherever there is AT&T reception for cell phones and essentially that's what you're using - "Free 3G cell-phone network web browser" - no monthly charges.    You wouldn't use it often but it can be a lifesaver when you need something and then you also know you don't have to pay data charges with it for the web look-ups the way you do with cell phones which are on monthly fees.    Also, WiFi networks do break down.  Electricity goes out.  Power outages are not that uncommon anymore (at least where I live.)    It's a not-good savings if you have the opportunity to connect with the outside world with the 3G cellphone part in those circumstances, but you saved $50 and don't have it.   It allows you to use email (slowly but at least it's possible).    This Kindle is not just about downloading books anymore.  Julian has the right idea in not limiting himself.   This 3G cellphone type access for free is usable by U.S. residents in about 100 cities worldwide.     That means you can get directions when you're in another country, from the sidewalk, from a bus, from anywhere, not dependent on a working wifi somewhere that wants you to put in a password etc.   Also, I don't like to ask friends for their WiFi password when visiting.    Julian, I'm with you on the decision you'd make.  Amazon has a unique and highly valuable feature here.  Just check out what people do need to pay for their web-data access on other gadgets.

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Dear Digital Flashback:  Thanks for your comment.  The Kindle treats PDF files like a computer does, essentially like an image.  So you cannot change font size, which would change the look of each page from the original, as well as the number of pages.  However, you can convert PDF files to the Kindle format, and then you can change font sizes like on the Nook.  Then, there's no panning/zooming necessary.  But you don't get to see the whole page, the way you would in its original format.

Author: Joy Kelley
Comment: Well, I finally got my Kindle 3 about a week or so before my trip from Guam to SC.  I usually kept the wi-fi turned on, so I could order a book when I thought about it - ordered some free classics to read while in the States.  In the process, my battery had dropped to about 1/3 left, so I decided the night before my flight to recharge the battery.  I unplugged it right before going to the airport.  When I got on the plane and opened my Kindle 3, it started that re-booting thing....which, naturally, after reading all these reviews, freaked me out.  Additionally, it had lost my place in the book I was reading, and I couldn't sync to the furthest page read.  My Kindle wasn't storing  that information on the device, and I was not in a wi-fi area on the plane.  So I had to go search for my place in the book, then I had to keep watching my location at the bottom of the screen in case the Kindle started re-booting again, which it did at least three times during my 16 hour travel to Houston before going on to SC.  In the airport there, I tried to find a wi-fi area, but with my limited time, was unsuccessful.  So for the flight to SC, I just had to keep on keeping track of my location and writing it down before putting the Kindle to sleep each time.  It was a very big hassle!  When I arrived in SC and got settled in, yesterday, I called Kindle customer service.  The guy told me that the problem had been corrected, and that I only needed to download the update from Amazon onto my Kindle.  He walked me through it, so  now it is working okay....knock on wood.  :)  However, I have decided to go ahead and order the 3G and send back the Kindle 3 for a refund.  My husband said that if the Kindle 3 keeps working, he may decide to take it and use it instead of his Kindle 2.  He likes the compact size, and it will fit in his military uniform leg pocket...no problem.  For his purposes, it should be good.  I actually already ordered the 3G, and will pick it up on the 16th at my son's house in Missouri and have a chance to use it for a week before heading back home to my little island in the sun.  :)  I still love Kindle, but this one sure did put a scare into me.  :)

Author: Joy Kelley
Comment: There are three basic differences between Kindle 2 and Kindle 3.  One is the size - Kindle 3 is much smaller and easier to carry in a purse or even in a larger pocket.  Another difference is the speed and smoothness in which the pages turn.  It is a significant improvement in the Kindle 3, which reads much faster and smoother.  One downside I found with the Kindle 3, is the text-to-speech feature.  In Kindle 2, there is usually a very distinct pause when you come to a comma or a period.  In Kindle 3, there is NO pause, and it's difficult to understand.  My husband was telling me yesterday that he might want to keep the Kindle 3 to use for himself (he has the Kindle 2), since it can fit into his uniform pantleg pocket, where the Kindle 2 can't.  But he has dyslexia and needs the text-to-speech feature.  When I just tried using that feature on my new Kindle 3, to check it out for this review, I learned about the problem with the lack of pause at commas and periods.  That brings the Kindle 3 WAY down for anyone who likes being read to by the device.  Also, I'm sending back this Kindle 3 and have already ordered the 3G for reasons stated in my earlier post this morning.  Living outside the continental USA, I couldn't use a Nook.  And I really do love reading on Kindle.  I'm hoping the 3G is as good as the Kindle 3 in page turns and text-to-speech.  I'll update later on about it.

My sister in law has a nook and just had a warranty issue.  Rather than fixing her nook, Barnes & Noble replaced it with a refurbished one.  She was worried about this, but the refurbished one now has all her content and settings like the old one, and it "feels" like hers. Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Rosk, Amazon's product page for each kindle model has objective information about the weight.    But it sounds like you're more interested in the subjective impressions of people who have used both.  I am one such person, and my opinion is that the extra weight of the DX was an issue for me.  For long leisure reading sessions, holding the DX in one hand was fatiguing after a while.  Also, the page turn button placement isn't as good on the DX as on the 3, especially if you're holding it in one hand and turning pages with the same hand.    On the other hand, the extra large display of the DX was GREAT.  I really loved it.  So there's definitely a trade-off here.    Of course, these are my subjective impressions, not irrefutable fact.  I'm sure you can find people who have a DX and consider the weight to be quite manageable.  If I would have kept the DX instead of getting a 3, I'm sure I would have adapted to the weight - e.g., rest it on a desk or my knees or something while reading for long periods at a time.     I'm sorry I can't give you a definitive answer.  But here's a suggestion that might help:  it was reported last month that Best Buy would soon begin selling all current kindle models, including the DX, and they would have fully functional display units in every store for customers to try.  Staples, too, I think.  So maybe you can find a store nearby that has the 3 and the DX, and hold both in your own hands.     Good luck!

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Alphia, it's fine to leave your kindle in its case.  Like you, I got the Amazon case with the light built in, and got one for my wife's kindle (also a "3").  We both leave our kindles in the case all the time, and we both use the light a lot.  It really helps.  When we drove a long distance, after sunset one of us would read our kindle while the other drove - if you use the light and make the font bigger, it's more comfortable reading the kindle than reading a book in the car.    If you have time before your trip, load up your new kindle with some books so you have good reading material while you're away.    I agree with you about the small keys, but after a while I got the hang of using them and now it's not so bad.  Hopefully, it'll get easier for you, too.    Have a nice trip!  -Ron

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Dear Ms. Driscoll:  First of all, thanks for reading, I know it's a LOT to read just to figure out which model to buy.    The $189 Kindle with 3G is probably the better option for you.  3G is the same technology that Blackberries, iPhones, and other "smart phones" use to connect to the internet.  Amazon has built this into the $189 Kindle 3G and made it very simple for us:  we do not have to THINK about connecting to a cellular network - the Kindle does it for us, automatically.    This 3G connection to the internet works very well, as long as you are in an area with 3G coverage - coverage is good in most of the well-populated parts of the U.S., but not as good in some locations that are more remote, or have low-income and low-density populations.  I think somewhere on Amazon's website you can find a map of the U.S. that shows which parts have 3G coverage.    The $139 Kindle does not have this 3G technology built in, which is why it's cheaper.  It can connect to the internet wirelessly using wi-fi, which you said you don't have in your house.  But, if you have a computer in your house that can connect to the internet, then you can download books to your computer and then transfer them from your computer to the Kindle.  Transferring files requires a cable, which is included with the Kindle.  (And if you lose it or want a second one, it is a very common type of cable, not expensive, and available at many stores like Best Buy and Walmart and Target).    This way of getting books on to your Kindle requires extra steps.  To those of us who work with computers regularly, it's pretty easy, but to someone who doesn't do much work with computers, it's probably not as easy.  But if you do it a few times, it'll become pretty easy.  You probably don't live near Milwaukee, but if you did, I'd be happy to show you.    Transferring files from your computer to your Kindle is certainly possible, but it's not nearly as convenient as using the 3G connectivity that comes with the $189 Kindle.  With the 3G Kindle, you just turn your Kindle on and you can immediately shop from Amazon's online Kindle store, right from the Kindle.    So I guess my advice is:  if it's not too much of a hardship to spend the extra $50 for the Kindle 3G model, then I think it's worth it for you.  But in these times, $50 is a lot of money to a lot of people.  As long as your computer can connect to the internet, then you can use your computer to download books and other content, then transfer it to the Kindle using the included cable.  It's less convenient, and there's a learning curve for folks that don't do a lot of work with computers.  But it's certainly possible, and not too bad once you get the hang of it.  This way, your Kindle doesn't need an internet connection, so you could get by with the $139 Kindle.    Good luck!  Best wishes, Ron C.

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: M. Perkins:  You MUST connect to the internet with either 3G or WiFi to download content from Amazon or browse the internet using Kindle's browser.  The term "Whispernet" is a marketing creation that refers, I think, to Kindle's built-in internet connectivity, which is based on 3G (and now, wi-fi) technology.  Without 3G or wifi, there is no "whispernet."    I hope this answers your question.    Don't forget:  Amazon has customer service people who are paid to answer questions about Kindle from prospective buyers.  That's a great resource for information, and I used them a few times when I was researching my purchase decision.    Best, Ron

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: jood,    Amazon itself has somewhat over 20,000 free books to choose from.  Most are classics but there are temporarily free contemporary ones on a promotional basis each day.    Also, you can download direct from Project Gutenberg to your Kindle, which has about 30,000 free books, via the 'Magic Catalog' ...      And at Internet Archive there are over 2 million free texts available for the Kindle.  Also, one can get books direct to Kindle also at feedbooks.com and mnybks.net ...  So there's a lot of choice for the thrifty.    NY Times bestsellers tend to be about $10 unless the larger publishers decide to price them higher.      The free ones from Amazon itself can be sync'd with your other Kindle-compatible devices, such as another Kindle, an iPhone or iPad, iPod touch, Blackberry, Android, Mac, PC etc. so that you can read from where you left off last on another device.    This can be done because those books are on Amazon's servers and the current location/page number can be marked and kept for you.    Some general information on free books can be found at http://bit.ly/kfreelow3     They also have a list of Top 100 Free and Top 100 Paid books (in popularity) on one page.   - Andrys, kindleworld.blogspot.com

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Kim and Jill asked whether two people with their own Kindles could share Kindle books.  It is possible with many but not all books, provided both Kindles are registered to the same Amazon account.  Some publishers do not allow Amazon to let people put Kindle books on more than one device at a time, but many do allow it.    To ARM-C, I like the *idea* of expandable storage on the Nook.  However, in my experience, Kindle's lack of it will not be a problem, for two reasons.  First, Kindle's included internal storage is huge (4gb vs. Nook's 2gb).  My kindle 3 has 10 purchased books and over a hundred free books (plus some MP3 files I never listen to), and I'm using only a tiny percentage of the available capacity.  Second, if space is running low, you can delete items you don't access often; they will remain on your Amazon Kindle account and it's very easy to get them back later if you wish.   Thanks to everyone for reading my review and for all your comments!

Author: Nix Cadavre
Comment: With the Nook's newest firmware update (as of 11/2010), page refresh speed is no longer an issue, so the Kindle's "speed advantage" is no longer a consideration. Nook has also added "shelves" to the library (allowing you to organize books any way you desire), and does support cross-platform bookmarking in Nook applications, now. Battery life seems to have been increased, as well.   However, there is as yet no way for a Kindle to use DRM-protected ebooks purchased or borrowed from anywhere other than Amazon, and it's unlikely they'll ever allow it. Meanwhile, the Nook has support for ePub and Adobe Digital Editions, which allows Nook owners to purchase ebooks from dozens of retailers, and also allows Nook owners to borrow books from the public library. Kindle can't do this.   Yes, you can get non-DRM books from other sources and convert them to Kindle, but books that are protected (which is MOST of them) are not usable on the Kindle with just conversion-- You'd also have to strip the DRM, which is illegal and difficult. Calibre cannot strip DRM from books, and will NOT allow you to borrow library books on your Kindle.   Furthermore, as many have noted, Nook supports storage upgrades via SD cards. Kindle does not. Nook supports user-replaceable batteries. Kindle does not (you have to send your Kindle in to Amazon, and they charge you approximately eighty bucks to do it for you while you're waiting for your Kindle to come back). As pointed out, opening your Kindle voids your warranty. Replacing the battery on the Nook does not.   The reviewer also seems confused about PDF support. The Nook does, indeed, have good PDF support. In fact, having owned a Kindle 2 and a Nook, I can say the Nook's PDF support is much better, and much easier to read. I have personally put graphic-laden PDFs on the Nook and been pleased with the outcome. On the Kindle, the PDFs were hard to read because the font size was terrible.   Nook's web browsing is a FAR better experience than Kindle's because you can see the web page in color on the touch screen, and you can interact with it there as well. Instead of using a joystick to click links, you simply touch them. The full page displays on the e-ink, while the zoomed-in section shows up on the touch screen. The only negative to Nook's web browsing is that you can't browse the web via 3G on Nook; It's WiFi only.   For me, it boils down to format support, though.  I won't get another Kindle until they open it up and support what is now turning out to be the industry standard for eBooks; ePub and Adobe Digital Editions. Kindle is closed-off, and getting content for it (legitimately) requires you to be at Amazon's mercy. This means you're stuck with Amazon's availability and pricing, and I just don't like being cornered like that (especially since I've found eBooks far cheaper on Amazon's competitor sites). With the Nook, I can shop around for the best price on an ebook, and even find books that don't exist in Kindle format, because I have support for almost every internet-based ebook store out there. Converting and ripping DRM is not convenient, legal, or desirable, and the end result is not as nice as the original. Kindle takes away CHOICE, and I like having choices.  Oh, and one more thing: The Kindle doesn't do actual page numbers; It has its own numbering system, based on font size. The Nook uses page numbers, which makes finding or referring to things much easier on Nook than on the Kindle.

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: Hi, everyone.   I've revised and updated the review to make it more coherent, slightly shorter, and to address two issues that have come up in recent comments:  storage capacity and the Nook version 1.5 firmware update.    I welcome the comments of Nook fans who note, quite correctly, that Nook has expandable storage, a user-replaceable battery, and compatibility with ePub; Kindle has none of these.  These are reasons I initially chose the Nook.  But after using Nook and Kindle, my experience is that Kindle's lack of these features is not a problem for me.  If you disagree, that's fine, I respect that.  But it's my review, and I honestly gave my impressions from using the two devices.    My review now mentions the new Nook version 1.5 firmware update.  To Nook fans who think I have not done justice to the awesomeness of the version 1.5 firmware, I apologize, but I have not used a Nook with this update, so I can't really say much about it.  Your comments have convinced me that it improves the experience of using the Nook. Maybe I would have kept my Nook if it had this software when I bought it.  (The one I bought was running version 1.4, which itself was a huge improvement over the initial Nook firmware, but still quite sluggish compared to the Kindle.)     I'm happy that version 1.5 improves the Nook experience.  Yet, it's hard for me to imagine that the sluggish performance of Nooks running version 1.4 and earlier is due solely to crappy firmware.  I understand that the first version of most technology gadgets is buggy, and that's one of the pitfalls of being an early adopter.  It's nice to know that B&N keeps improving the firmware.

Author: T. Madsen
Comment: Regarding your comments on the Nook Color screen (which I now own and have been using for a couple of weeks): it may just boil down to taste, but I prefer the touch screen (with color a current nice-to-have and in the process of very quickly becoming a must-have).  For example, as far as preference for Kindle's "dedicated keys" - again, a matter of taste but I am looking for a direct interface with my e-reading material and a touchscreen is the only way to accomplish that.  With the Nook Color you can not only directly flip the page back/forth but more quickly and intuitively touch on a word for a look-up, highlight a section, bookmark, take notes, and generally interact with your book (and other media such as top newspapers and magazines in their intended, high-res color layout - perhaps one of the biggest market disruptors).  All of these are big differentiators for me (rather than watching movies, surfing, playing games, etc...) as I love to highlight and take notes - basically, interact - with my books and other reading material.  What I have always done with the printed page and a pencil/dictionary/encyclopedia by my side I can now do with a touch ereader - with all the tools built-in.  I am now, finally, fully sold on the ereader.  Regarding the screen brightness - I too had an issue with how intensely bright the screen was.  I then touched the lower left corner of the screen and up popped - the brightness control.  I turned it DOWN :)  Again, perhaps just me, but with the brightness down, I have not noticed any fatigue the last two weeks.  Bottom line, if I had to place the Nook Color somewhere in the current market, what I currently have is the first generation of a lighter weight, lower-cost, more reader-oriented alternative to the iPad.    Overall, you've done an excellent review - I just think the color, direct-screen approach (not to mention a more open platform for alternative book files, reader-dedicated android apps, etc...) is not just a different category, it is the replacement of the static black/white screen.  Amazon will need to catch up quick.

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: T Madsen, thanks for your review of the Nook Color.  It sounds like a great device.  I love the touch-screen of my ipod touch, so I can see how it would be easy to love the touchscreen interface of the Nook Color.  I absolutely agree that magazines like National Geographic which have gorgeous photos or graphics would be wasted on an e-ink based reader.   And of course, the Nook Color's web browser is quite good, and makes Kindle's web browser look even more inadequate.    Tablet computers like Nook Color may eventually dominate the ereader market, as you suggest.  But I think there's still a market for e-ink based Kindles, at least for the foreseeable future:  They still work great for reading novels and most non-fiction books, they're about half the weight of Nook Color, they get really great battery life, and they cost about $120 less than the Nook Color (when you include sales tax on the Nook Color).   Maybe I'll pick up a Nook Color when my finances recover from the Macbook Air I just bought (that will take quite a long time, unfortunately).  Until then, I'm happy that it's such a great device for you and others who buy it.  Having more choices is better for us consumers, and healthy competition will motivate both companies to keep improving their products.

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: S. Sokolinsky:  I know people who buy every new ipod model that's introduced.  E-readers aren't as sexy, but is it really so inconceivable that someone would buy new models frequently, just for the sake of having the latest and greatest?   Yet, that is not our story.  We have two, not five or six.  You want to understand why, so here's why:  Last summer, I bought a Nook and my wife bought a Kindle 2.  We fully intended to keep them for years.  After using my Nook and seeing my wife's K2, I grew to strongly prefer the K2, so I returned my Nook.    Instead of ordering a K2 for myself, I ordered a DX.  It was a lot more expensive, but it had a new kind of e-ink technology with 50% better contrast than the K2, and of course a bigger display.  I fully intended to keep the DX.  But the day it arrived (literally!), Amazon announced the new Kindle 3.  The screen of Kindle 3 wasn't as big as the DX, but Kindle 3 had the same new high-constrast e-ink of the DX and it was $200 cheaper.  K3 made me regret my DX purchase.   I called Amazon customer service to discuss these issues.  I said I didn't want to abuse their return policy, but I also didn't want to spend hundreds of dollars on devices that were immediately obsolete.  They told us to return our kindles within 4 weeks and put us on the pre-order list for new K3s.  They said don't worry, this is normal whenever a new model comes out, everyone who just bought the old model and is still within the return period wants to exchange it for the new model.  They factor these returns into the cost of coming out with a new version.   I promise you:  every time I purchased one of these e-readers, I had every intention of keeping it.  In 12 years of shopping at Amazon, I have bought well over 1000 items and returned maybe 5 or 6 of them (including 2 or 3 that were defective).  We have had our K3s for over 3 months now, and are very happy with them.  We will keep them for a few years.    Or maybe we'll get into the habit of buying the new model every year.  If so, then next year you can look forward to seeing my review comparing the Kindle 4 to the Kindle 3.

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: Ron,   You did ask for other feedback from those who have worked with it.      A great number of us (which I link to elsewhere) feel the DX is fantastic for textbooks but then we know how to use it for that, as I mentioned.  I followed the campus projects  closely.    Mobileread forums are full of people who are agog over the DX and they are very heavily technical and tend to be academic but also technically adept in trying out features of this larger e-reader.    The most egregious report was from the Princeton newspaper, in which they had a professor who did not want to have the Kindle in his classroom but he acquiesced and then did not let the students use the location numbers to reference a paragraph, even though the entire class was a Kindle class.    Then they had about 4 quotes that were negative.  This was repeated in a few hundred other newspapers for a couple of months and each time it referred to "many students" being negative but what was not pointed out was that 3 of the four negative quotes  were from the same student.    That form of "many students" had a huge life in newspaper reports.       It is definite that the lawsuit against the Arizona college for not having audio-menu navigation for the visually impaired was the big stopper.  Federal funds would not be available to any college who used the Kindle as it was during the evaluation process.   But there was also the feedback from a majority of students who did not like the keyboard (nor do I); however, that doesn't mean it's not good for reading textbooks.       If someone asks if it's good for note-taking, no, it's too slow, though I do it.   I am unusually patient though with that kind of thing.  I would prefer a real touch keyboard somehow.  I too use a small netbook for heavy typing, but that DX is with me if I need to read reference books with diagrams, etc.    That page 'flipping' thing and what some students "were used to" and didn't find substitutes for tended to be because they didn't know what to substitute for their previous procedures and didn't seem very exploratory.       The Collection features do make a big difference but then so does the pan and zoom for PDFs though it is not nearly as smooth as with the $500 minimum iPad.   We are answering this question in the real world.      You and I agree that the 6" e-readers are non-starters for textbooks and focused use of PDFs, due to size problems and also because color is needed for courses in biology or for any books for which color illustrations are key.       However, I feel that the DX price has to come down, so I would wait for that, though there is a 30-day full-refund period for any reason whatsoever.

The kindle is asking you to spend $140 for a single-use device for text novels.  I don't really expect it to last long enough to pay for itself in book savings. I give adequate items three stars, and I don't really think that only comparing it to previous poor-quality devices should give it any extra credit.

Author: Avid Reader

I love the page saving feature that never loses the last page read. No more fumbling to find that anymore. The automatic shut off saves battery life. I'm down to 50% after 8 nights. The dictionary is an additional boon. It allows me to highlight and save the text, which I can later review under 'My Clippings' by selecting the 'Home' key. For night-time readers the text is easy to read if you have an attached light. I purchased the Belkin light. It has two settings and takes 3AAA batteries. I am using the lower setting and have used it for 8 days, leaving it on all night; so far, the batteries are doing great. The base of the light slides around a bit but I attached it to the Kindle with Velcro which solved the problem. The light itself has a 7" flexible neck which allows you to (re)position it as desired to avoid any glare.Kindle Wireless Reading Device, Wi-Fi, Graphite, 6" Display with New E Ink Pearl Technology

Author: tls5088
Comment: Thanks, almost no one refers to my biggest challenge with the Kindle -- the search & sort features.  If you are an avid reader, have caught up with your favorite authors' latest publications, you will have to move to a PDA or computer to do a "real" search.  The pages are unbelievably slow -- reminding me of the days we only had dial-up -- and, as you mentioned, very frustrating.  I was really disappointed that these issues were not addressed with the newest edtion of Kindle.  With that said, I want the best READING EXPERIENCE.  I bought the Kindle to replace my books, not as a second computer, iPad, Blackberry, etc., but certainly understand others desire for those features. Based on these factors, I want to quickly and easily search for new books and authors; adjust the sorting for my "wish list" for ideas; view "similar" books or authors; and see the ranking/rating, publication date, etc.  Who knew it would be so difficult to remember if you've read an ealier edition (8 years ago) or find out the "real" publication date to ensure you have the first book in a series.  It seems most publication dates on the Kindle are not related to the actual first edition of the orginal book rather when it was an e-book, or a reprint, or just when Kindle loaded the book onto their system.    In short, I appreciate you touching on the search/sort functions.  Possibly others will provide comparison reviews related to these elements.

Author: Steven Mason
Comment: Laura, yes, I DO watch videos on my iPod, but more importantly, I LISTEN to videos on my iPod, often. Some programs are available only in a video format. The new iPod doesn't even allow video files to be loaded on it, so the option of listening to them is lost.   As for your laughing at the loss of the camera, I actually use that, too. But you're missing the point. Anyone who wanted to listen to music "undisturbed" on the older iPod could do so. All they'd have to do is not use the camera.   You've got your facts wrong. The new iPod doesn't have more memory than the old one. They both come in 8GB and 16GB. If it's "all about song storage," you can't store more songs on the new model. I have to wonder why you'd get such a basic fact incorrect. Moreover, what kind of "true music lover" needs to have 2,000 to 4,000 songs on an iPod? And if you want that many songs, you'd do well having the larger screen of the older nano, so you can navigate through thousands of songs much more quickly and easily. But maybe you think navigating through thousands of songs on a very small screen is not disturbing. :-)  A true music lover, who didn't want any "disturbances" on her iPod, would do quite well with a 2GB player (500 songs, or over 24 hours of music), with a display for navigation, that cost about $50. With the money you save, you could buy a lot more music. :-) LOL right back to you!   The worst part of it is that you seem very happy to pay more for less. Yes, I can understand that you don't care about being able to watch or listen to video files, and you don't care about taking pictures or movies. But why on earth are you HAPPY to pay MORE for less? You do understand, don't you, that products are suppsed to be CHEAPER when they take features away? Why have you been "waiting for" an iPod that gives you less and costs more?

Author: Steven Mason
Comment: If you were to poll IPOD 5th gen users about how often they use it for videos or photos, myself included, you would get a miniscule percentage.  That may be true, Stef, but it's completely besides the point. The point is, with the latest model, we were paying more for less, at least until Apple got wise to what was going on and jacked up the price for 5th gen iPods.   But like a good little Apple groupie, you solve the problem by purchasing yet another Apple product - an iPhone. And others solve it by purchasing an iTouch, or an iPad. And that's exactly what Apple wants you to do.  Apple designed, manufactured, and sold a perfectly good nano - the 5th gen - that could not only play music and had a decent size display for human eyes and easy-to-use controls to navigate through all your stuff, it could also play video files, take pictures and movies, and record sound. And still it was small enough to slip in your pocket or wear around your neck. And you could get them for as low as $130. Now "refurbished" 5th gens cost $200, and new ones cost almost $300. That's the free market for you.  So now we're paying just as much as we used to for something that is not as good, no matter how you slice it. The 6th gen has absolutely NO advantage over the 5th gen. And anybody who says that the smaller size is some kind of advantage is kidding himself. It's not like the 5th gen was big and clunky.   And you know what, Stef? The 5th gen nano had the SAME quality sound and was a GREAT MUSIC PLAYER. Why do people keep saying that about the 6th gen as if it's a better music player than the 5th gen?   I don't mean to sound mad, but I get tired of people who dismiss the "minority" of people who play (or listen to) video files. And I get tired of people who are "much happier" to pay more for less. And I get tired of people who casually suggest that a "reasonable" solution is to buy an iPhone, iTouch, or iPad. People like you are the apple of Apple's eyes.  By the way, Stef, if you own a 5th gen, what was your reason for getting a 6th gen?

Author: STEF
Comment: You are making FAR too many assumptions.    1)  This is a PORTABLE MUSIC PLAYER.  Not needing a camera or video capabilities is EXACTLY the point.  Last time I checked, there were many other products that could play music and video and fit in your pocket - non-Apple products included.  And if I'm not mistaken, most of them have much bigger screens than the Nano 5G.  2)  Apple groupie?  People who enjoy and purchase Apple products are groupies?  I purchased an IRiver mp3 player, does that make me an IRiver groupie?  I purchased a Windows laptop...am I Microsoft groupie too?  I suppose if I would have chosen a Droid I'd be a Verizon groupie...or an EVO would make me a Sprint groupie too (?)    3)  You are very quick to point out that Apple removed the camera and video capabilitites, but you said nothing about adding the Apple dock connector.  How do you know the cost differential between the additions and subtractions don't offset each other?   Since this is a PORTABLE MUSIC PLAYER, the dock connector is much more important to "hi-fi" music listeners than any "non-musical" functions.    4)  Have you listened to the 5G through an amplifier using the headphone jack vs. the Nano through an amplifier using the dock connector?  Of course not.    So why exactly are you stating that the 5G is as good at playing music as the 6G?  Because you're just another Apple basher making blind assumptions.  5)  You dismiss smaller size as being a benefit.  How's that?  This is a PORTABLE MUSIC PLAYER...that's exactly the point.  With the 5th Gen, I had to keep it in my pocket:  the headphone cord would strangle me at every turn...and I would have to keep taking it out and putting it back in my pocket to use it.  6th gen:  I run the cord through my shirt sleeve and clip the Nano in place...no obstruction or intrusion whatsover.    6)  This was initially designed as a music player...later adding "bells and whistles" in attempt of selling more units.  Video is ABSOLUTELY an afterthought - that shouldn't come as a surprise to anyone.  I'm neither an Apple supporter nor an Apple basher, I simply buy products that work for me.  I sold my 5G for $80 and purchased a 6G for $130.  It's worth the extra $50 to me.  In your case, I'd honestly recommend a Droid.

Author: Steven Mason
Comment: Apple groupie?  For Pete's sake, that isn't an assumption, it's a joke. I think I can safely "assume" that you know what a real groupie is. My point is that your "solution" of buying an iPhone is not reasonable. You totally ignore the point and focus on a silly joke, pretending to be hurt.   "You are very quick to point out that Apple removed the camera and video capabilitites, but you said nothing about adding the Apple dock connector."  Yeah, right, like the other nanos didn't have dock connectors and that's why they had to take the other features away. I'm an engineer and I KNOW what's involved. I've even talked to Apple engineers about blue tooth.     "Have you listened to the 5G through an amplifier using the headphone jack vs. the Nano through an amplifier using the dock connector?"  As a matter of fact I have hooked up MANY versions of the iPods to MANY hi-fi sound systems. They've been extremely good for events, performances, parties and weddings. But I guess it isn't good enough for you. Do you have a specific complaint about the quality of sound coming out of a 5G? Hey, here's a question for you: Have you watched any videos on an HDTV using that wonderful dock connector on the 6G? I can use my 5G for that.       "You dismiss smaller size as being a benefit. How's that? This is a PORTABLE MUSIC PLAYER...that's exactly the point."  Oh, so that's why you bought a 6G when you already had a 5G: You got tired of lugging that brick around? If you think the 5G isn't PORTABLE, I think it's time you hit the gym. That is, if you can manage to find the strength to get to the gym. And speaking of gyms, I've seen plenty of people who clip their 5G nanos. When I run it goes in my pocket. I never have problems with the cord. You must be one of the miniscule percentage of people who has problems with their 5G.    "This was initially designed as a music player...later adding "bells and whistles" in attempt of selling more units."  I UNDERSTAND that. But what's hard to understand about people not liking to pay more for less? In the opinion of MANY people, the new touchscreen is just too small to be seen as an advantage. And then there are other shortcomings with the 6G that I haven't even mentioned. I'd LOVE it if Apple came out with a basic audio and VIDEO player, about the same size as a 5G, with NO "bells and whistles," that cost $100 (adding video playing capability does NOT make it more expensive for Apple). And I'd LOVE it if, for $25 bucks more, they offered the same with blue tooth. And then maybe, for those who like such things, Apple could offer a model that has a touchscreen for $150. ALL of these models could have a built-in clip, for people like you who apparently don't mind buying iPhones to play video files but do mind buying accessories like clips.   I'm an Apple basher? LOL! It's probably a safe bet that I've spent LOTS more money on Apple products than you have. I go way back to the Apple II, sonny boy. I bet you weren't even born when the Apple II came out.

Author: T. Gonzalez
Comment: Anyone looking for something like the old iPod Nano (4th and 5th gen) might consider the Zune HD.  I know those are usually compared to the Touch, but if you're in the market for a Nano, you don't care about the apps or browser.  Off the top of my head, there isn't really anything the Nano does that the Zune can't, except record video (in the case of the 5th gen model).  I test drove both a Zune HD and 3rd gen Touch for a couple weeks trying to decide which one to keep.  I thought the Zune was a much better media player, and loved the form factor.  It was very well built and surprisingly light.  I enjoyed the feel of it much more than my brother's 5th gen Nano.  I never did try bringing it into the gym or anything like that though; I wasn't sure I was going to keep it, so I was careful not to abuse it.  Ultimately I wound up returning both devices, as they were both way more than I needed in a music device.  But I think those looking for an alternative to the older Nanos ought to at least consider the Zune HD.  Or try and get away with something like a Sansa Fuze (what I have now - they can be found cheap refurbished).

Author: Myrna Minkoff
Comment: You gym people seem to think that it is all about the d@mn gym.  Granted, the shuffle is ideal for that environment, but -- believe it or not -- people enjoy them in many environments, including exercise that takes place under a clear blue sky where FM signals are not impeded by concrete.  I am almost never without one of my Shuffles (which I greatly prefer to my Gen 5 Nano).  I have them loaded up with audio books and language courses, as well as music.  Rather than being annoyed by the queues or reception rooms or life's other little "waits," I almost look forward to such times; no time is wasted.  I also wear one much of the time when I am at home, because I can move about from room to room and chore to chore, inside and out, while continuously listening to whatever I choose.  (One of my favorite times is when the mowers and leaf-blowers assault the grounds around my townhome.)  As sleek and cool as other recent Nanos have been, the additional size and weight and, especially, the lack of a clip made them much less friendly as constant companions during a variety of activities.  I am so overstocked already with iPods that I may not pounce immediately on this one although for my use it appears to be the best package yet.    Gyms, smelly sneakers, and sweating to the oldies....piffle!

Author: Your Role Model
Comment: Here's a (warning: long) comment I wrote under Bob Penn's review... I brought it over here because I think it brings up a number of interesting thoughts regarding this.   Hopefully no one takes major offense at my line of reasoning... it's just one man's speculation, nothing to get too jihadi about.   >> Hey Bob, nice review. I think you're largely right in your replication of Apple's reasoning here... but I also think Apple is probably going to end up being wrong in their calculation that the Nano audience is going to be happy being told to "just go buy a Touch" if they miss certain features that the new Nano (aka 'Super Shuffle') lacks. Or if they just plain do not dig the very small screen size.   And I say this as someone who *likes* the new Nano/Super Shuffle... a lot. It's very good for its intended use. But not everyone wants a pure 'gym' shuffle, and all those who want something else don't automatically want a Touch, either. Those ppl are now pretty unhappy.  Worse, this move leaves a significant hole in Apple's line-up, which no doubt Microsoft, Sansa, and the rest will attempt to exploit. Again, some ppl *do* want a relatively full-featured player that's significantly smaller than a Touch, and which can pull double-duty as being both a gym-player and a cool 'media' player to have anywhere else as well.  Sure, one could easily argue that such a player is 'jack of all trades, master of none', and there's some truth to that... but that doesn't stop a significant segment of the market from still wanting one- especially if they've owned Nanos in the past. And those ppl will vote with their wallets.   Consider too that if you're one of the ppl who never watched video on their Nanos because you thought even the 5th gen screen was too small... how much more screen real estate could Apple have gained by keeping the overall size similar (maybe a bit wider and shorter), ditching the clickwheel, and making the entire front a touchscreen? Realistically, quite a bit more screen could've been had, and I think that's what 5th gen Nano fans were hoping for/anticipating. Boy, were they surprised... hence some of the angry comments and reviews. =  I myself am a hardcore *Apple* fan, not a hardcore *Nano* fan, but I can understand where the Nano fans are coming from.  The annoying thing is, we WILL probably see such a 'true' Nano touchscreen player before too long... from one of Apple's competitors. =[  Which highlights the real head-scratcher in all this for me- that this really didn't have to be an 'either/or' choice from Apple. They could've made Super Shuffles AND MultiTouch 'true' Nanos, and both would've sold very well... while leaving zero daylight for the competition.  Thus, the only rationale I can think of for diverting from such a strong strategy/iPod line-up and leaving such a hole is that Apple wanted to push (shove?) the Nano crowd towards the Touch, both for the higher ASP (average selling price) and, perhaps more importantly, because this makes more people into 'apps' buyers... which in turn attracts developers and helps push the entire iPhone/iTouch platform.   This ends up being a 'snowball effect': More apps buyers = more developers = more apps = more reason to purchase an iPhone/iPod Touch = more iPhone/iPod Touch buyers = more apps bought = more devs = more apps = more reason to buy an iPhone/iPod Touch..., etc. etc. It's a pretty awesome feedback loop of *cha-ching!* for Apple. But that's no comfort to former Nano fans, who loved the prior form factor and feature set.  Thus, I predict there's going to be quite a run on 5th gen Nanos. And after those are gone, the Nano crowd is likely up for grabs.  Apple will probably convert many into Touch users, but they may lose more than they banked on as well.  An accompanying reason might be that Apple is just really into a device being perfect for its intended function, and the old Nano didn't really meet that standard. But I think that's Apple not really understanding that 'truly portable media player' is a valid function as well.

Comment: I think you have this in reverse. The Nano died when they decided to turn a portable music player into a useless multi-function device. Author: Your Role Model
Comment: Whoa, strong opinions, John. But in the end, they're just that... an opinion. You have yours, and others have theirs.  In yours, you got mad when you saw Apple adding features to the Nano with the 3G, 4G, and 5G models. However, many other folks would disagree, and actually liked those changes. The Nano line has certainly never lacked for sales, in any of its iterations.  The funny thing is that you flame me and take me to task as if I was some sort of 'champion' of  those added features. Re-read my review carefully and you'll see that I'm actually not... I simply state where fans of the previous gen Nano stand on the issue. It's called providing context.  *My* review, if you bother to actually read it, judges the 6G Nano on its own merits in the role Apple has assigned to it... that of a 'gym'/workout music player. And the things it gets dinged on are not that it's not a 5G, but rather the ways it falls down on the job as said gym/workout player, plus the value-for-money proposition.   Some of your comments are quite curious, though. Why would you "laugh your ass off" at someone taking a picture with their mp3 player? I don't use any of mine for that, but some ppl do. Did you also "laugh your ass off" at ppl when they first started to take pictures with their flip cameraphones? Do you currently laugh your ass off at ppl taking pictures with their iPod Touchs? If so, I bet you get a lot of funny looks. ;)   As far as sound quality goes, you do realize of course that 90-95% of iPod users just use the stock headphones or similar, and never plug a headphone amp into the dock connector, the 'big feature' you're so head over heels about, right? Just another case of someone thinking that THEIR usage pattern is only valid one, I guess.  And your final comment- "If you actually had a clue about what you were reviewing you would have at least given it 4 stars"- is quite silly. Nearly 50% of Amazon Nano reviewers (over 200 reviewers) have given the 6G Nano three stars or less. But all those ppl "don't have a clue" because their opinion does not match up with that of the lone, self-annoited expert? Wow. Good luck with that.   While zealotry can be fun (and I've been guilty of it myself from time to time), being dismissive of large numbers of ppl for simply having different opinions/tastes/usage patterns ultimately says more about the dismisser than those dismissed.  Enjoy your nano John, and get the new 1.1 Software Update for it. It addresses a couple of significant issues that 'those without a clue' pointed out repeatedly.   Guess Apple feels differently from you, since they if not you realized that there were significant deficits in the player that needed addressing, and took steps to do so. Cheers.

Author: Peter Hunt
Comment: Great review, particularly the discussion about the product placement in the iPod/iPhone lineup. I think you're right on the money.  I think Apple are smart to pare down the nano to being "targeted to the highly mobile exercise crowd", as you describe it. The HD video and Retina screens on the new iPhone and iPod Touch makes the fifth gen nano video look very substandard in comparison - and Apple doesn't do substandard.  Unfortunately, I think the replacement of the click wheel with a touchscreen on the new nano makes it less effective as the kind of player they've designed it to be. Having to stop running, cycling or working out to look at the screen and skip to the next song, back up in a podcast, and so on, is a bit cumbersome.

Author: SFLS
Comment: I'm in the technology industry but this is too long and complex - and the wrong audience - audience here are consumers.

Author: Dizzel
Comment: I couldn't agree with this review more.  Personally I didn't use the video playback of the 5th gen because the screen was just too small.  I also didn't use the video camera because it took less than decent video.  I have a pocket HD camera for video. The games weren't appealing either.  The bottom line is that I wanted a small mp3 player that I could workout with or travel with.  Obviously the smaller the Nano the better for me.  I don't understand why people compare this to a shuffle when you can pick an album or artist and play the songs you want to hear, unlike a shuffle.    My only complaint with Apple is that they probably have stripped many of the popular items from the sixth generation only so they can add them to forthcoming generations.  If the 6th generation had all of the old specs and apps what else could they add to the 7th gen. to make you interested?  I believe all of those items will return and old nano users will be happy after double and triple dipping.

Author: Tim Kaiser
Comment: I agree. Love the new direction of the Nano line. Who needs games, movies, a camera, contacts, calendars, etc. I just want a solid music player. If I want all that other stuff then I'll buy a touch or use my cell phone or my digital camera, etc.   When people say it's a "shuffle with a screen" I think that's exactly what Apple intended.

Author: sparkalicious
Comment: I travel  a lot, and on long flights I usually just want to listen to music and nothing more.  I love my Shuffle but it lacks storage; I love my Touch but its battery life is less than stellar. The new Nano is the perfect solution for me, and since it has a clip I won't be in danger of dropping it! Nothing worse than a device that slips out of your hands and disappears under the seat (and slides all the way to the back of the plane on take-off!)  For travel, for walking and working out, and for commuting on the train, a "shuffle with a screen" is just exactly what I needed.

Author: Brenda Stander
Comment: I totally agree with your review especially your comments about Apple's different product uses. I have an 80GB Classic with stores all my music and used exclusively in the living room docking station. My iPhone I use for apps, camera, internet, mail etc. My iPad for ebooks, movies, games, internet etc. etc. I also use it in place of my laptop while on vacation. However, in my case... my 3rd and 4th generation Nanos are used only for audiobooks (and maybe some music) while commuting, doing chores, walking the dog and exercising. I don't need any other functions on my Mp3 payer, although I really love the idea of the pedometer. I have never used any of my iPods for video, games, contacts, calendar or anything else. Even WAY before my iPhone and iPad - I didn't bother with games or whatever on my iPod. For that reason, I didn't go for the 5th generation, but even if I had had one - I wouldn't have used it for camera functions. This small Nano Clip with touch functions is just ideal for me. No more wires getting tangled, no more hopping iPods. Gorgeous, secure and above all SMALL. Just wonderful. So basically, even though some people don't seem to appreciate how appropriate, useful and wonderful it is, many others have been waiting for YEARS for this. I know I have! I'm getting the red one :). Oh... just one thing... I would love if this Nano had Bluetooth (with wrap around behind the head earphones). Thanks for the nice review. P.S. I don't agree with the people calling it a Shuffle... a Shuffle has no screen and can't play audiobooks properly and book or album art can't be enjoyed. A shuffle is ONLY for songs played randomly AFAIK. I think the Shuffle still has it's place on it's own merits. For eg. the young skateboarding crowd, and for the many other extreme sports, where a solid, small music player - WITHOUT a glass screen is preferable.

Author: Myrna Minkoff
Comment: >>1) This unit does not have a way to completely shut it off...only a sleep wake button. If you do not make absolutely sure that all music is stopped, the radio is off, this thing drains battery life very quickly because you cannot fully shut the unit off.   In many ways, I want this thing.  But the comment above is a deal-breaker.  I have a 5th Gen NANO and several lovely Shuffles.  All I really want from the device is audio (including the radio) and the ability to navigate in it.  I love the Shuffle-like form factor.  On the surface, this would appear to be my ultimate device.  BUT...I never use my 5th Gen NANO.  And the reason is that it is ~always~ out of battery.  No matter how careful I try to be the thing seems to defeat me.  For me, it was a complete waste of a lot of money.  I've read the manual for this one and their "intelligent" power management sounds good.  But having been so badly burned before, I can not ignore this review. (One of the greatest thing about the Shuffles is that you have to almost make a willful effort to run them out of battery.)

Author: Erica Reid
Comment: Fantastic review! I was hoping that maybe the small look was not as small as I thought, but I just saw one up close and it's safe to say that I will not purchase. Touch screen is aggravating enough on a full size but to add that feature to such a small frame means I will be getting pretty annoyed. I have the Zune HD and I am not thrilled on how thin it is and I am not so keen on the touch screen but other than that it's a great player so I will stick with what I have! I am still looking for an Ipod I can buy that won't agitate me and it sounds like this one will not be it either.

I bought mine only a few weeks after its release and have used many different IEMs (Klipsch, Denon, Sony, Ultimate Ears) and each plug into the headphone jack VERY securely.  I cannot comment on the radio antenna because I do not use the radio.  But the 1/8" plugs I use all give a reassuring *click* each time I plug them in.  Also, the volume control- what you described sounds like a software bug or defect.  I have not encountered this problem and in fact love the volume control and the granularity of adjustment.  I wish I could say the same for my iPad, where each click of the volume is equal to about 3 clicks on my Nano... VERY annoying.

My wife gave me one, yesterday, for Christmas, and I discovered all of your mentioned flaws inside four hours of ownership.   the radio reception seems directly linked to the fitting of the headset jack into the Nano; which, mostly, means it doesn't. Making the radio useless.

Author: D. Varga
Comment: Having owned the 16g for nearly a month now, and with daily use I have not noted any of the problems mentioned by M. Chapman with the exception of not being able to actually stop the music. The first thing I loose when getting a new mP3 player is the inferior ear buds. And iPod ear buds are no exception. I use a set of high-end Sony's. The sound is far superior and they connect very securely. Volume control works as advertised. I don't use the radio and don't know anyone that does. I would rather apple use that space for something more useful. I deselected the "shake to shuffle" option after accidentally shuffling an audio-book. I happily downloaded my manual, not wanting to accumulate more "paper" in my office. My unit does not have the Nike+ feature, so I cannot comment on that issue....sounds like defective units...which I agree doesn't sound so good for iPod products.

Author: SBG Reviews

Comment: Thank you, SBG and Joel, for the correction.  I mentioned the volume buttons in the fourth paragraph, but I agree that my subsequent description makes it sound like you can't adjust the volume without looking at the device. That is not correct, and I didn't mean to imply it; in mentioning volume control, I was describing what the click wheel *can* do, and I should have been more specific about what the new nano *can't* do.  Thanks again for your comments.

Author: Martin Jaszczuk
Comment: Let me start by saying that I'm the farthest thing from an Apple fanboy, but your review is too critical based on your bias.  Just because you're used to the click wheel doesn't mean that the buttons on the touchscreen will not appear on the same quadrant of the Nano as they always do... you just have to get used to it.  Aside from the fact that the item is overpriced, your criticism is unfounded.  Why would physical buttons for volume be harder to use than the click wheel?  In my opinion (and most others) a physical volume button is easier to use than adjusting to the click wheel.  Please do me a favor and re-asses this product once you get used to its features, because your negative comments seem like they'd be positive changes to me.  But, then again, everyone's feedback on any particular item is relative... you like it or you don't.  It's a given that this item is solid to the touch and will endure the test of time.

Author: Peter Hunt
Comment: I don't want to appear argumentative, but let me reply at length, since I think I probably wasn't clear enough in my original review about my main criticism of the new nano. I don't expect or hope to convince anyone of anything; I just want to state my opinion more clearly.  I agree that if you're sitting on your sofa at home, or standing on the train, or walking down the street, that the new controls for the nano are just fine. If you can stop to find the buttons or use the touch screen to adjust the volume or find the next song, then cool.  But to me, and to other reviewers I've read, the appeal of the nano has always been in its portability. Based on the reduction in size and the new clip on the back of this model, Apple are clearly positioning this product as an "mp3 player when you're on the go". It's the player you use for running, cycling or even if you're just working on the house or the garden.  And this is where I think the loss of the click wheel hurts the product. With the click wheel, you can adjust the volume, seek within a track, or skip to the next or previous tracks, without looking at the device. That's handy when you're running, cycling, driving or concentrating on anything visual.  With the touch screen, having to stop and look at the product while making these adjustments is more cumbersome. It's not the end of the world, but it's simply not as convenient as the click wheel on the previous product. Even when adjusting the volume, the click-wheel is easier to find and use than struggling with two small buttons on the edge of the nano.  This isn't my bias in favour of the click wheel, it's my evaluation of the effectiveness of the new design when using the product in the situations it's been designed for.  Finally, let me just say that I like Apple's products a lot, and I am always excited to see what they come up with. They've done an amazing job in reducing the size of this device, and in putting a touch screen on something so small and still making it usable. The three stars I gave the new nano are three full stars. It's still a pretty good mp3 player.  The trouble I see is that given how Apple are positioning the nano, I don't think a touch screen benefits the device's purpose, no matter how beautifully engineered it is. The click wheel was a better tool for the job.

Author: J. Wilson
Comment: I totally agree with you Peter and decided not to purchase the Nano after playing with it for a while for the reasons you pointed out.  Also, I listen to a lot of podcasts and audiobooks and the FF and RW buttons look like a nightmare because accidentally tapping one will loose your place in the book or podcast.  If I had infant sized fingers it may not be a problem but I don't.

Comment: The new nano does have a photo app very similar to the iPod Touch or iPhone, so the review isn't even correct.  Apple in this incarnation of iPods is clearly trying to push people up.  an iPod Shuffle 4GB? No more, only 2GB. Buy the new Nano, at 8GB or 16GB. iPod Nano with video? Author: Jeremiah Puckett
Comment: Agreed!  The OP has probably never thought about exercising anything but his bicep doing potato chip curls, or he'd know the fitness crowd is exactly what this version is for.  I have an 80 GB Zune and an 8 GB Creative Zen Microphoto.  The Zune has the pretty, large screen and the capacity.  The Microphoto (purchased first) is smaller and a tad lighter.  Both stay at home 99.9999% of the time I "could" be using it.  Both are just too heavy and bulky to be wearing while rowing, biking, jogging, hiking, working, etc.  This new Nano is perfect for working out, taking on the trails, etc.  It's 0.74 oz. according to the Apple website.  (That's about 3 US quarters in the hand.)  Ignore all the fat potato chip eating fools!  This is for the fit!  This is for those that want to listen to music.  I don't need bloated software.  I don't need a crappy camera.  I don't need video capability that I will NEVER use.  If you want an ultra-light, ultra-slim MP3 player, this is a good option.  The price is a tad high, so consider the 8GB version.  I know, I know.  For $30 more, you can double the capacity.  Do you REALLY need that much more space?  8 GB will hold over 100 hours of music, assuming 192 kbps MP3.  You will have to charge this thing a dozen times to listen to all that music.  While charging, swap a few songs.  NO ONE "needs" more space.

Author: John P. Galloway
Comment: It should be noted that when you format to MS-DOS for the mac.  You are selecting FAT32 file structure.   FAT32 has a few limitations such as limits of 4gig for any files, and some Mac applications may not run because FAT32 doesn't adequately handle the permission structure of OS X. (Konfrst, 2008) However, this shouldn't be an issue with simply backing up.  http://www.myfirstmac.com/index.php/mac/articles/1-external-hard-drive-for-your-mac-and-pc

Author: Valjean
Comment: To use this disk on a Mac, go to Disc Utility, highlight the drive on the left, look for the "partition" tab and click that.  Under "Volume Scheme" select 1 partition (or however many you want).  Select Mac OS Extended (Journaled) or whatever you need/want.  Click "options" and deselect "Master Boot Record" and use something else (I used GUID Partition Table), rename the disc and click apply and you're done and disc is usable.  I just did this on a Mac running 10.5.8.  I got errors when using the first instructions listed in this comment, so I wanted to post what I did and what worked for me.

Author: MaggieToo9
Comment: I use an NTFS file format on my drives; however, I DO want a drive to drop into sleep mode after a period of non-use (reading, saving, copying count as 'use').  Are you saying that the sleep feature will not work if the drive is formatted for NTFS?    I have a Toshiba that drops into sleep mode when not in use and a Passport that does not (both are NTFS formatted, so apparently the 'sleep' feature on the Toshiba is handled by either hardware or firmware (which are not changed by reformatting), not handled by software (which would be wiped out by a reformat).  When a drive goes into "sleep" mode, that means the disk stops spinning - it is not possible for a copy process to continue after a drive stops spinning.  A drive should NOT go into "sleep" mode while a copy/save/read is in process, but only after a specific period of NO activity (read or write) on the drive.    I was interested in this drive, but not if the sleep feature will be lost by a reformat to NTFS.  How do you know this will happen?  Does your reformatted drive continue to spin when there is NO access to the drive at all for 30 minutes or more?
