Author: Pankaj Gupta
Comment: I am sure you have ample experience with professional Nikons (D700 to begin with). However, comparing an entry level amateur camera to a professional-grade D700 seems wrong. Before I proceed, I am adding that I do have a D700 and FX lenses to match.  I can agree that under good lighting conditions, and using a similar lens (and aperture) both camera's could come up with a similar looking photograph. However, I think, similarities end about there. Now, we are talking about two entirely different classes of cameras.   One (D3100) is an entry level amateur camera meant as a basic DSLR. The other (D700) is a full professional equipment, which costs about 8 times the other (when taking an appropriate lens into account. I am taking a 70-200f2.8 as an example lens). A basic setup of a D700 with a 70-200 f2.8 lens (or a 24-70 f2.8 lens) would cost about 5000 USD.   - D700 feels and operates on a different level than amateur cameras. The first time you hold it in your hand and use it, it feels like a professional equipment, not an amateur toy.  - D700 has amazingly low noise. When light is ample (day time), I prefer to use 200 iso and not 100. At 200, you cannot detect any noise visually in the D700. At 1600 iso, the colors and noise level of the D700 are still aesthetically pleasing.  - D700 has a body of a tank, and fits the higher profile professional FX lenses like nikon 70-200 f2.8 perfectly.  - D700 has features like frame-burst of 8fps, intervalometer etc. which are not to be found in the amateur range.  I am sure that what are saying is that D3100 is a decent camera, and will fit the bill for most people. To compare it feature by feature with a D700 seems like a futile exercise to me, unless you were doing it for your own amusement!   [Just wanted to supplement your review]

I am not a sports photographer making my living off my photographs who might want a 8 fps. But D700 has a burst mode where it takes 8 fps. Also, attach a grip and you do get 8 fps. Author: Neil H.
Comment: Nice review. As you say, the D3100 (like the other small-body Nikons in the D40 family) can't autofocus with really older lenses, i.e. those made before about 2003 that do not have an AF motor in the lens itself. However, I presume the D3100 does have an electronic rangefinder in the viewfinder, like the D60 and D3000, that works very well with those older lenses. I am not speaking of the simple focus confirmation light way over on the bottom left that's in all Nikon DSLRs, which is sometimes CALLED an "electronic rangefinder" (causing some confusion), but an actual rangefinder scale that shows when you are approaching or passing correct focus. It is not turned on by default (the scale is used for other information) but has to be turned on through the menu system.

Author: Neil H.
Comment: Ken Rockwell is always worth reading, but it should be remembered that he is extremely opinionated -- and his opinions reverse from time to time, so I would take them with a grain of salt. Yes, the 18-105mm VR does have some barrel distortion at the short end (as most zoom lenses do) and mild pincushion distortion at most other focal lengths. The fact is that for most subjects, i.e. subjects that DON'T have long straight lines near the edges of the picture, you will never notice this distortion. And anyway where it is noticeable it can easily be corrected, either automatically in-camera if your Nikon has that feature, or afterward in software. It really isn't anything to worry about. And the 18-105 is a SUPERB lens as far as definition and contrast are concerned, which is far more important than the modest amount of distortion. Again, this pattern of distortion -- barrel at the short end and pincushion at the long end -- is common to virtually all zoom lenses.

Author: Neil H.
Comment: The 18-105mm VR Nikkor is an excellent all-around lens. I wouldn't worry about any negative comments from Ken Rockwell if I were you; he tends to go overboard one way or the other. As you say, Nikon introduced this lens as the standard kit lens with the D90 and after about two years is keeping it as such with the D7000, which tells you something.  I have about a dozen Nikon lenses from the 10.5mm fisheye to the 70-300mm VR, and the 18-105mm VR is one of my favorites.

Author: Neil H.
Comment: Absolutely, your SB-600 (or any other Nikon CLS flash unit) should work just fine with the D3100. You can pretty much count on that for all Nikon DSLRs for the foreseeable future. If Nikon ever does decide to change from their Creative Lighting System to something else, which seems unlikely, it will be big news and we'll all hear about it.

Author: EMH
Comment: Regarding QIOMD's post earlier...  It's not unusual for photo software to not support newly-released cameras right away (this affects all DSLRs from all manufacturers, so not unique to the D3100). They will add support fairly quickly though, usually in the form of a downloadable patch.

Author: SD Book Lover
Comment: I have a Nikon D50 right now.  I have 2 lenses for it.  Will they fit this Nikon?

Author: Neil H.
Comment: The lenses for your D50 will fit the D3100 just fine. Whether they will AUTOFOCUS on it depends on whether they have an AF motor built in, since the D3100 (like other small-body Nikons in the D40 family but unlike your D50) does not have an AF motor in the camera body itself.  If your lenses are Nikon products put on the market since about 2003, they are almost certainly AF-S lenses and will work fine in every way on the D3100. (But note that some Nikon lenses still being sold brand new are actually pre-2003 models.)  If it says "AF-S" and/or "SWM" somewhere on the lens it will work fine. Older Nikon lenses and some third-party lenses would have to be focused manually, but apart from that should work just fine.   Another way to tell is to take off the rear lens cap and count the contacts. If there are only five contacts the lens does not have a built-in motor and would have to be focused manually on the D3100. If there are more contacts (typically eight or ten) the lens does have a built-in motor and will autofocus on the D3100.

Author: Neil H.
Comment: Arch --   There is no question that the D90 is a far more capable camera than the D3100 or any of the other small-body Nikons in the D40 family. I have seven Nikon DSLRs in various models and sizes and like them all. The more compact ones are great just because they are small in size and light in weight, but the D90 can do things the little guys just cannot do. Many users and especially beginners will not need those extra capabilities, and those people are the intended market for the D3100 et al. If your intentions are more ambitious and you plan on buying only one DSLR, the D90 is the one that makes the most sense, especially now that the price has dropped so much. It really is a great bargain.

Author: Arch
Comment: Thanks Neil.  Wow, why would you need 7 DSLRs?!!  That's awesome.  I am waiting to see if the D90 price tanks a bit more.  Do you have any recommendation for lenses?  I am thinking of getting the Nikon 18-200mm lense just so I don't have to switch lenses too frequently.  Any recommendations on additional lenses i could expand to in a few months?

Author: Neil H.
Comment: You're welcome, Arch.  Heh. I don't *need* seven DSLRs -- nobody does. I'm afraid I'm just one of those sappy people who accumulates a lot of stuff they don't actually need. I expect I'll sell off at least one or two of these Nikons, my D40 and maybe my D60. I'll keep at least one small-body Nikon, the D3000 (almost the same as the D3100 in most respects). My others are the D70s (my very first Nikon DSLR), the D80 that followed it, the D200 (which I never use, but I got it at a very good closeout price and it's so nifty I'll just keep it in my collection) and finally the D90. Eventually I'll get the new D7000 also, but not till it's about to be replaced with the next model and the price has come down -- probably about two years from now. That's when I prefer to buy cameras, when the next model is about due. I doubt the D90 price will fall much lower; in fact it has been creeping up a bit since I got mine here on Amazon. The price changes almost daily. Today I see it (body only) is $773.95 here, which is about a dollar more than I paid for mine in early April.   I have quite a few of the Nikon lenses, including the 18-200mm VR you're asking about. It is really a great all-in-one lens, though it's not the sharpest Nikon lens by any means and I think the Tamron 18-270mm VC lens (which I also have) is actually a bit better, especially at the long end. One of the *best* lenses though is Nikon's 18-105mm VR which is the usual kit lens you get with a D90 when you buy the camera with lens. Obviously it doesn't have the zoom range of either the Nikon 18-200 or the Tamron 18-270, but overall it is sharper than either. And it's a lot less expensive than either, especially if bought with the camera. It does not have some of the deluxe features of the Nikon 18-200; for example it does not have the distance scale window and it has a plastic lens mount instead of metal, which annoys some people. I've used Nikon's kit lenses with plastic mount on all my cameras and never had any fail me yet -- I suspect it's just that some buyers like the idea of a metal mount more than plastic. In any case, the 18-105 VR is a great lens at a great price. Nikon's 18-135mm lens is also excellent, not quite the equal of the 18-105  perhaps but close, however it does not have VR. And you definitely want VR (or VC in the case of a Tamron lens).

I'll wait may be just a little bit more if it comes back.

Author: Neil H.
Comment: Arch, you're quite welcome. I have been meaning to put some pix up on Flickr but haven't gotten around to it yet. By all means, if you can get a deal like the D90 + 18-200 VR for $1205 I would certainly go for it.   One thing I didn't mention about the Nikon 18-200 is that like some other long zooms it evidently has "zoom creep" which annoys some users -- i.e., if the camera is carried lens down as it would be when carried slung around one's neck or shoulder by the strap, the weight of the front end tends to make it slide out toward the 200mm end. I have actually never had this problem myself, perhaps because I just haven't carried it very far that way. Anyway I understand the latest version of this lens has a lock to prevent it doing this. (As the Tamron 18-270 does, as a matter of fact.)

Author: Arch
Comment: >>Anyway I understand the latest version of this lens has a lock to prevent it doing this.  Neil, how are lens versioned?  How do I know i am looking at the latest 18-200 lens - is it called VR2?

Author: Neil H.
Comment: That's actually a very good question, and Nikon has created a certain amount of confusion about this. The new version with zoom lock is indeed called "18-200mm (etc., etc.) VR II." However, my earlier version without lock also has VR II, the "II" in this case referring to the more advanced type of VR used on their more expensive lenses, which all the 18-200mm lenses have. So the II may refer to either the type of VR, or the lens version. As far as I can tell, where you see VR II in the lens description itself it refers to the latest version of lens. Another way you can tell probably is by the color of the "VR" on the lens. Nikon always used to fill the "VR" on their VR lenses with red paint, but a year or two ago they started making the "VR" in gold. So if the lens has "VR" in gold it should be the latest type with the zoom lock. My guess is that any new Nikon 18-200 VR you buy from Amazon will be the newest type.

Author: Cody H. Clemens
Comment: So for the Nikon D3100 the 18-200 would be the best zoom? The sales people sold me the 70-300 but from what I am reading I should take it back and get a different one? THANKS DARLA

Author: Neil H.
Comment: Darla, didn't your D3100 come with the 18-55 VR kit lens? That's the way it's usually sold; at least I've never seen it sold just the body alone, though it is possible some dealers might sell it that way.  If you do already have the excellent 18-55 VR, then the 70-300 VR is a fine choice for a second lens. If you DON'T have the 18-55, but only the 70-300, that is not a very good situation since you almost certainly would want something shorter for wide-angle, "normal" and short tele use -- which is what the 18-55 would be for.  Incidentally, when you speak of the 70-300 I assume you're talking about the Nikon 70-300mm VR lens. There are many other brands of 70-300mm lenses, as well as older Nikon 70-300 lenses that do not have VR.   Please advise what exactly it is you have. And if you DON'T have the 18-55 VR kit lens that normally comes with that camera, I would be curious to know why.  The 18-200 VR is a very good all-in-one lens, though more expensive than the 70-300 and generally not quite as sharp, though most users find it plenty sharp enough. If you feel you must have only the one lens for your camera (because you hate changing lenses or carrying a second lens), then yes, the Nikon 18-200 is your best choice among Nikon brand lenses. If you don't mind stepping outside the Nikon brand, I would recommend the Tamron 18-270 VC (in Tamronspeak, VC is the same thing as what Nikon calls VR). I have both lenses and am well satisfied with both, but published lens tests have shown the Tamron 18-270 to be sharper, especially at the long end -- and it's cheaper, too. There are pluses and minuses to both, but you wouldn't go wrong with either lens.

Author: gguess
Comment: Zoom lenses are never as sharp as fixed lenses, and the quality decreases as the use (age) increases.  If you're just shooting 'regular' photos (sporting events/action type shots) then a zoom is OK.  The 18-200 gives you more light and wider shots, but the 70-300 gives you more power (distance).  If you want the sharpest photos then use fixed lenses.  You'll have to decide upon how you're using the camera.

Author: Neil H.
Comment: OK. Darla, since you already have the 18-55 VR, which is an excellent lens, if I were you I would return the 70-300 and hold off on buying a second lens until you have a clearer idea of what exactly you need. Or if you have the urge to buy a second lens right away anyway, consider the 55-200 VR which is also an excellent lens and goes very well with the 18-55 you already have (since it starts at 55mm and therefore "picks up where the 18-55 leaves off" so to speak), and is much less expensive than the 70-300, as well as being lighter and more compact. Those are the two lenses I usually carry when I'm taking one of my own small-body Nikons, the 18-55 VR and the 55-200 VR. That makes a nice, small lightweight kit.  The 70-300 VR is an excellent lens itself, but bigger, heavier, more expensive than the 55-200 and I question whether you really need a lens that long. It's intended for shooting at long distances, and/or for small subjects such as birds. But even with VR, that long a lens may be difficult for someone to use who isn't fairly experienced in handling a DSLR.  Also, in your description of your 70-300 I notice that you do not mention "VR." There are several older Nikon lenses of that zoom range which did NOT have VR (which you absolutely, definitely want!) and also not with autofocus motor built into the lens itself, which means they would NOT autofocus on your D3100. There are in fact so many different Nikon 70-300 lenses being sold used out there, or perhaps in some cases old but "new" stock (i.e., never sold before) that the subject is sort of confusing.  Here's how my Nikon 70-300 VR lens is marked on top of the lens barrel just ahead of the mount:  Nikon ED AF-S NIKKOR 70-300mm 1:4.5-5.6 G  VR (in red)  If your lens isn't marked VR then it doesn't have that image-stabilization feature, and that alone is reason for you to return it.  Apart from that: your lens being marked "G" means it is an autofocus lens, but if it isn't also marked "AF-S" it doesn't have an autofocus motor in the lens itself, but requires an autofocus motor in the camera body. That is something your D3100 (like other small-body DSLRs -- D40, D60 etc.) does not have. So it should autofocus on the larger bodied Nikons that do have the in-body motor (D70, D80, etc., etc.) but not on yours. In that case, if the dealer knew your camera was a D3100 he never should have sold you that lens.  You can also check this by taking off the rear lens cap and counting the number of contacts you see. If there are only five contacts, the lens does NOT have the built-in motor and will not autofocus on your camera. If it has more than that (typically eight or ten) then it does have the built-in motor.

Comment: Darla, I KNOW your 18-55 VR lens will autofocus on your D3100 body. What I was saying is that not all Nikon lenses will, and some Nikon 70-300 lenses will not, because those older lenses do not have the autofocus motor in the lens itself which your D3100 requires.   Now, as for the "AF 70-200mm 1:2.8 APODG HSM" you bought, that sounds like a Sigma lens and not a Nikon. That may be OK, but it seems to me like a lot of lens for a small body like the D3100, and I question whether you need that fast a lens. You certainly are "jumping in with both feet" as you say. Good luck with it!

Author: KarenB
Comment: Thanks so much for the terrific review. I just got my d3100 about 2 weeks ago and have been having problems with flash in auto mode because the ISO defaults to 3200 every time. This has got to be a glitch and is very frustrating. I saw this problem mentioned in a couple of other reviews and wondered if you've experienced it. If I can't figure out how to solve it, I'll switch to using program mode and limit the ISO to a lower number. Have you had similar results with flash set on auto mode? Thanks again! Karen

Author: Macauley
Comment: Hi Karen, Yes, it's a known glitch of the D3100 firmware that will probably be fixed with the next firmware update. It does it in every mode, even my favorite P(rogram) mode if the AUTO ISO option is enabled in the MENU.   If Auto ISO is selected, it's not that the ISO defaults to 3200, but rather defaults to whatever ISO the camera would have chosen with the flash off. I mostly don't mind that because I've selected a still-clean ISO 800 as my max ISO (camera defaults to 3200) and am okay with the camera using ISO up to 800 for my candid interior shots (less power demand on the flash), but if you do mind it, then you should disable auto ISO under MENU, assign your FN button (below the flash button) to ISO selection, and choose your ISO manually. Remember, this you have to do regardless of the shooting mode you are in (auto, A, P, S etc...)  I leave auto ISO on and only disable it under MENU for shots that require ISO 100 or 200 (real estate shots on a tripod, for example). I use my FN button for white balance since, for me, that's more critical than ISO on modern cameras that have a clean ISO up to iso 800.  Hope this helps.

Author: KarenB
Comment: Thanks so much for the terrific review. I just got my d3100 about 2 weeks ago and have been having problems with flash in auto mode because the ISO defaults to 3200 every time. This has got to be a glitch and is very frustrating. I saw this problem mentioned in a couple of other reviews and wondered if you've experienced it. If I can't figure out how to solve it, I'll switch to using program mode and limit the ISO to a lower number. Have you had similar results with flash set on auto mode?   Actually, I just tried lowering the ISO in P mode, and the camera suddenly goes to extremely slow shutter speeds. It's like the camera doesn't recognize that there's going to be light from the flash. Any idea what's going on? I'm thinking of sending it back. Thanks again! Karen

Author: KarenB
Comment: Oops, sorry for the double post with the slight addition. And thanks for the response. Yes, it does it in every mode I've tried. I just now saw your post - thanks, I'll try that.  I don't understand why the shutter speed gets so slow if I use a lower ISO - doesn't the camera recognize that it could use a faster shutter speed since there will be light from the flash? Or maybe it's because of how I've set the flash??  Thanks again!

Author: Macauley
Comment: Karen, If you lower the ISO, the camera shutter will have to stay open longer to gather more light; at ISO 800, the camera will have to gather 4 times as much light as it does at ISO 3200, hence the shutter speed is going to be lower (say, 1/8th of a second instead of 1/60th of a second. This is okay for still subjects with the image stabilized lens that comes with the camera; it's not okay with moving subjects. In that case, you should use a faster lens, like the 35mm 1.8 DX. A faster 1.8 aperture will offset the slow shutter speed since it can gather over 3 times as much light as a 5.6 aperture, so you will be back to shooting at a higher shutter speed. Frank

Author: Macauley
Comment: Because of the firmware glitch, the camera does not increase the flash output to allow for a faster shutter speed, but it defaults to what the camera would have selected without the flash.  To offset the problem, you may want to select the S mode and select the shutter speed you need (say 1/60th of a second) and also the max ISO you want, then let the camera worry about aperture and flash output.

Author: KarenB
Comment: Ok, thanks, I'll give that a try. I like much of what the camera does and don't want to send it back. But I'm wondering if I should have gotten the Canon T2I.  Do you think Nikon will fix this firmware glitch? I just learned that there's been a firmware update... which will be another challenge for a non-techie like me! It doesn't appear, though, from what I've ready that this particular update addresses the problem we're discussing regarding high ISO default in auto flash mode. Sigh. I've long used "bridge" cameras and have taken some pretty decent shots for an amateur (even won runner-up in two Fodor's contests!), but this is my first time trying a DSLR and much is new to me. I understand the basics - used an old Minolta 101 years and years ago as a teen-ager, but it was far less complicated!

Author: Macauley
Comment: I tried the Canon T2i and didn't like it. It had all of my beloved canon xsi's faults (see below) and none of its beautiful colors, plus switching from picture mode to movie mode was cumbersome (unlike the D3100, which makes it quick and easy).  Why I don't like the T2i: it's more work. if you enable auto iso, when you take flash shots, it defaults to iso 400, even in bright sunlight. At least the D3100 uses iso 100 in bright sunlight (as it should).  I like slow shutter speed for my interior shots (1/15th or 1/30th of a second with image-stabilized lenses), and can do so with the D3100 in P mode. Not with the Canon, which only does that in A mode (P mode defaults to 1/60th of a second). For my type of flash photography that's not good since my subject will be well lit while the background will be dark. With my D3100 I leave it in P mode, use slow sync flash, and concentrate on composition, which is the stuff that matters (and for which you won runner-up in the Fodor's contests. Congratulations!!!). I was willing to put up with the XSI's quirkiness because I loved the output; not so with the T2i, but that's me.  For me the D3100 gets out of the way better and lets me concentrate on composition.  If it is your first DSLR, I recommend one of the D3100 guides on Amazon (the magic lantern guide to the D3100 or "Nikon D3100: from snapshots to great shots" by Jeff Revell. You already have the compositional talent. You just need to master the D3100 way of doing things.  Hope this helps.

Author: KarenB

From what I've read, though, the 18-250 is a little better. The Nikon 18-200 is probably a little better yet, but for the difference in price, plus a bit more reach, I decided to try the Tamron. Most of my shots are taken while traveling (recently returned from India - which is a photographer's delight), and I definitely wanted an all-in-one lens solution.   With your tips (and others I've read), I'm hoping to make the most of the d3100's capabilities. And I'll be keeping my fingers crossed that Nikon releases a firmware update to fix the ISO problem.  Thanks again, Macauley, you've been so helpful. It's great to talk to someone who obviously knows what they're talking about but is able to put it in laymen's terms! And yes I'll look into one of the guides you recommend.  Karen

Author: Bruce
Comment: Perhaps there's a way of avoiding the ISO/Flash issue that I'm unaware of. One could always set the ISO manually. Then forced flash in "P" mode seems to act properly. But if the ISO is set to auto and flash is forced, the camera uses less flash light and more ISO high settings than it should. This makes for less than optimal flash photos.   If there's a fix, I'd love to hear it.

Author: Bruce
Comment: I knew about all the negatives except the extent of the ISO/flash problem. Ken Rockwell has a somewhat comprehensive review and he mentions the ISO/flash issue, but I never really thought it would be as intrusive as I've found it to be.   Re the grid lines, yes- they work in live view. No- they don't work through the viewfinder.

Author: Paladin08
Comment: Joan,  No, there is zero parental controls from what I could find.  Also, its as easy as a couple of button clicks for the user to remove their browsing history and cache.   Graphics/pictures appear in detailed greyscale, but no videos can be played on this device from what I've seen.  Also note, if the user leaves page xxxx and goes to the bookmarks list, then exits the browser. The next time they come to the browser, then page xxxx will display again, not the booksmarks page user thought they exited at.   User would need to select an actuall web site like Google in order for the returning page to be something different than page xxxx.  I think this is partly why Amazon is still calling the browswer "experimental", due to the lack of certain functionality.  Hope that helps., Erik (Paladin08)

Author: Lashunda N. Birks
Comment: Thank you so, so, so much for your review it help me in choosing the Kindle...I have a quick question about loading music onto my kindle...I load music to my music file in to my kindle music folder but when i try to listen to it...its saying no music in folder...thanks if you can help with this...~LaShunda

Author: Paladin08
Comment: Lashunda,  It's normally one of three things:  1) You copied a folder into the music folder. The kindle cannot read folders. . .thus you need to move all music together into the Music only folder. Yes there is no organization allowed with the music. It all needs to be grouped together in that single folder  2) I think I read that music files cannot be "protected" -- such as some music purchased through iTunes -- but I'm not sure how to tell if it is  3) Check to make sure you're files are actually MP3.  If it is not, you may need to check the internet on a way to convert your files. More step-by-step details on how to check if it is the right file type can be found here under the Music & Audio files section: http://www.amazon.com/gp/help/customer/display.html?ie=UTF8&nodeId=200510540  Otherwise you may need to contact Amazon technical support, but my understanding is the MP3 playback is considered an "experimental" features and thus they may not provide support on this.  Hope that helps, Erik

Author: Paladin08
Comment: Greetings Susie,  This is my first Kindle, so I cannot comment on Kindle 1 behavior. As people ask questions I try and figure it out, that is the only way I appear to know what I comment on.  To your first question, I started playing the Audible book, but as soon as I hit the Home button to switch to a book, the audio book is paused.  Now if I chose to load the audio book as part of the MP3 music selection (I assume I'd have to convert the audible audio book to MP3 and move files to the Music folder), I then could listen and read at the same time. Problem is, as noted in my review, once you stop the MP3 and restart, it starts back at the most recently track loaded. There is no pausing the MP3 to play from where you left off.  As far as re-registering, I bought 2 kindles, one for me and one for my wife. Each kindle was registered in my name. All I had to do was log into My Account > My Kindles and de-register one of the devices. Once de-registered, I gave the 2nd kindle to my wife. From the kindle device, she connected via wi-fi/3G to register the kindle to her Amazon account.  NOTE: I have seen posts on eBay that some so called previously owned and even "new" kindles don't have valid serial numbers. Thus, the ebay buyer gets a kindle at a great price, but can never register it with Amazon. They can still load books via USB, but getting on the internet or sending books via wifi/3G won't work.  Hope that answers your questions.

Author: EMF
Comment: I am ready for an eReader and doing my research, so finding your detailed video and info was very useful.  I just read another review listing battery replacement as a minus for the K3.  Apparently it lasts 1-2 years, then you have to send it back to Amazon for replacement.  Since they replace the entire K3, not just the battery, I wonder what happens to the content of your original K3?!?

Author: Paladin08
Comment: Greetings EMF,  My understanding is the following happens:  1) You can plug your original Kindle into your computer and simply copy all the items in the Documents folder and Music folder to your computer. When you get the replacement device, then copy the files back. It acts as a USB storage drive for the most part.  2) For any items that you purchased from Amazon, they are backed up/archived. . .this includes any bookmarks and notes you took on amazon purchased items and storied in your Kindle Library on Amazon's site. This also allows you to share the content between multiple devices (kindle, blackberry, iphone, etc) and keep the page numbers synched so regardless of what device you are reading on, it remembers what page you left off at.  Thus, when you get a replacement device it's supposed to download the archived books & notes to the new device, once you register the new device.    Unfortunately, I don't see an easy way to test this to prove exactly how smooth this process will work from one kindle to another.  Another thing to note, is that technology is constantly changing.  If Amazon cannot give me another Kindle 3 as a replacement (I did buy the extended warranty from square-trade), then I look forward to getting the Kindle 4 or 5 by then instead.   Unlike a heart rate monitor where being able to change out the battery myself or not is a show-stopper to buying one; I personally wasn't concerned about not being able to change the battery on the Kindle because I'm okay with being "forced" to upgrade in a couple of years.  But that is me.  Hope that helps, Erik

As far as 3G...this what Amazon says (please take note of the last line):  Important Information About the Coverage Map  Map may include areas served by unaffiliated carriers, and may depict their licensed area rather than an approximation of their coverage. Author: James Paskell
Comment: C. Stoneham,  Thanks for the review.  I'm thinging about purchasing a K3.  My concern after reading your review is the WPA enterprise.  Does this mean that if I buy a K3, and my router is password protected I can't download anything?  I'm a newbie at this so just asking, if you know.  Thanks, Jim

Author: C. Stoneham
Comment: Happy to help. Only if you happen to use the "enterprise" level of security can you expect to have trouble. Simply having a password doesn't necessarily translate to "enterprise." I can't claim intimate knowledge with wireless security protocols, but "WPA Enterprise" (and "WPA2 Enterprise") are security measures implemented by large businesses (corporations, universities, government installations, etc). Your home router will just use "WPA Personal" (or WPA2 (maybe even WEP, which isn't all that secure)) and the K3 will be fine with that. I'm sure someone else will come along who can explain the nitty-gritty better than I can, but the reality is that your home router will NOT be using Enterprise, so you're fine. When you get your K3, it'll likely see the network and then just ask for the passkey and you're good to go. If you visit Texas Christian University or Southern Methodist University, however, you'll be out of luck. ;)

Author: Rene'
Comment: I'm looking to purchase my first ebook reader and I have a question about the Kindle.  Will I be able to transfer ebooks that are in PDF format from my computer to the Kindle device?

Author: C. Stoneham
Comment: Yes, but I would caution against buying the 6" Kindle as a PDF reader. The Kindle screen is rather small, and though the K3 is much faster reading PDF's, you will still have to engage in a bit of panning to read parts of a PDF. The DX is much better suited to reading PDF's because of the large screen. It's certainly possible on the 6", but it's not "ideal." :)

Author: Rene'
Comment: Thank you so much for your quick reply!    One more question.  If I don't want to mess with the wireless aspect of the Kindle, can I buy "kindle books" from Amazon and download them to my computer, then transfer via usb to the Kindle?

Author: C. Stoneham
Comment: Yep! You sure can. There's an option in the "Manage Your Kindle" section of your Amazon account page that gives you the option to "Transfer via computer."

Author: Rene'
Comment: Thank you!!

Author: C. Stoneham
Comment: You bet :)

Author: Tariq
Comment: Rene,  C. Stoneham is right about the limitations with PDF files. Just wanted to add that Amazon lets you "convert" those PDFs to native Kindle format for free. The conversion is not 100% perfect (sometimes there are text alignment or spacing issues) but I always find the converted PDFs files more readable than the original ones because you don't have to pan and zoom.

Author: Reader
Comment: If I were to buy two of them would I be able to read all the same books on both or do I have to buy the books twice?

Author: C. Stoneham
Comment: Kindle books come with anywhere from 3 (rare) to 6 (common) use licenses. Buying the book once allows use on as many devices as you have licenses. For example, most of my books (purchased once) are now on my iPhone, my wife's iPhone, my Macbook, a spare PC,  and my Kindle 3. It will be exceedingly rare that you would ever need to buy a second copy of a Kindle book, especially since you can remove a book from a device to free up that "use."

Author: Liora Hess
Comment: It's turning into a widespread problem. Not just a few that people would like to believe. There are some who are going on their third replacement unit after having identical issues with previous Kindles. It would be easy to write this off as people with an axe to grind and just selectively posting about this, but some of us you can see we have a very high review rating and have established a good reputation here on Amazon. You can also go to an off-Amazon forum like the KindleBoards (at the same name dot com) where you'll see many of us long-time trusted Kindle fans at first thought this was a vocal minority and then the thread grew into serious concerns by all. If you read enough boards, you see that many who had no trouble for days suddenly did experience multiple crashes. Unfortunately, the problems are sporadic, and at this point, there's no guarantee a replacement is going to be any better.   I don't see that you've said you've done a hard reset yet. Kindle Support had me do that and had me do it for much longer than the 20 seconds I'm seeing recommended. He had me slide the on/off to the right, hold it for probably 90 seconds to 2 minutes, well past the reboot, the books reappearing. Hold it maybe 20 seconds past your books reappearing. Since then I have only had one immediate reboot right after that.   My plan is to hang onto the Kindle for at least a few days and see if more issues occur. If they do, then I know I'll be returning it, either for an exchange or just a refund (and waiting til they fix the bugs). If no more problems, then I may keep it. If news is released concerning a firmware update that will solve these issues that would help make a decision.

I thought it was broken for good just then.  I then placed it on the table and every few moments tried to reset it again.  One of my tries may have been about 2 minutes and I finally got a response out of it, the boot up screen with the progress bar; I guess that was a hard reset. Author: Terry Ligon
Comment: This may not be your problem, and your review dates from back in Sept, but concerning the random crashes, some new info has recently come to light.  Did you have an Amazon Kindle Leather cover you were using with your Kindle? If so, believe it or not, your problem may be a defective leather cover, not the Kindle itself.  To quote a recent owner: "Any chance you are using one of their leather cases with the metal connectors that hook the K3 to the case? I went through 4 units with this problem until, on the fifth, I finally reached a tech support person who asked if I used a Kindle cover/case and which kind. Turns out that some of them are defective, and since they have the new units that have the lights that run off the battery of the Kindle, those metal connectors actually do more than just connect the Kindle to the cover (whether or not you have the lighted model). My problem went completely away when I stopped using that case (after being on the 5th unit doing the freezing and restarting). (If that is your problem, note that they will send you a new case/cover.) I was pretty amazed that this solved the problem, but I could not believe that I could really get 5 defective ones in a row, so the possibility raised by the smart tech person immediately made sense to me as a possibility."  Here's the link to his full story: http://www.amazon.com/gp/cdp/member-reviews/A1A306IAZ3TM1/ref=cm_rna_own_review_more?ie=UTF8&sort_by=MostRecentReview#R2096VZNTZ3C9G  If you *do* own a Kindle leather cover (lighted or not. His wasn't lighted), remove it, reboot the Kindle (slide on/off switch to right & hold it there for 30 sec) and see if the self-rebooting continues.

Author: Terry Ligon
Comment: Liora, I would first see (if you've used the Kindle leather cover) if removing the leather cover fixes the problem of random reboots & freezes.

What's your take?

Author: J. Doherty
Comment: David,  You offer some compelling questions... I will try to answer them in turn with the knowledge I have of the PRS-650 since I haven't seen one in the wild and haven't been able to hold one in my own two hands.  K3 vs PRS-650 I was not aware of the upcoming PRS-350 and PRS-650 models at the time I pre-ordered the K3. I only became aware of them recently. It looks as though Sony has used infrared beams to create the touch interface which eliminates the resistive touch screen found on the PRS-600. I can only assume that the screen quality of the PRS-650 will meet or exceed that of the PRS-505. However, I would wait until some models are out in the wild to see how the battery life pans out. The beauty of e-ink displays is that they do not require constant power to run, just power to change the display. In the PRS-650, the same rules apply to the screen, but now the touch infrared sensors will require constant power. This would result in shorter battery life but I'm not sure if Sony beefed up the battery to compensate.  Also... Amazon's library of ebooks is still larger. With the PRS-505, I found it frustrating to search site after site after site to try and find the book I was looking for in eBook format. I almost always found it at Amazon.com (I never actually tried converting from the Amazon format to something the Sony could read, I've read you can).  The Sony solution is altogether more expensive than Amazon's. I would say the PRS-650 is as close as it gets to comparing apples to apples and Sony's solution is expected to be $229 (from what I've read) and their library is more expensive... compared to Amazon's $139 entrance fee and in most cases eBooks from Amazon are cheaper.  PDF and ePub You hit the nail on the head here... if you are partial to PDF and ePub formats then the K3 may not be the device for you. For PDF, the K3 has added the ability to adjust the contrast of the PDF document which is nice and you can search and annotate PDF's as well. Since the PRS-505 had no keyboard/touch screen the search and annotations couldn't be done. The PRS-650 will (more than likely) have this feature. What the K3 lacks in terms of PDF support is PDF reflow and PDF links (i.e. Table of Contents, etc.). For ePub, well, K3 doesn't support ePub. Calibre (software - free) may be able to help you there, it was and still is my best friend when I'm trying to convert content from one eBook format to another. I use it frequently to convert word documents and pdf's to something the K3 can understand if I don't want to go through the Kindle email conversion. (I will say though, the Kindle email conversion can be handy because if I have a friend or family member setup on my approved email list, when they say they want me to read something I just tell them to email it to my @free.kindle.com address and it just shows up on my device... it's kind of handy. I could see it being helpful in an office type setting. I think it's about as close as we'll get to dragging images from one screen to another like they do in the movie Avatar).  So, looking at how you use your PRS-505 currently, I would say you might want to wait for the PRS-650 because of the ePub and PDF limitations of the K3. Personally, I'm happy with my choice of the K3 and don't think I would change my mind and go to a PRS-650 just because of the higher cost. At this point in time the K3 meets my needs as I really don't do that much work in PDF and, if necessary, I convert the PDF's.  But, that's just my $0.02. At the end of the day you have to go with the device that is right for you.  Good luck in your decision!

Author: J. Doherty

I think $99 will likely be a magical price for a lot of people. $139 isn't far off, but some will likely wait for further decreases. Author: J. Doherty
Comment: Debbie,  Thanks for your comments!  Honestly, the fingerprints were the least of the PRS-600's issues. It was the resistive display which had a lot of glare which required constant readjustment of your reading position to eliminate. Then, once you readjust, you still have a screen that lacks contrast (background was darker and text was lighter... the opposite of the way you want things to progress with an eReader!). I used my PRS-600 on a plane once and found myself putting it down 45 mins into my three hour flight... I gave up (That's when it was returned.). I went back to my PRS-505 until my K3 arrived. Honestly, if you are looking to read eBooks from Amazon (or another source with a compatible format) this is the bees knees. I think eReaders touch an interesting part of the market, early adopters of technology who like to read. The only problem with the "early adopters of technology" part is that we all want the devices to do things they just aren't capable of yet (or are capable of and the individual manufacturers have made individual decisions to include or exclude certain features in favor of a different feature). In my humble opinion both Sony and Kindle have come very close to developing the ideal device, neither is perfect for everyone, but at least they offer different feature-sets which caters to different individuals.

Author: Roger Knights
Comment: Amazon seems to stubbornly refuse to make one simple fix which would make this useful to students and scholars--and that is including the print version page numbers in Kindle editions.  I agree 200%. I made several emphatic comments about this flaw as soon as the K-1 came out. Probably some non-academic Amazon Pooh-Bah is dogmatically pooh-poohing the issue, from his limited perspective.

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: I guess we each judge it against our own expectations. I agree with your point about the locations being a completely inadequate substitute for absolute page numbers. However, I view the kindle, especially the 6 inch one, as a device for pleasure reading, not work reading (I am a college professor, too).  The DX with it's 10 inch screen isn't even that great for reading journal articles in pdf format, or textbooks. (i had a DX for a while.)  But for nonwork reading, and newspapers and magazines, I consider the kindle a 5-star device. I don't fault it for not replacing textbooks and other schoolbooks.

Author: Roger Knights
Comment: And who decides which edition's page numbers the Kindle edition uses?  The Kindle would use the page numbers of the version supplied by the publisher, and that would presumably be the most recent hardcover edition. I assume this is how ePub pagination is handled, so this is not really an agonizing dilemma. (It would be possible to use pagination from more than one edition, distinguishing them with italics, etc., were such information ever wanted.)  If the different pagination that sometimes occurs (and it usually doesn't) between different editions (and multiple editions are unusual) were a real "showstopper" it would already have made the current hard-copy page citation practice so confusing that it would be more trouble than it's worth -- which is the reverse of the case. It's very useful, and its problems are mere molehills.  For instance, mass market paperbacks are always going to be considerably "off" from the pagination of the original editions, but that hasn't been a problem in scholarly citations, which rarely refer to such works (or to book club editions).  "Or, if it is a "simple fix," it's not going to fix it for everyone."  Advocates of Kindle pagination haven't made a claim that it would. It's enough that it would fix it for most people, especially for scholars and others engaged in serious writing. (It would also be needed by college students writing papers, which is a market Amazon hopes to penetrate.) Saying, in effect, that a practice is no good for anyone if it isn't perfect for all isn't a good argument, especially when the imperfect system is already doing a satisfactory job in the hard-copy world. There's no need to turn the best into the enemy of the good.

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: I, too, agree that the page numbering issue could be fixed, or at least improved, at very low cost to Amazon (and probably in a software update), and that doing so would increase the utility of the Kindle to a group of potential buyers.    This is a very interesting discussion, and it is useful in the sense that it is connecting people with similar views. But I doubt the Kindle engineering team is monitoring this discussion, and therefore the main use of the discussion seems to be to allow people to vent about an issue they find annoying.    If you want to make a difference rather than just vent, you need to make sure the right people hear your arguments.  One of you, perhaps Professor Twain, should take the initiative to summarize the excellent points you all have contributed here in an email, and find out where to send this email to have maximum impact.   That said, I would not raise my hopes too much.  I read a few months ago in the New York Times that students and grad students who had Kindle DXs for a semester did not rate them highly for academic purposes, just for leisure reading.  It may be that Amazon has concluded that its product (at least in its current form) is not a good fit for academic uses, and so they are not willing to devote resources to winning over this market.    Or maybe they are.  In any case, they certainly won't address your very legitimate concerns over the page numbering issue if they don't know about these concerns.

Author: MollipZ
Comment: My point is WHY limit this device to reading romance novels and mysteries?  If the only fiction literature you read for pleasure is romance and mystery, you should consider branching out a bit.  I agree that the page number option should be there, and hopefully it will be incorporated at some point. I actually prefer the percentage system now, but I don't use the Kindle for academic/legal work. I don't think they anticipated the popularity of this format, and my guess is that the page number issue will be addressed eventually.

Author: Chykcha

Author: Terry Ligon
Comment: Midol & tampons? Ha!  Nah, I just find 3 Kindles in a short space of time with three *different* problems very "against-the-odds". Maybe, but highly unlikely. Others here finding that?  Yes, there are numbers having wifi/net use issues and a BIOS update is due. But these three problems aren't all related or related to that.  At the end of the day ... I don't really care. I'm just astonished at the odds and find it ... odd, unless he's doing something (perhaps unknowingly) that is putting a strain on each of his Kindles (like one reviewer who put on 5,000 small, free books on his Kindle 3 and the K3 freaked out trying to index it all and it slowed to a snails pace and began acting odd and rebooting.  But he pushed it just to see its limits. I wonder if this reviewer is doing something to get this beyond-the-odds different problems on three different Kindles.  Perhaps not, and he's just wildly unlucky.

But the Nook was a gift so, I'm fine with it.  I'll buy a Kindle someday but I'll probably (maybe?) wait until a color screen is available.  That's years away.  Amazon has great customer service; I've had to call upon them many times and always am left happy and satisfied.  Annev's experience is testimony to that as well.  B&N's Customer Service sucks, frankly.  I've only had to deal with them once, so maybe that's an unfair statement, but that one time was bad and worthless. Author: S. Stanley
Comment: [i'm posting this comment on a few of the reviews where people had the same problems i had with 5 of these K3 models in case it helps others.]  Any chance you are using one of those cases/covers they sell?  If not, don't bother reading further.  But, if you are . . .  On the 5th model, I finally reached a tech support person who didn't ask about the Kindle but about the case I was using. I thought that was pretty strange. But, it turns out that some of them are defective, and since they have the new units that have the lights that run off the battery of the Kindle, those metal connectors actually do more than just connect the Kindle to the cover (whether or not you have the lighted model). Since they are used to power the light on that type of case with the built in light, those leads are connected to the electronic operation of the K3 models. My problem went completely away when I stopped using that same case I had used on all 5 units that had the problems freezing and restarting. (If that is your problem, note that they will send you a new case/cover.) I was pretty amazed that this solved the problem. Further, I did not have the type of case with the light. Nevertheless, since those connector points potentially involve current, if you use standard Kindle case, the occasional defective case is either shorting or throwing some variable load across those leads and causing the freezing and restarting. I have not had a single problem (was happening every 10 minutes before) since I quit using that one case. Incredible.

Author: Louise M. Broadaway
Comment: Thank you for posting these comments. I want to buy a kindle for a special little girl for Chrismas but I will now wait to see what action Amazon takes to correct these problems BEFORE I buy one. Thank you all! Louise

Author: Ron Cronovich
Comment: I have great empathy for this reviewer's frustration with the frequent reboots.  However, this experience is NOT TYPICAL.  My wife and I each bought a Kindle 3 and have used them heavily since they arrived on August 27, with only one reboot on hers, none on mine.  Before you heed this reviewer's advice and postpone your purchase, scan a few of the 700 reviews here.  The vast majority of Kindle 3 buyers are very, very happy.  Most of the negative reviews are from people who are frustrated with the shipping delays and haven't even received their Kindle yet.    Regarding the case:  If you think it's a ripoff, don't buy it.   There are cheaper cases available, and more will be coming out in time for the Christmas shopping season.  Look at how many cases are available for Kindle 2--probably even more will be available for K3 because K3 will be a bigger seller than K2 (K3 is cheaper and better).  So you won't have to wait long for more inexpensive case options.     Or, you might still consider splurging and buying yourself a nice case.  After all, the Kindle's price has fallen from $259 at the beginning of this year to $139 for the new wi-fi model; the $120 difference is enough to buy a nice case and have plenty left over.

Author: monakh
Comment: Much as I would hate to admit it, Ron is correct--for the most part.  We are a vocal--though sizeable--minority but it WOULD be unfair to ignore us.  However, if there is a product defect and it is known to affect just a few production units, what do you do?    As of 7pm Eastern on 9/12/2010, here's the breakdown:   160 Reviews with 3 stars or less: 545 Reviews with 4 and 5 stars:  Do you ignore the 108 1 and 2 star reviews out of the above-mentioned 160?  For that matter, do you ignore the total (almost) one-third reviews that are less than favorable?  I do realize, though, as Ron mentioned, that many reviewers are just complaining about not having received their Kindle.  These reviews, in my opinion, should be removed so we can get an accurate picture.  Regardless, you cannot ignore the fact that there is a real problem that is affecting some Kindle shipments adversely.  I will leave it to the consumer to make an informed decision but one thing is for sure, you ARE at risk of receiving a device which has an issue.  Whether you are brave enough to shoulder that risk is a decision that is yours to make.  I want people to make informed decisions and as far as I know, Amazon still hasn't fixed the issue.  There is NOTHING wrong with postponing a purchase.  If anything it pressures Amazon to fix the outstanding issue that much sooner.  In Amazon's defence, they have very good customer service.  Someone called me after reading my comments and tried to fix my issue but wasn't incredibly helpful.  I asked them to push the new firmware to my device, which purportedly fixes the issue, and they said 'sorry, we can't promise that'.  So much for that.  I told them, I don't mind being a beta tester for the firmware fix that they are testing, after all, my device is pretty much unusable to begin with so how much worse can it get? Anyway, that was ten days ago, and still no firmware update has been received on my K3.  As for the case options, well yeah, like I said, we should vote with our wallets and buy the cases we want at a price which makes sense.  The fact that the Kindle is cheaper and leaves you 'plenty to work with' because K2 was 'X' amount is an argument that holds very little value.  It's Moore's Law in technology and economies of scale at work.  Things get better, and cheaper and just because they do, doesn't mean we say, 'Oh see how much more it was yesterday?  Let's use the money to buy a nicer case'.  That's a flawed argument for an opportunity cost that is non-existent.    Anyway, that's my take on it.  To each his own!  Edit:  Added the stats.

Read on, if you happen to be using one of their Kindle brand covers/cases.  If not, what solved problem for me won't be working for you.  (I went through 5 of these units with the same problems you identify but problem turned out to be the case, not the Kindle.) But, it turns out that some of them are defective, and since they have the new units that have the lights that run off the battery of the Kindle, those metal connectors actually do more than just connect the Kindle to the cover (whether or not you have the lighted model).  Since they are used to power the light on that type of case with the built in light, those leads are connected to the electronic operation of the K3 models.  My problem went completely away when I stopped using that same case I had used on all 5 units that had the problems freezing and restarting.  (If that is your problem, note that they will send you a new case/cover.)  I was pretty amazed that this solved the problem.  Further, I did not have the type of case with the light.  Nevertheless, since those connector points potentially involve current, if you use standard Kindle case, the occasional defective case is either shorting or throwing some variable load across those leads and causing the freezing and restarting.  I have not had a single problem (was happening every 10 minutes before) since I quit using that one case.  Incredible.

Author: Terry Ligon
Comment: Concerning your random freezes on sleeping, do you have an Amazon non-lighted Kindle Leather cover you are using with each of those Kindles? If so, believe it or not, your problem may be a defective non-lighted leather cover, not the Kindles themselves.  To quote a recent owner: "Any chance you are using one of their leather cases with the metal connectors that hook the K3 to the case? I went through 4 units with this problem until, on the fifth, I finally reached a tech support person who asked if I used a Kindle cover/case and which kind. Turns out that some of them are defective, and since they have the new units that have the lights that run off the battery of the Kindle, those metal connectors actually do more than just connect the Kindle to the cover (whether or not you have the lighted model). My problem went completely away when I stopped using that case (after being on the 5th unit doing the freezing and restarting). (If that is your problem, note that they will send you a new case/cover.) I was pretty amazed that this solved the problem, but I could not believe that I could really get 5 defective ones in a row, so the possibility raised by the smart tech person immediately made sense to me as a possibility."  Here's the link to his full story: http://www.amazon.com/gp/cdp/member-reviews/A1A306IAZ3TM1/ref=cm_rna_own_review_more?ie=UTF8&sort_by=MostRecentReview#R2096VZNTZ3C9G  If you *do* own a Kindle leather cover (lighted or not. His wasn't lighted), remove it, reboot the Kindle (slide on/off switch to right & hold it there for 30 sec) and see if the self-rebooting continues. Let us know what happens!  If the same owner has a *series* of Kindles having the same symptoms/problems (while most others aren't), that would indicated that the Kindles' problem is OUTSIDE of the Kindle itself.

You mention that you use the standard kindle cover.  Is this the cover with the metal hook on the bottom and the clasp or slide at the top--the cover sold by/offered as Amazon's own cover?  If so, perhaps you've nailed my problem since that's the cover I use which I purchased with my first 3rd gen kindle.  I appreciate your post!

Author: Terry Ligon
Comment: Yes. That's is the cover he describes. The Amazon Kindle leather cover (his was the non-lighted version). Kindle Leather Cover, Steel Blue (Fits 6" Display, Latest Generation Kindle) I'm not S. Stanley but I use the lighted leather cover with no problems. Author: soraya
Comment: I purchase my cover directly from Amazon, am up to my 3rd kindle. Just gonna keep having the same problem with these use junk. I love my kindle, the little time it work. What a shame this has to happen. Big problem with software.

Author: Terry Ligon
Comment: Soraya,  Are you using that Kindle in one of those Amazon non-lighted leather covers with the metal hinges? Many have been found to be defective (Amazon doesn't sell them any more) and were causing problems such as freezing, rebooting and not coming on. When folks removed their Kindle from the defective cover & rebooted, the problems stopped.  If you have that cover, remove the Kindle from it, charge the Kindle (without the cover) and then unplug the Kindle. Then reboot it (slide the on/off switch to the right and HOLD it there for a full 30 seconds. Then release the switch and wait.)  See here: http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2374502,00.asp  Amazon has been crediting people with a defective non-lighted leather cover causing the problems you describe and they have been offering a FREE upgrade to the lighted leather cover ($60 value).  As for "refurbished", the replacement Kindles aren't that exactly. Amazon has replaced 1,000's of Kindles that have turned out to not be defective (but was the non-lighted cover). It may be one of those.  A refurbished device may have scratches or use on the body and will usually come with a 3-mo or shorter warranty.  These replacement Kindles (we had two of them) look brand new (NO wear on the keys or body) and come with the full 1-yr warranty. So they are not "refurbished" in the normal sense at all.

Author: soraya
Comment: I was informed by customer service that the replacement are refurbished.

Author: Terry Ligon
Comment: I realize that, but I wanted to make the distinction. When you buy a Kindle 2 refurbished, for example, it is a 3-mo warranty and the Kindle may look a little used, plus a refurbished sticker is palced on the body of the Kindle.  But our replacement Kindles (switched TWICE only because my wife wanted another color) had a refurbished sticker on the box, but nothing saying that on the Kindles. The Kindles both looked brand new and both came with the full one-year warranty.  So I think people are making a bigger deal out of it than necessary. In "refurbished" terms they are not equivalent, IMO.  I think I'd wait till the replacement arrived & I could inspect it before I worried about the matter. And I'd only worry if it didn't look new or there was a refurbished sticker on it or the warranty was reduced.

Author: Drew Loker

Author: Scott Showalter
Comment: Barney and Quan: You're right. Apple has not officially announced the iPod having 512MB of memory, but there was a recent conversation with an Apple Support personal who confirmed it. Plus, several gadget blogs have had inside sources echo similarly. Wikipedia also reports the 512MB spec, though its source is yet to be confirmed. I suspect the source will end up being iFixit, once they do their teardown and confirm it.   Here's that conversation, by the way: http://bit.ly/ipod4ram  The same employee also outed the vibrator, later confirmed by an FCC teardown. If that's not enough to confirm 512MB ram, consider this: the iPhone 3GS and iPod touch 3rd gen (32GB & 64GB models) shared the same processor: the Arm Cortex A8. Consequently, they also shared the same amount of ram: 256MB. Frankly, it'd be asinine to put an A4 processor in the new iPod touch and keep the memory at a dismal 256MB. That's just laughable. Go ahead... laugh already. :D  Update: The laughing has turned into weeping. iFixit has done their teardown and found the device to be sporting only the same 256MB of ram as the 3g touch. Dang! Apple, you have officially been declared asinine! My review has been updated to reflect this newfound disappointment. Meanwhile, the demo model I toyed with still ran pretty smoothly, considering these circumstances.

Author: Scott Showalter
Comment: Ivan: I wouldn't say you can't do AS MUCH multitasking with 256MB of memory as you can with 512MB. The more accurate statement would be: you can't do multitasking AS WELL with 256MB of memory as opposed to 512MB, and only if you're running tons of multitaskable apps in the background (which isn't all that likely).   In iOS 4, memory works like this:  When you hit the home button, apps developed with iOS 3 or older, or set to exit on suspension with iOS 4's SDK are killed right away, and all memory is immediately released for use by other apps. Apps developed with the iOS 4 SDK and set NOT to exit on suspension will remain in memory and run their specified background processes (if any). If and when those processes complete, or if no background processes are specified, the app is then suspended in memory (meaning it can relaunch quickly at the exact state it was in when it was suspended).  Meanwhile, the active app can use use however much memory is available so they can run as efficiently as possible. This means when they hit their limit of free memory and need more (really only possible if tons of apps are backgrounded), one of the apps suspended in memory gets killed. Apple hasn't published any details about how the device determines which app to kill, but I'm thinking it loads a virtual revolver with a single bullet and plays Russian roulette with all the suspended apps until one gets blown to oblivion (and as such, it no longer exists in memory). Just a theory though. ;)  In any case, I figure that a majority of users will never see issues with the 256MB limit. But the thought of 512MB is still nice, especially for more serious multitaskers!

Author: Scott Showalter
Comment: Hey Renie, to hook connect to the internet (and use Skype, among other apps that require the internet) you'll need to have a wireless router (plenty here on Amazon if you don't already have one) and broadband internet, meaning your internet service is provided by the cable company or other high-speed internet service provider (as dialup won't work).   If you have more than one computer connected to the internet at home, especially a laptop, chances are you already have a wireless router. You might need a bit of help setting it up and securing it if you don't already have one. The kids are often great at helping you out with that, so enlist them if you need to!  Thanks again for the great feedback from everyone on this review. It keeps me motivated to write more. :)  Nicole: Thanks for sticking up for me!

Author: Joseph Hindy
Comment: I clicked "yes" on the review being helpful. You're very educated on the subject and I very much appreciate knowing all the goods and bads about the new iTouch (I'm buying a 32GB in a few days).  However, I do not believe your comparison of it to Android is as unbiased as your review of the device itself. Like you, I carry an Android and an iTouch (MyTouch 3g Slide for my Android, 2nd gen on the iPod...as I wanted to wait for this one before upgrading) and I'm on my Android far more than my iTouch. That being said, I think the iOS and Android debate is strictly a matter of opinion. Android lacks the sheer number of apps as the Apple app store and the process is a little more complicated on Android, the Flash support is buggy (but it's getting better) and "i" products are dead simple to use for the mainstream user (i.e. my idiot gf can work an iPhone 4g, but my Android runs circles around her). However, the flash does work, even if buggy, and I can't play farmville on an "i"anything. Android allows the use of SD cards so you can upgrade without having to re-sync all your songs, pics, etc and with Apps2SD now being used on Android 2.2 (where you can install and store apps on the SD card), re-downloading all the apps on an upgraded phone is far less time consuming. Apple is more stable, Android has more options...no hardware keyboard on anything with iOS, half of Android has them...Apple can't tether it's internet connetion to other devices while Androids with 2.1 can (easy tether...free in the app store. It allows free internet tethering on one device, so you don't have to pay Sprint extra money to do it). iOS won't let you share your music with others while you can copy music files right off an Android's SD card and give them to anyone, but Android's music player blows (nearly everyone has a music app who has an Android). iOS has a uniform release date for all "i"products...Android is all over the place (but I believe they're fixing that, according to many, many rumors).  I say this with all the respect in the world, as you are smarter than most Apple fans, but you cannot compare Android to iOS and come up with a definite winner. It all depends on what you want out of a mobile OS...and since both of us obviously like the features of both, we both own devices that feature both. There's just somethings iOS can't do and there's just some things Android won't do.

Author: Scott Showalter
Comment: Hey Joseph. You have a point, and I agree with you--everyone is different. I tend to speak mostly from a software standpoint in my review. The hardware is so different between devices that you can't really use that as a basis for comparison between the two. Nevertheless, I figure even a little bit of comparison may still prove helpful to some.  From a hardware standpoint though, while the SD card support in Android is useful in some respects, I would personally rather have the storage built in, probably because decently sized cards are outrageously priced or non existent (32GB and 64GB respectively). Physical keyboards are nice too, but after two years of using the virtual keyboard on the touch, I'm kinda used to it now. WiFi tethering is a definite plus though.   Of course, you're absolutely right. The two are very different. So that's why I kept my comparisons to just those where I felt one OS could learn something from the other, and vice-versa.

Author: Scott Showalter
Comment: Hey Regina. Sorry if the memory info confused you. Memory has no effect on how much media you can store on the device. It only determines how smoothly an app runs, or how many apps can run simultaneously.   What you're thinking of is storage space, and that's what the 8/32/64 GB is all about (with each of the  the available models, respectively). I simply recommend going with the 32 GB model. It gives you the best space-to-cost ratio and will be plenty enough space to hold your husband's videos, or even full length movies if he wanted.  Hope that helps!

Author: Scott Showalter
Comment: Oops, looks like I forget to mention that one Dorothy.   No, you don't need a screen protector. The iPod touch's screen is made out of glass. Thus, it will not scratch (easily). You could even take a razor blade to it and it probably wouldn't scratch. Even the one I had for two years never had a scratch on the screen. The only scratches were on the chrome (stainless steel) back, which scratches easily, so just make sure you get that silicone skin right away, to protect the back!   Also, I can only imagine that having a screen protector would only hinder the accuracy and smoothness of the touch experience. Screen protectors often feel sticker than the glass feels, so it probably wouldn't be as easy to drag your finger across the screen, use swipe gestures, etc.  Hope that helps. (And helps save you a little change, too!)

Author: Scott Showalter
Comment: Hey Priscilla. I guess the major factor here would be the size of your existing music library, and whether you want to transfer the whole thing, or just part of it, to your iPod. The photos aren't going to take up much space at all.   If you aren't going to store any movies on the iPod, and your music collection is less than 32 GB, you may do well with the 32 GB model. If it's larger than 32 GB, you may want to go ahead and get yourself the 64 GB model.  Hope that helps a bit.

Author: R. Regovich
Comment: Hi Scott, so I've been on before, and I like your review, but,....bottom line, what is the battery life like on the 32GB?

Author: Scott Showalter
Comment: Only had it a couple days now, but I haven't seen any issues with battery drain while in standby. Others are reporting that there's a bug affecting iPods connected to wireless-g routers. I use wireless-n not wireless-g, which may be why I've had no issues so far. So it seems to be an issue that you can avoid (by using airplane mode while not in use, getting a wireless-n router, or changing your router to only broadcast in wireless-b... you can also close out your running apps, especially Skype which appears to just eat battery like there's no tomorrow), while waiting for an update from Apple to fix it. The bug also affects the iPhone, apparently. It's not just limited to the iPod touch.  Frankly though, I wouldn't be caught without wireless-n... it's so much faster, and I get a much stronger signal from the other side of the house than I used to be able to get.   As far as battery life goes though, I've been getting a good 6-8 hours of solid use (depending on what I'm doing, and how bright I have the screen set to) with no noticeable drain in battery while in standby. Noticeably more usage than my second gen touch, that's for sure.

My unit gets hot from watching videos. How much heat can the unit stand before it degrades performance? Does adding the typical silicone/rubber case make a difference? I  assume it shuts down rather than self-destructs. [Edit 12-12-10 - I haven't had any overheating from videos any more. The iOS upgrade helped? Isolated problem in one unit (I have 2 now).]  Battery life is terrible under iOS 4.1. I don't mean in actual operation, but in "standby" mode. My last gen under the last operating system would last a long time on standby. Neither the new nor the old one last as long under iOS 4.1. I thought this was just a "bug" of iOS 4.1 on the last gen, but the new gen isn't any better.  Reading a book under the Kindle app is surprisingly battery intensive, as much so, I think, as watching a video. Maybe anything that requires the screen to be on has the same issue (audio, you can turn off the screen). I run my screen at about 60% brightness level.

Author: Scott Showalter
Comment: To force-close an app, double-press the home button to bring up the multitasking bar. Then locate icon of the app you want to force closed, such as Skype. You may have to scroll the multitasking bar to find it. When you see it, long-press the icon (touch and hold) until the icons start to jiggle and you see the red (-) icon in the corner. Just hit that red (-) icon to force-close the app.  Hope that helps :)

Author: MWebb
Comment: There is a VERY good manual tucked away in the "bookmarks" section of the Safari web browser. Just tap to open Bookmarks then scroll down and load the manual. Usually I skip the "simple" sections but don't do that in this case! You may know how to operate Windows but iOS on the iPod has it's own conventions! For example, for the past year I have been using "pinch to zoom" to widen the text on the NY Times in Safari so it is readable. Last night, though, with nothing else to do I was reading the manual and discovered that if you tap twice on an article you are trying to see, it automatically resizes to a nicely legible single column of text! Slick! Double tap again, and you get the whole page!  My daughter put a clear plastic "sheet" on the face of her iPod. It was invisible and barely noticeable, and did not affect performance. Held on by "static cling" really quite tightly, hard to peel off later. BUT I think Apple uses a special hard glass that doesn't scratch easily. My other daughter's iPod got really scratched on the back, but NO scratches on the glass. I use a microfiber drawstring eyeglass slip case (check them out at REI for example) to store my own iPod in; I use the Griffin FlexGrip Action case which has slight "bumps" at either end to make it easier to hold - the bumps shelter the camera lenses and help keep them clean. Unfortunately Amazon's assortment of cases isn't as deep as I expected, and I had to get my case at Best Buy.

Author: Scott Showalter
Comment: BetsyR: Editing videos without the iMovie app is really only limited to trimming your clips. It's a bit tricky though. The trick is to find the visual time line at the top, when the video is playing, and then drag one side or the other to trim as desired. You can then save as a new clip, or save over the top of the existing clip.  For iMovie, you can watch this YouTube video for details on how that works: youtube.com/watch?v=CotWYEsNOII  Duly noted, about the Air review. I'll be sure to work something in for ya.

Author: E. Stoddard
Comment: Well, there are two types of people who use technology such as this:  1) Those who buy products for what they can get now, and 2) Those who buy products for what they will be able to get in the future.  I'm the latter type person.  I know much of Netflix's content is still SD but I do see that more of their content, as time passes, is binging offered in HD.  Too, it might be a while before 1080p HD is offered (720p HD is probably what they offer now, as opposed to 480i/p SD), but I have a 1080p HDTV, so why not a Ruko player that has that capability, too?  Not all TV channels broadcast in HD, but a lot do, therefore I have an HDTV.  Would not the same logic apply to the Roku XD or XDS when one has an HDTV?  Anyone with a regular TV would do best to just buy the Roku HD box, since it won't matter much if the content is SD or 720p.  Of course, folks with a 720p HDTV, which there are a lot of them out there (my daughter for example), could use either of the three, as they all do wireless connections, but only the XD and XDS come with remotes and N wireless capabilites for a stronger wireless connection.  Of course, for some price will be the primarily issue.  Either of the three should serve a customer well.  The Roku HD might be better used hard wired with an eithernet cable to one's router, however, for the best possible uninterrupted streaming of content.

That's not to say the quality is terrible or anything, and it's not to say that media streamers aren't of value: I watch Netflix streaming almost daily, and certainly more frequently than I watch Blu Rays!

Author: E. Stoddard

HD technology is starting to take off, so the demand for the content will be there.    Too, Blu Ray players are beginning to sell much more now than every before.  Once customers learn they can play all their old DVDs on a Blu Ray player, then that is what they will upgrade to.
