Author: P. Colin McGraw
Comment: @E. Stoddard - I'm not sure you understand what I'm saying.   Resolution is just one piece of the picture quality puzzle. A 1080p Netflix image streamed at even 7Mbps will contain literally 5x less information than than some of the higher bitrate Blu-ray

Author: E. Stoddard
Comment: P. Colin McGraw says:  "Resolution is just one piece of the picture quality puzzle. A 1080p Netflix image streamed at even 7Mbps will contain literally 5x less information than than some of the higher bitrate Blu-ray movies. In reality, I believe Netflix streams max out at around 4Mbps, so you're looking at about 9x less information. If you're the kind of person who cares about picture quality, the difference is absolutely noticeable.  See here to learn more about bitrates and why it matters. It's in the context of 720p iTunes downloads, but it still applies to 1080p Roku streams (just to a lesser degree): http://www.zdnet.com/blog/ou/why-hd-movie-downloads-are-a-big-lie/511?tag=mantle_skin;content  Also, I have no problem blaming Apple (and the movie industry) for annoying DRM, but it doesn't change the fact that Roku can't stream iTunes video."  *****************************************<wbr>*************************  I agree with you about Blu-ray content quality, but it is rather a moot point, since I know I am not going to buy every Blu-ray disc out there for the content I want to watch.  I'm going to use Roku and Netflix, Amazon VOD and Hulu Plus to provide me content, much of which is in HD quality, just not Blu-ray HD quality.  That is fine with me.  What ever Netflix and others offer in quality is what I will get.  I understand this and the differences between a paid for Blu-ray disc for $20 or $30 per disc and Netflix content for about $9 a month.  The math is not hard to understand.  My intent has never been to discuss absolute quality of content, no matter the cost.    Secondly, if Apple did not require some sort of licensing fee Roku would probably have it available to customers, if, and I say if, there was a high demand for it from customers.  Apple could play with other but they do not do that part well.

Author: P. Colin McGraw
Comment: I think I'm with you here. Roku (and other streamers) are good value and you can't beat the convenience, but there's a tradeoff in quality, though arguably not enough to matter for what you get.

It matches my TV which is 720.   7-10 Mbps to see the 720 at this point and 1080p will require more....hence that is a problem.  Why would time warner or other cable tv Co.s  want to give more....they sell movies on demand. The 1080p Roku will work great but you will only see 720 on Netflix and  Amazon.

That might change in the future, as all things do.    Comcast, as you said, has several stations that broadcast their HD content in 1080i.  That is not to say that Comcast, itself, could not handle 1080p content over it's cable.  1080i is probably easier, cheaper and uses less bandwidth than full 1080p, I would guess.  Don't know, but broadcasters have stayed with 1080i, which is very high definition and almost indistinguishable from 1080p.

It's especially fast on acquiring satellites, recalculating routes, and the text-to-speech is very good.  Inputting data is not especially fast, but what do you expect for the money? Scrolling through Favorites, though, takes a bit of time if your list is long, but you can start at the beginning or end at the get-go and go up or down from there.  Mio Moov 200 is a very good navigator.  I keep mine charging in the car.  If I leave it on without charging, the battery still works and has not 'died' on me after nine months.  CR should have tested the Mio Moov.  I was steered to this Garmin due to their report on the 265T, and reviews here.  Amazon took my order, and it's a good price presently.  I look forward to receiving this Garmin 265TW.

Author: dsrussell
Comment: Number of POIs:  While Garmin boasts 6 million POIs, that's a fraction of what is really out there (only about 15 - 20 percent).  That it doesn't show several business is par for the course on most GPS units, and coverage and accuracy will vary from city to city.  POI management:  I also think Garmin needs to update the way these are handled.  If you do not set some type of limit (via the "near" button at the bottom of the screen when accessing POIs, or pin it down by subcategories), the search will indeed take a long time.  Garmin shows the closest first, then goes out in a radial spiral pattern as it continues to add more and more points of interest.  Naming errors, map errors, etc., should be brought to NAVTEQ's attention (the map maker Garmin uses).  Map update policy:  Believe it or not, their current policy is a vast improvement over just one year ago (when there was 0 days of grace), and was one of my pet peeves.  However, Garmin may be going much further.  Hopefully some time early this year (January?) Garmin may implement quarterly updates for the lifetime of your unit for a one-time charge (est. around $120).

Author: B. Berman
Comment: I just got mine yesterday and have written a separate review that will hopefully be approved and posted.  POI NAME SEARCH database definitely inferior to my Mio Moov 200's (which I purchased in 9/08 and have not updated) at a fraction of the cost.  I updated Garmin with latest yesterday, and DISAPPOINTED with the POI NAME SEARCH database as common destinations like well-known stores such as Smart & Final, Bed Bath & Beyond etc. sent me to timbuktu.    In all other respects, unit seems very nice, and I will likely keep it.  I can't get it to instruct me to make a U-turn though when I've purposely missed my turn, whereas the Moov so instructs, in spite of the fact that I disabled the U-turn avoidance box.  I've given the unit 3 stars and feel that it has been overrated by a major consumer reporting organization.  But my view has changed to the better-see my full review here.  I'd give the unit 4 stars.

Prices may vary from day to day, but the day I checked (last week) Garmin was charging $120 for lifetime maps.  However, Amazon.com was selling the same garmin lifetime maps for $85.

Author: Solver

This setting might save you some headaches when in unfamiliar terrain. You'll see what i mean if you experiment with these two settings.

Author: MiBassman
Comment: Garmin's map update policy is a joke.  They "allow" you one update within 60 days after you purchase a device.  Actually, you pay for this update in the price of the unit.  Unless you purchase your GPS shortly after they update their maps, you have to download the updates from their website.  The files are about 5 gig and download very slowly.  This is not an option for anyone with anything but the fastest internet connection.  Even then, there are reports that the Garmin server is very slow and errors abound.  Garmin's response to my concerns-sorry about that, but, too bad. This company has the potential of capturing and maintaining the majority of the market.  They have pretty good products.  Their attitude toward their customers makes the market ripe for a company with good customer service to eliminate Garmin as a serious contender.

Author: Adam
Comment: the route it gives me to work is rather strange. It routes me off of the freeway onto an expressway that has several lights. I tried it once, and sure enough it took longer than predicted, even with light traffic.   Why would you use a GPS to get to work?  I'd hope you know the way on your.  GPS is more of an occasional use item for when you don't know where you're going.  It's never going to give you as good of a route as a HUMAN who knows the area and makes the same commute daily.

Author: HHB
Comment: Dude, thanks for your in depth updates!!!!  Big help!

Author: Julie Ann Allender
Comment: I appreciated the posts. I had a TomTom One for 2 years and loved it. It gave me fast accurate directions. The unit had problems finding satelites so I figured I would try the Garmin. I hate the maps. The system is better than the TomTom, but the maps are horrible. I end up on one way streets the wrong way, on gravel roads when 2-4 lane highways are available, sending me a mile in the wrong direction and on and on. I have been afraid to give up my TomTom even though it is slow to find satelites. I run both at the same time and when the Garmin shows a similar route to the TomTom I use it, but that is rare. It doesn't do well in Pennsylvania and doesn't like expressways. It prefers to direct me directly into city traffic no matter if I set fastest or shortest.   I had contacted Garmin when I first got it and they did determine that their was something wrong with the software and I had to re-install it. The hope was then it would be give me better directions. That never happened. It is only a few months old and I am looking to buy a new one, but am afraid to throw away money a third time.

Author: Other
Comment: Well, should I buy it or not? This one looks promising to me.

Author: Julie Ann Allender
Comment: I am now on my 4th or 5th Garmin in the first year. Their tech support is horrific. The same problems keep happening with "the blue lines" which they finally figured out after telling me there was something wrong with my units 3 times. It is a setting for Show Mapping. The unit takes forever to reroute if I decide to avoid one of their directions which are OFTEN wrong. I have been sent onto dirt gravel roads, one way roads the wrong way, etc. creating a nightmare at times.  I had a TomTomOne before this unit. The Garmin has better features, but I never worried about getting accurate, fast & direct directions with the TomTom. The TomTom had satelite issues which took 4-5 minutes to start up. I usually keep the TomTom running to make sure I don't get lost with the Garmin 265W.  I strongly suggest NOT buying the Nuvi 265W unless you want to end up in Timbucktoo. Their new update was supposed to correct some of the issues. IT DID NOT!

Author: Michael J. Shears
Comment: Adam:     Most people test their GPS to see what it will do when you know where you're going. Why? Because then you can evaluate the device: You can see whether shortest distance or shortest time works better. Whether strange directions will add too much time to your commute or get you lost before it conks out.  If it gives you strange directions when you know where your going chances are it will do the same when you don't know where you're going. If it gives you strange directions, you may want to return it for something better. Adam, when you buy a car, why do you test drive it?

Author: John David Schatz
Comment: When you buy a refurbished unit, you save lots of dollars. Since there's no such thing as a totally free lunch, you should expect some degree of discomfort when you try to equalize refurbished with new. The important thing is, you can. Just register your unit, contact Garmin, give them proof of purchase and the update download will show up in your online Garmin account. From there, the download process (in terms of time and space) is exactly the same as if you had purchased a brand new unit. My service rep had the download posted to my Garmin account while I was on the phone with him, and he wanted to stay with me until the actual upgrade process was under way.  BTW, if you are are still using a fax to communicate, no wonder things may take longer. Ever heard of an e-mail attachment?   "Tons of space"? In 2009 if you can't find 2.06GB of space, just exactly how old is your computer?

The dictionary is my favorite part of the Kindle!!!  Do enjoy hearing what others think of the latest and greatest!

Author: Brig Young

Author: Lynda Kohler
Comment: I had the same question about the backlit, but once you have one you will understand. It reads like a book and the backlight would ruin that. On the plus side, any normal book light will do the trick for low light.  On the durability, I have dropped mine and the side came apart just a bit and I was able to snap it back together. Two things on this, first it is a lot of money so we bought the insurance, so if I do drop it they will fix or replace it. Second, buy a case. The cheap one from Amazon is great. This really helps with throwing it in my purse. I never worry about that.  Consider the size also, depending on what you are doing. The Kindle 2 fits in my purse which is very handy. I am not really considering upgrading to the DX because of the size and I like to take my Kindle 2 with me all the time. I think the bigger version would limit this.  Hope this helps!

Author: MAURICIO AGUIAR

I regularly work with confidential documents so I'd like to make sure I can transfer them from my computer to the Kindle without having to send them to some e-mail address first. Is it possible to transfer pdfs directly from the computer to the DX in offline mode? Thanks in advance for your help.

Author: MAURICIO AGUIAR
Comment: Dear Y.Sharifi:  Because I once asked myself the same question I will provide you with an answer.  I have a 11-inch Sony Vaio notebook and a 8-inch Acer netbook. I have had a Kindle 2 (not the DX) for a while now. Some reasons (not in any particular order) that led me to buy and use the Kindle (I am quite happy with it):  - I do not want to wait for a laptop to boot every time I want to resume reading - A laptop battery lasts for hours while the Kindle's lasts for days - The Kindle screen has been specifically designed for reading and is completely different (and better for its purpose) from a laptop screen. It does not tire the eyes as a computer does. - The Kindle is small and light enough to be held in one hand just like a pocket book. I can use the Kindle in bed just like I do with a real book. A laptop is comparatively clumsy and difficult to handle. Maybe a tablet computer would be closest to the Kindle, but still very far from it. - Having a book delivered to the Kindle in one minute is very convenient.  Please notice I do not mean to have listed all possible reasons for someone to prefer a Kindle over a laptop as a book reading device.  Note: if you want to read pdfs on the Kindle maybe the DX will help you but not the Kindle 2. This is a product designed for reading books bought from Amazon.com.  Hope this helps,  Mauricio.

Author: Eric C. Welch
Comment: You can.  You can buy Kindle books without owning a Kindle and have them downloaded to an iTouch, iPhone or computer of your choice.  Just download the Kindle software for the PC and read to you heart's content. I have two laptops, an iTouch and a Kindle2 and can read the same book on all of them and the best thing is that the last point read is sync'd between all of them.  Outstanding.  See http://www.amazon.com/gp/help/customer/display.html?ie=UTF8&nodeId=200395770

Author: K. Corn
Comment: In case no one has mentioned this before, the Kindle 2 (and perhaps all of the Kindles) can be loaned to friends but the Kindle 2 has an intriguing twist. First of all , to "loan" a Kindle you have to temporarily "unregister" yourself and the friend (who has to have an Amazon account) can register the Kindle under his or her name.   But here is the twist on the Kindle 2. I assumed all my books and magazines would disappear from that Kindle and remain only on my original (first generation) Kindle. Wrong! I could have deleted them one by one on the Kindle 2 but that was a hassle. So basically you can loan material with the Kindle 2  if you trust a friend to handle it with great care (I did and was not disappointed).   Theoretically, this should not work but it is a glitch (perhaps temporary). But in the meantime, information can be loaned between readers. Has anyone else experienced this? I think they'll correct it due to copyright laws, etc.

Author: Luis Alberto Bertolero
Comment: Well, after two weeks of reviewing Kindle3 dx vs Ipad I have reached a verdict. As ereader I like Kindle3 dx 9.7 ...but  $380 is expensive compared to the Ipad. To be more competitive, I think Kindle should cost $300 (including a cover in the price) and keep the free 3G, in this way Ipad would be an temptation you can easily avoid specially when looking for an ereader.

Author: deb217
Comment: I own 3 kindles and an iPad.  In my opinion, there are 5 advantages to the Kindle vs. the iPad. 1. The price. . . I paid $359 for my original 6" wifi/3g Kindle and $189 for my second 6" wifi/3g Kindle. I also own the DX which I paid $379. On the other hand I paid $829 for the 64gb iPad 3g/wifi (The 16gb 3g/wifi iPad costs $629). That's quite a price difference between the Kindle and the iPad.  2. Remember, if 3g is important to you, 3g is free on the Kindle. I pay $29.99 for 3g unlimitied data download on the iPad. For the monthly charge of 3g on the iPad you have just paid for the Kindle DX in 13 months.  3. Battery life. The iPad battery life does not come close to the battery life of the Kindle which is handy if you are on a cross country trip.  4. Eye strain is reduced with the Kindle (I read for hours and do not have the eye strain with the Kindle that I do with the Kindle App on my iPad).  5. Device weight. The kindle weighs less than the iPad.   Botttom line is that it depends how you use a device. I see advantages to both the Kindle and the iPad. I read for many hours which is the advantage of the Kindle but enjoy picking up my email while downloading movies and music on my iPad.  Hope this helps.

Author: Reader
Comment: I find the Kindle DX excellent for reading in bed -- easier than a book.  With a book it can be difficult to hold it open with one hand, and with the least distraction you can lose your grip and lose the page you are reading.  This is not a problem with the Kindle as there are no physical pages to fiddle with.  Another thing your mother might appreciate are the many classic books available on the Kindle for FREE - nearly everything that is in the public domain (no longer copyrighted).

Author: deb217
Comment: Yes Reader, I don't find the voice reader helpful either but, from what I understand, Amazon was trying to replace print books with the Kindle. There was a lawsuit that claimed that the Kindle did not address the issue of sight-impaired students. The school was forced to go back to the print books. The voice reader allows the sight-impaired students to participate in the class. With the voice reader pages automatically turn and read continuously. Maybe that is why it is included on the Kindle. One thing for sure, the voice reader will never take the place of audiobooks.

Author: Meadowhaven
Comment: Thank you for a helpful review of this product.  I'm still in the "thinking about it, getting information" stage of a Kindle purchase, so appreciate a Kindle owner taking the time to provide me with the pros and cons of the device!  One question--Is it wishful thinking on my part to wait for prices to go down for the Kindle DX's?

Author: bigpackerfan111
Comment: How kindle has enhanced my reading experience.  First of all...books are cumbersome. With it's leather bookcover, my kindle feels just like a book, has a nice weight.  1) I now carry nearly 100 books with me at all times.  2) I can read anytime I have 5 minutes. (3-6 enhance my experience in that my mind is now free to enjoy reading) 3) My shoulders don't ache from carrying a bag with 5 books I can't be without. 4) I can download and read a new book or whatever in seconds. 5) Books cost less on Kindle. 6) My house isn't so overrun with new books. 7) The display size is perfectly compatible with the amount of information my brain assimilates in a glance. It's almost like I can absorb the material instead of making my eyes move back and forth over the width of a page! 8) When I'm driving I listen to the "reader" mode. It has such a neutral, mechanical way of speaking that my imagination comes to life and adds inflection, corrects pronunciation, and adds life to the text in addition to keeping me mentally stimulated as I interact with what I am hearing. I LOVE that I get to determine how the words are expressed. I would not want it any other way. It's perfectly neutral.  So, to sum it up.... The ability to carry reading material everywhere and the opportunity to use random bits of time for reading have revolutionized my reading.

Author: K. Corn
Comment: I wanted to add another plus for the Kindle these days. Of course, those of us who own Kindles realize that we can change the size of the print. But has anyone else noticed that fewer large print books seem to be published now? This makes Kindles even more appealing to former readers of larger print books (although there are limitations, see info below).   I have an elderly relative who often has me buy large print books for her. It used to be common for bestsellers as well as other new books to have large print editions. No more! I can't get my aunt to use the Kindle yet but I think she may be a convert soon simply because the supply of large print books seems to be decreasing. Anyone else notice that? And even though it isn't directly related to this thread, if anyone knows of a reliable large print publisher I'd like the recommendation (just in case I can't get my aunt to use a Kindle). Also, the large print on a Kindle still isn't as large as those in the average large print book.

Author: Romeo J. Turcotte
Comment: This review was very helpful.  I am researching a Kindle for my wife who is legally blind, but can still read large print books.  It appears that by going to the larger DX, I would be able to continue to give her the satisfaction of her being able to continue to live with her passion of reading.  I will purchase the DX, based on this review, even though, the smaller 6" version is available.  Thank-You Amazon for providing a product that I am sure many handicapped individuals can capitalize on and get much enjoyment from. I am planning on writing a review on how the DX works for her.

Author: L. Brock
Comment: I agree that a lack of folders to sort books, magazines and newspapers is really needed if you are carrying 3500 books. While I am intrigued with the DX, I will happily carry my K2 with the number board until the next, new, and improved version. Love my K2.

Is this the best the market can come up with for old people who like to read but can't find everything in big print? Also, how large does the type get on this Kindle DX? Author: Mary Ellison
Comment: I mostly agree with your review, but I disagree with your observation about the size of the DX.  The size is necessary to support technical documents and journals in PDF format.  And it is a lot less "top heavy" that a 300 page hard copy document.  You must remember that this device is not intended for the casual reader market place; it is intended for those who need to deal mostly with large, technical publications and text books.

Author: Mahlers2nd
Comment: @Amy,  If you press the button that allows you to change the size of the font (the AAA key to the right of the space key), the ability to lock the auto-rotation is in that menu. You can lock the rotation in any orientation you prefer.

Author: Random Person
Comment: Susan I loved you review -- very thoughtful analysis.  I too have the Kindle 1, 2, and DX -- and I am definitely sending the DX back for all the reasons you mentioned:  the lack of left side navigation controls, the awkward size and weight, the dreadful keypad and the need to press "ALT" for every numeric entry.  what the Kindle 2 lacks in screen size it more than makes up for in terms of portability and ease of use.  My DX is going back today.

Author: Duane Alexander
Comment: Hi Kansas scholar,  I just measured the largest font size on my Kindle.  I have version 2, not the Kindle DX. At the largest type setting, the capital letters are 3mm high (or about .2 inches) and the lowercase letters are 2mm high.  This allows for roughly 11 lines of text (with roughly 5 words per line) to be displayed on the Kindle's screen.  Hope this helps.  DA

Author: R. Rodriguez
Comment: Thank you for posting this comment.  I really wanted this model but decided to wait as I just got the K2 for Christmas.  I use the .pdf function on my K2 for school works so I don't have to carry my textbooks around which is the main reason why I wanted it.  It is helpful for reading the text and I refer to my textbooks for the diagrams and pictures when I am home.  Although it would be great to have the .pdf apprear correctly on the screen of the K2 - it saves my back from carrying all my work things and school books so I deal with it and make the best of it.  But if you can't adjust the image on the DX, there is no point to get it at this time.  I would really like to see a Kindle in color and would definitely would have purchased it if it was.  I saw the Kindle app on the iPhone and the books are in color and it is amazing.  The price, the removal of the number keys row and not having the page turn on both sides of the unit also deterred me from purchasing.  Thank you for your observations on both the pros and cons of the unit and will probably wait until everything I want is available on a future Kindle.

The DX offers so much right now, but your assessment has brought up things I never thought about. Much like most others who have commented here, I appreciate your detailed assessment of this product. Based on what I've read so far, I will continue to wait and see what comes next.

Author: rosetree
Comment: I agree that not having a left hand button is almost a deal-breaker.  Why did they omit it???? If you are using a book rack & drinking coffee, my favorite am sport, you have to put your cup down to flick the page.  Baaaad Choice!

Author: Sue Beebe
Comment: I don't have a DX, but have had a K1 since they first came out.  I also have 1900 regular books, which are kept on an alphabetical listing.  I have never needed folders to sort my books.  Sorting by the author's name has worked very well for me.  However, from the reviews, I might upgrade to the K2 eventually, but probably wouldn't to the DX as I like to be able to handle my book comfortably with one hand.  I also agree that it is really a shame that there is not a Kindle for the visually impaired.  My father has macular degeneration and has always been a prolific reader.  He could see a much bigger text, but not the biggest on the Kindle.  I would also like to agree that as you get older, your eyes are weaker and tire easier, so I am already using the largest text.

Author: LaTendresse
Comment: Adding to the negatives - The DX displays books with right justified margins instead of the ragged right that is used in Kindle II - I HATE it.

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: Random   If you have a series of numbers, you press the Alt key once and just keep it pressed down.    On the other hand, they made it so you don't have to press the alt-number combo at the same time.  You can do a sequential key press -- alt key first and then the number, which helps if you want to do it one-handed.   - Andrys

Author: ExcitableBoy
Comment: I was about to order this because of the native PDF mode, but your review alerted me to the fact that there is no PDF zoom. That is a deal-breaker for me. The price is just on the edge of being too much, but if they will add PDF zoom (a magnifying "loupe" feature would be great too), then I'm in.

Author: Bubba Milt
Comment: I was dead set on getting the Kindle DX but after reading this review I have decided against it.  In fact I don't believe that I will get a Kindle at all.

Author: E. F. Stinson
Comment: This review has made my decision not to buy this product firm.  The price is prohibitive.  I would buy one for every family member if the price was lower.  We suppose, that like most electronics, if we wait, the prices will become affordable down the road.  Right now it is for the Rich and Famous reader.  It has also become a object of attention to the criminal.  Most criminal minded folk only read Billboards, so people with books are somewhat safe.  Note: Stay alert on the Subway with or without a Kindle!

Author: ExcitableBoy
Comment: Thanks for the suggestion, A&HFan, but I went ahead and got a Sony PRS-700 for the true zoom feature on PDFs. But, if you read reviews here for that device, you will see complaints about the screen being hard to read due to the layer of touch-screen added to the display. Those complaints have merit, as the display really does have poor contrast.  At this point, I will just use the Sony until a second-generation DX comes out.

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: ExcitableBoy,    I do know what you mean about the Sony PRS-700 and its display problems due to the extra glass.  My kindleworld blog quotes part of the review of David Pogue at the NYTimes about that as well as another reviewer who explains how e-ink operates, and they were both highly disappointed by the touch screen's defects and the uneven lighting of the side-lights (a good effort to please those who want night lighting w/o a clip-on lamp).   A lot of Sony users say they went back to the Sony PRS-505 for its clarity (similar to the Kindle) despite the fewer features.  But, you still have a very good unit and it handles PDFs with text reflow so that is a plus.  We're all lucky to have these good alternatives.  - Andrys

Author: Joe Skeith
Comment: It sounds as though the decision is already made.  Based on your review I agree with sending the DX back.  For $500 there are a number of other devices available.  Maybe the new Dell mini.

Author: Dennis Weeks
Comment: Based on this review, I will not be purchasing the Kindle.  Thank you for having these reviews available on your site.  I just saved $489!!!!

Author: V. Gil
Comment: I completely agree with this review, the DX is dissapointing when you consider the $489 tag

Author: Karlene J. Dance
Comment: So, I am getting ready to purchase a DX for my mother-in-law who is 86 and using magnification to read books.  Is this going to be the best by for her.  After reading the review by Susan Umpleby I'm getting a little to nervous to spend that much money if it isn't exactly the best buy.  Her daughter has a Kindle 2 and loves it but she thinks the bigger one might be better with more words per page.  Reassure me if you can.

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: Karlene, don't know that I can reassure you but there are something like 4-1 posts that rave about the DX here and you might look to see if their pros vs the cons make it worthwhile for your mother-in-law or not.     It would depend on whether it's a problem for her to hold a hard-copy book.  The latter is almost always heavier than a DX, but the DX will be heavier than a Kindle 2.  Some get a 'Platform' version of a cover/jacket and it can just be propped up and that won't weigh on the hands.  I do that for my Kindle 2 sometimes.       If you're going for utmost clarity of reading and more words on a page, the DX is, for me, a great unit.  I use it at home (and I am older than most people posting) while I use the Kindle 2 on the streets as it is more likely to fit into a purse and it's quite a beautiful little unit.   I do have a lot more info at my Kindleworld page (google that if interested) that might help you make up your mind, but the only negatives I can think of for anyone who is not keen on using it for editing PDFs, is that it's heavier than the Kindle 2.  It's also far easier on the eyes while at the same time giving you more words at one time on a page.  I personally love the DX and Kindle 2 and it's hard to go wrong in either case but it's the DX that I choose to use when at home.  One can also put a pillow on the lap while reading as some do, and that lightens things up too.  - Andrys

Author: M. Burke
Comment: Most of your complaints are extremely petty. I can think of only a few actual SIGNIFICANT complaints about the DX. Only your complaint about folders is justified. Lame review.

Author: ExcitableBoy
Comment: Her review kept me from making the mistake of buying it. When Amazon advertises native PDF compatibility, I just assumed it would have a full-fledged zoom. That omission will keep a lot of people away who want to read technical PDFs.

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: ExcitableBoy, most definitely I do call myself a Kindle "Enthusiast" in my intro/profile, which is the same thing, but it's for what I consider quite good reasons.  If you look at the tags at the right column, bottom, you will see that my stories are also often critical of Amazon decisions and I have criticisms of the various Kindles.  I cover some sore points that other bloggers don't.    BUT I continue to really enjoy the Kindle, which is like a very varied window to words and ideas for me - open that window and there is so much to choose from and the study tools are no small reason - I love the annotations and search capabilities and the results and the clarity of most pages this way.   HOWEVER, I have written columns (first one on May 18) which rag on Amazon for not putting full PDF support (annotations) in the DX, and for those in school, Amazon really will have to.  I think it's a matter of getting full licensing from Adobe and adding capabilities in upgrades to the firmware.     Zoom will be crucial in some cases, yes, and while the landscape mode does quite a good job on most things you've noted have clear lettering, as I think my photo page shows (they can be double the size or more in some cases depending on width of a line), there are those for whom that won't do, and you're one of them since your 24" desktop monitor is barely making it for unclearly scanned documents, not to mention anyone with a 24" monitor has high standards.    In other words, you'd need a 24" e-reader screen, which would be a quite unwieldy portable E-Reader, for some of your scanned PDFs.   At 1200 x 834 resolution for the smaller screen of the size we see for the DX, it's obviously quite good for some thiings, but not if your own 24" screen needs good zooming on it beyond that 24" capability.      In other words, any e-reader of a smaller size won't be much good.  I also just did an article on the Kindle's use in storing and displaying approach-plates for pilots, and they've just launched that, with a video of this at youtube and you'll find that at the kindleworld.blogspot.com page also.  The videoclip gives a better idea than most videos, of what the DX is like for some tough PDF-type viewing.    A problem for some with PDFs on any b&w screen with gray scale translation of colors, is that gray shades going from light to dark have a lot of gradations which too often won't have nearly the contrast of color charts.  So I don't recommend any gray-scale e-reader where that is important.  Thanks for checking out the landscape mode photos, EB.   - Andrys

Author: islandreader
Comment: Thanks for this thoughtful and honest review. I was certainly thinking about purchasing the DX but believe that I will await version 2 which will, hopefully, incorporate most or all of your points here. I have both the K1 and K2 and really enjoy the latter.

Author: vtbobby
Comment: You can download the daily NYT puzzle online every morning, and the Sunday puzzle on Saturday night!  What is the problem? (this is a comment to a few other commenters, not the original review) We can't get a physical NYT here, and we can't get Kindle signal through the air...so everything goes through the computer.  Will buy a DX (or newer ) when they add Wi-Fi!

Author: Mary Roach
Comment: Excellent review! I've got a DX sitting in my shopping cart right now, and I think I'll go ahead with the purchase, based on   1)I read a fair number of technical books with illustrations  2)When I read fiction, I love to look at maps about the places I'm reading about. I have the 2007 edition of the CIA Factbook (available for your Kindle for 99 cents!), but the maps are almost unreadable. It wouldn't take much larger for them to be useful.  3)I have a lot of manuals in pdf format, which I moved to my Kindle 1. Many stayed pretty readable, many did not. Experience will tell for this item.  As another responder pointed out, the paper back and/or hard copy of the technical books I read are also awkward to hold (not exactly bed-time reading).   Still no folders sucks, and no SD card sucks, but that's true of the Kindle 2 as well. So I'm hanging on to my Kindle 1 for now for leisure reading.   I bought the Kindle 1 in the first place because the piles of books were getting to me, and I love it. Now that I'm observing the piles of technical books starting to grow again because they're not suitable for Kindle 1, it was time to take a hard look at Kindle DX.  Thank you again, Susan, for a very helpful review.

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: Mary,    When you do get your DX, please come back and report on it - or let us know you just posted a review, pro or con.     Like you I have a copy of the CIA factbook.  Mobile Read forums point to the most recent one also, so I will get that soon.   I love to travel so I just put the travel info from a brochure into Microsoft Word and then used CutePdf utility (free) to 'print' it "to pdf" and then I put that on my DX and it's fun to read the details there and have the maps at hand to prepare for the trip too.    My electronics manuals in PDF format tend to be very readable in rotated landscape mode.  I do love this feature as I am very manual-oriented and now don't have to wonder where I put one  :-)  If you didn't see my earlier comment on this, I put some sample photos of vertical to landscape mode at http://pbase.com/andrys/kindleplus    I'd recommend sending for the Octo sleeve as it is only $30 but it feels almost weightless and is a perfect fit.  Sometimes I place my DX on top of it and use it like a desk and just hold the sides, as I don't like reading the DX in a cover that usually adds weight and awkwardness.    I also use an M-Edge Platform cover that allows you to stand the Kindle up and not hold it at all.    But outside of that, I just read the DX w/o cover and am probably more careful with it.  I took it to a city council hearing the other day and while listening to people speaking I also looked up newspaper articles on the issue when some speakers were not as interesting.   The thing is I always preferred my Kindle 2 for portability but the DX screen size has become my preferred size for reading and it is a startlingly clear screen!   So I now carry a slightly larger purse.    However, remember that your pdfs are usually in color and that the grayscale translation of those will make for less contrast than liked.   At any rate, since you're coming from a Kindle 1 and are prepared for any downsides, I'll want to know what you think after you get yours.   - Andrys

Author: Wade M.
Comment: Sounds like you've answered your own question....if I was that disappointed there would be no question as to whether I would return the item.  Your review leaves no doubt that you are disgusted with the DX...not sure how you could have rated it a 3 out of 5 stars with all of the issues you have with the unit.

Author: Dave
Comment: I appreciate the review.  I would point out a flaw in your description, although I knew what you meant.  And, I would add, if this has been mentioned earlier, I apologize, but I did not take time to read all the comments.  So, you say it is top heavy, but the way you describe it, you have to be wrong.  In the review you say, it is really not that heavy, but it is top heavy.  Top heavy things are bad, since that is usually an unstable configuration, since a heavy base means less chance of tipping over.  Top heavy here meaning the top weighs more than the bottom.  Maybe you should have said it "feels" top heavy.  It is not heavier on the top, or it wouldn't feel even heavier on the top when you turn it upside down.  That is a contradiction.  Being heavier at the bottom is good.  So, it is not how the weight is distributed that is the problem, as much as the total amount of weight being distributed.  Basically, it is too heavy.  You said it wasn't, but your description would indicate that it is.  I get the point, anyway, and just wanted to be a nitpicking nerd.  Good review, by the way.  I agree with you entirely except for the misstated point.

Author: listenswithwolves
Comment: Thanks for your review, Susan. Reading ergonomics seem to have been ignored on this device. The  location of page-turning buttons is so important, and it appears that Amazon dropped the ball on  that one. Also, they had a great opportunity to re-vamp the OS to allow sorting and folders but in  their rush to market they basically ignored it.   As a K1 owner, I was thinking about upgrading to this, but can't really find a reason to upgrade  besides the screen real-estate and the 16 grey scale. Good review, and thanks for saving me a lot  of money.

Author: Bill Hudson
Comment: Thanks for the "heads-up".  I was concerned about the size and ease of carrying it.  Think I'll go with the K2.

Author: Wheat
Comment: I have to agree that the lack of a memory card slot doesn't make sense to me.  The number of books is reasonable, but that number will be drastically if you store email, images, and MP3 music on the reader.  The lack of a memory expansion slot also places an unnecessary limitation on the useful life of the device.

Author: C. Chimayan
Comment: Thank you so much

Author: J. Kim
Comment: I agree with a lot of the gripes on here.   This DX needs an improvement so I  advise potential buyers to wait for  the next generation of Kindle to come  out.  The cost of this should make this  fantastic, not just OK.  As it stands now,  it is just OK.

Author: Pequecita
Comment: I'm interested on buying it specially to read scientific journal papers (IEEE-format papers for example). Please comment something about how does it works for this purpose. My special concern is if you can upload your own PDF material without using the net (like dragging the files thorough the USB port of my PC). I already pay for many scientific papers, so I don't want to pay an extra fee to download, each one, to my reader. Thanks!

Author: Susan Lynn Umpleby
Comment: Super Dave said: "Maybe you should have said it "feels" top heavy. It is not heavier on the top, or it wouldn't feel even heavier on the top when you turn it upside down. That is a contradiction. Being heavier at the bottom is good. So, it is not how the weight is distributed that is the problem, as much as the total amount of weight being distributed. Basically, it is too heavy. You said it wasn't, but your description would indicate that it is.  I get the point, anyway, and just wanted to be a nitpicking nerd. Good review, by the way. I agree with you entirely except for the misstated point."  Perhaps, as you say, I WAS unclear.  No, the DX is not very heavy at all.  What I meant by "top heavy" is this:  In the normal way of things the reader holds the Kindle (K1, K2, and DX) toward the bottom, at the keyboard--this gives easy access to the page buttons.  The DX is so much longer, though, that holding it there increases the drag on your hands.  Even with the DX's light weight that drag quickly becomes noticeable and tiring.     BTW, I did end up sending my DX back.  But I am awaiting the next model of it in the hope that Amazon has made improvements to it.

Author: I. Gower
Comment: I have the K2 and would like to get the DX.  Is the font size any larger on the DX?  My visually handicapped husband has to use a magnifying glass with the K2. Thanks.

Author: E. F. Stinson
Comment: Thanks to all that took the time to comment.  This is a great help to the planet.  The evaluations by actual users have made me decide not to buy thw DX.  I will buy one of the older models and wait until Amazon gets their act together.  Can anyone tell me if the older models have the option of listening to the book when you cannot be reading, such as getting into a car, etc?  Rigjht now I own and play a lot of books on CD when on long trips.  I have not listened to my car radio for  quite some time.  Thank you all for your time and interest. Eddie stinsoneddie@prodigy.net

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: The Kindle 2 will read to you (not the Kindle 1).  But its speakers are not as strong or loud.    You should read the bulk of reviews on the reviews page to get the best idea of what evaluations of actual users are.    In either case, remember that the text-to-speech feature uses more battery juice so you might want to get a car charger for the unit you buy.

Author: Dana Glendinning
Comment: I agree with Susanmpley with her comments. She is way more astute than I am with these applications  however, since reading her/his posting, I found this to be a problem. Thank you Susan!  Marko

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: BlondeUnicorn,   That is Susan's personal reaction to the Kindle DX.  If that were a general response, it would't be selling to non-students.  If you go the Amazon forums or to the kindleboards.com forums, you'll see that a lot of people who don't read textbooks love their DX's for the normal fare even though they previously loved reading on their Kindle 2's and still do.    For me, it's much better, though I am only 5'4" and slight, with thin wrists.  It's not heavy if one has the ability to hold a regular hardcover book for any length of time, but that will vary with the individual.    The clarity is wonderful, as is the ability to handle informational material from anywhere in PDF format so that we can see the originally-intended layout.  Google's free books are in PDF so it's not only textbooks.     I'm going on a trip and it's the DX I'm bringing with me.  I really am fond of my Kindle 2 but I just enjoy reading on the DX much more.  We're all different.  Amazon lets you try one for 30 days - as no one else can judge for you which is best for you.   For comparison articles, you can visit "A Kindle World" by googling it.  I do have my own photos up of each model in real-life use at www.pbase.com/andrys/kindle2 and www.pbase.com/andrys/kndleplus and maybe those can give you a better idea than commercial photos.      No model will suit everyone so I don't see how Amazon can do what you want which seems to be that Amazon would ensure everyone is happy with whatever model they buy.   - Andrys

Author: Leenie
Comment: You took the word's right out of my mouth.  I'll surely be hoping that Amazon will follow your sugestions completely.  I will not purchase another kindle untill they start listening to the same comments posted over and over again.  Please, Amazo-you can do it!!!

Author: Catherine S. Stitt
Comment: I have a k1 and have waited to see reviews on the DX before  making a purchase.  I have planned to give my D1 to my 8yoa grandson, but now I am concerned what is the deal with bleed thru china text on the DX???  Also is the audio reader portion of dx reliable this is one of the features I am most intrested in. How can I check for listing of books that have audio feature. When is the next hopefully improved DX version due out?  Thanks for imput catherine

Author: C. Zessin
Comment: thanks for the details.  I guess I'll wait a while longer to invest in an electronic book reader.

Author: IvyB5O5
Comment: Question: Which Kindle should I get? I am an avid reader. Been reading myself to sleep for 30+ years, usually anywhere from 30 minutes to 2 hours before drifting off. I am now 50+ and have been having some vision problems which means I need to use magnified glasses in order to read. However, I find them  uncomfortable while laying in bed. I'm thinking a Kindle may help since the text size can be adjusted, but I don't know if I'll be happy with a K2 or if I should consider a DX. Is the text on the DX larger than on the K2? NOTE: I may also use the Kindle to read some newspapers or magazines, not just books. Your feedback is appreciated. Thanks!

Author: sam i am
Comment: Pam, I agree with you.  I've been on the fence about getting a Kindle since the K1 came out.  My husband even told me to wait because the Kindle is such a single task oriented device.  Which is all I want, an electronic reader.  The more bells and whistles the Kindle gets the more we want it to do.  So, folks ask yourselves what do you want a reader or a computer.  BTW, I'm going with the K2.  When they come out with email and Web browsing, I'll think about upgrading.  For now, I'm getting off the fence and joining the Kindle Generation. Thanks Pam.

Author: Shipper
Comment: Yeah you are right, the bugs and improvements do need to be worked on. I don't even own any Kindle but really want the DX. Yet if they ever do make a color version, THAT things' gonna be probably like $700 freakin' dollars, Kindle, you CHARGE TOO HIGH a price for your DX, LOWER IT!

Author: The Meltdownman
Comment: I am new to this kindle thing but would like to know a couple of things for possible future purpose.  If anyone could help I would appreciate it:  1) Can you organize your books by somehow checking in on your library and then load an SD card up and put the organized file on a computer where you can download a set of reading material (you have to charge the Kindle any way)? 2) I haven't read too much in the way of the voice feature on this model.  Is it any better than the K1 or K2?  I would venture to guess people that have a tough time reading would find this feature critical. 3) Does the Kindle read captions below pictures? 4) Does it not seem strange that they have not come out with color?  After all this comment section is listed under "Art & Photograpy".  If I am spending 500 dollars on something like this for viewing books on photograpy I guess I will have to limit myself to Ansel Adams work. 5) How is the screen with regards to viewing it in bright sunlight?  Is there glare coming off if shiny surface? 6) I read a lot of techincal documents that are often times scanned for later viewing.  Can someone tell me how one downloads these types of documents at work for later downloads to a Kindle and sorting such types of documents for later retrieval.  I would like something like a Kindle for business trips.  Thanks Ahead of time...much appreciated.

Author: Pen Name
Comment: Amen, fellow "in the '80s reader." You've answered my question on whether to switch from my Sony Reader to the Kindle or not. Thanks, Al.

Author: Roberta C. Martin
Comment: Thanks, Susan, for the careful and thoughtful review.  Between you and GadgetQueen, I now know enough to hang onto the cash and wait for Amazon to pay attention to both of you. Behnny

Author: T. Nathan
Comment: Thank you, Susan, for this great review.  I think you just saved me $489.  I'm really just looking for something primarily to view my many .pdf's with, something a little more portable than a laptop (I can't bring a laptop to work, but I don't think they'd object to a reader).  I was already hesitant to buy the DX because the idea of emailing 100 MB .pdf files to convert them to the Kindle format doesn't appeal to me.  So not being able to zoom in or increase the font size on the .pdf kind of kills my whole reason for wanting the DX in the first place.  Your other complaints weren't deal-breakers for me, but they certainly reinforced my decision to wait until a better reader is available.  And I agree with some of the other comments that SD support is a must.

Author: J. Anderson
Comment: 1.  There is no SD card on the K2/DX, but you can manage your library with your computer without a problem.  Even easier than that you can download any book you own directly from Amazon any time you want without reconnecting to your computer.  This obviously wont work for PDFs that you load through your computer and such, but anything you bought from Amazon you can redownload whenever you like.  2.  I think the read aloud feature is more of a gimick than a great feature.  I mean it works, but I find it rather useless myself.  3.  On the read aloud it will read captions below pictures and will get confused as to what is "next" on complicated formats, it works best with novel type text.  4.  Color eBook Readers are VERY expensive right now, this is not an LED screen and it is still a VERY expensive technology for color.  They sell for 3-4k right now.  This is not the device for looking at photography, that would be much better suited for a tablet PC or similar device.  5.  You really need to see the screen, it is more like looking at the page of a book then looking at a "screen".  There are very few issues with sunlight and it is not a shiny surface at all. 6.  On the DX these types of documents will work well, on the K2/K1 the PDF conversion ability will not do you much goo.d

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: M. Smith,   The DX resizes the fonts when you let it auto-rotate to landscape mode or you manually set it for Landscape.  It's considerably better this way -- the fonts enlarge to fill the width of the device.   I've seen some reviewers on news sites who missed the option and later noticed quite a difference when they did turn it around.  I have the DX and it is very good on PDFs (for reading).  On the other hand you could instead pay $800 for the new Plastic Logic Que to get more flexibility with editing on it and a slightly larger size.

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: Yes, if you prefer it that way but you haven't tried it for yourself.  I personally can't stand zooming in on the pc to see bits and pieces of the screen.  Amazon has a 30-day return policy, and they don't care what your reason is.  You can return it just for not liking it enough as Susan did.    But I happen to love the display on this device.  It's true of many of us on kindleboards.com and the Amazon forums.  Am under 5'4" and am thin wristed.  But the unit doesn't bother me at all as far as weight.      The width that the landscape mode is on the DX, the original size of the document is quite well approximated.    Some of us really need to read PDFs and there is no alternative right now that isn't far more expensive.  And I find the unit really quite beautiful in the presentation of a page.    You can see some photos at www.pbase.com/andrys/kindleplus I choose to carry it around when out because it is a really excellent display even though I have the smaller Kindle.       Besides, all you have to do is keep the PDF as reference for the layout and then convert a copy in 3 minutes with either the free mobipocket creator or Stanza into a 'mobi' file (Kindle format - which was the former more-open format).     And if you don't want to do the conversion you can send it to your [you]@free.kindle.com and put "Convert" on the Subject line and Amazon will send a link to the converted copy back to your email  address normally used for correspondence or orders with Amazon,  converted at no cost.    Then the text reflows to fit the device size and while the layout is not true to the original, you still have the original to check against and you can enlarge the fonts on this copy all you want.      We are getting an upgrade before summer that will double the current largest font.     Personally, I don't care if others have deal breakers - to each their own, but if you want solutions, sometimes you have to look for them.   - Andrys

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: Excitable,   There are so many things coming out this year, it's hard to know what vendor model will grab us next.  Most of us on the forums who initially regretted lack of zoom on PDFs came rather quickly to love the DX regardless and we don't touch our K2's much anymore and feel bad about that because we were so pleased with them before.  I have scores of PDFs on my DX.     Glad your wife does appreciate your gift, which was very thoughtful! They were never inexpensive gifts.  Especially even half a year ago.    I personally find too much emphasis was put by readers on how awkward it was for one person to hold the DX when used to the K2 -- a hard cover book is FAR harder on any hand.    I do feel a bit bad that people who otherwise want a Kindle for reading actually decide not to even try it because, they say, of one review based on a reaction that is quite individual.  While Susan's is an agonizingly honest review, there are many of us who reacted another way.   I feel strongly as shown by my choosing to carry the DX on vacation instead of my little K2, which is definitely more 'personal' in feel.  Just too pleasant to read on.  That was despite my already bringing my 10" netbook for work.    Nevertheless, the DX will not be a comfortable size for some people -- I just would not read a post and generalize a point made, to myself.  IF interested in seeing for yourself, Amazon does have that 30-day trial in your home with full refund.    But the big point is that you do want something nigh perfect before spending that much money at all even on a trial basis, and that's the most important thing.  You know what's most important for you and you've gone with your gut feelings - they show what you really want and don't want.  That you're here a lot after deciding against it makes me think sometimes that you're not entirely convinced though and would like to be able to change your mind, maybe.   So I present another side.  Good luck.   There are other devices coming up this year that you WILL like enough, I think.

Author: Gerald Hansen
Comment: I was going to buy one for my girlfriend's birthday, but now having second thoughts. Thanks!

Author: madmaus
Comment: Thank you for the insight. My fiance' was about to buy me the DX but I asked him to hold off till I read some of the reviews and I must say that I choose NOT to get the DX. I'll stick to the K2 until Amazon balances out the needs and wants of the customers vs cost saving reductions on such a high priced item.  - One of the key things that I am extremely finicky about is the functionality of paging through utilizing either the left or right side of the Kindle. That is precious since I find myself switching from one hand to another and clicking accordingly (I am ambidextrous).  I am sure that this is a huge disappointment for left handed individuals. I find this more as a cost reduction.   - With the added weight, it will be very obvious that the left "next page" click is missing.  - No folder assortment is just down right silly especially with the number of years they already have in the business.  - Changing the functionality of numbers sounds like a cost issue. Less buttons, less cost. There is more than enough space on a DX to keep the buttons for the numbers. The DX is NOT the size of a cellphone (>.<)  There has to be a more profound reason why someone would want to "upgrade" from the K1/K2 to the DX. For the price that they has put on it... it seems like it is not worth it. I'll print the pages that I need from my pdf's for now. It is better than getting frustrated. Before long, there will be a DX2 and I can only hope that Amazon listens to their customers instead of what they think the customer wants without asking. /sigh

Author: momma ann
Comment: For those who are visually impaired. I would like to see an option to choose so I could have the book background in black and the fonts in white. That is called the polarity.  Some visually impaired people might not want to hear about the pictures, so give an option so we can unselect pictures unless you are going to describe them like NLS does for special VHS tapes from the library services.  I agree with other posters, can we have a way to make folders on the Kindles?  One more thing offer trade ins on the old Kindles, customers can use the credit towards a newer version of the Kindle. Author: David M. Peterson
Comment: I agree with everything the Susan wrote and I also have the K2 and DX. I found my K2 text to be darker and crisper than the DX. Also the lowest Font setting on the DX is not the same Font as the lowest on the K2. The next to lowest Font setting on the K2 (one I prefer) seems to be the same as the DX lowest Font Setting. I found the text to less crisp and faded compared to the K2 on this setting. With comparable Font settings the DX has about 2.5 times more text on screen.     For travel the DX is too big and uncomfortable for long reading. Also was looking for an E-Reader for my Grandmother who is finding reading large books difficult due to the weight. She found the DX to heavy and uncomfortable also. The K2 was nice but she still prefers a book. I found the K2 much better and like Susan prefer the KS's Next Page on both sides of the screen.  I do like the magnetic closure of the DX leather cover but it is not a deal breaker when compared to the K2 leather cover with no closure device.   I know both units don't have add on memory capability but really there is no need. All of your items are kept on the Amazon servers and are ready for retrieval anytime via wireless or direct connection to a computer and internet download.

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: David, you need to call Kindle Customer Service about your Kindle DX if its text is less dark or crisp than the Kindle 2 !   There is something quite wrong with it if that's true.    For travel, the DX is what I took when I recently had 3 weeks of vacation and was also bringing a Samsung 10" netbook, both to go into my backpack for some of the time I was walking.  I used the DX on the various short air flights that the trip included and I generally take it out and about with me even here, where I live, though I sometimes take the little K2 if I want to use a smaller purse.    I am not quite 5'4" , am female, and am thin, with a small frame and rather bony wrists.  Add that I'm in my 7th decade.  Yet, I have no trouble holding the DX, which is FAR lighter than most books I would carry, especially since I don't have to press it back.  It WILL be too heavy for some, but one should not read and believe it is too heavy for most, as many people who have bought it feel the same way I do and stop using the Kindle 2 much, after getting the DX.    I'm serious that you should call Amazon Kindle customer service, at 866-321-8851 to request a replacement for your DX as in no way should it be less clear than your Kindle 2.  I have a Kindle 2 that is as clear as the Kindle 1 as shown in photo comparisons I've made and which are on my site.    Many found their K1's to be more clear.  Yet the DX is VIVIDly more clear when compared to even my K2.  For examples (including side-by-sides with K2) see my photo series at   - www.pbase.com/andrys/kindleplus    When going back to the K2 I am actually frustrated that the PrevPage is not on the right-hand side at all.  It's what you're used to or prefer.  When I want to have the Prev/Next on the left-hand side of the DX, I turn it upside down.       Really, it's all in what a person prefers - but there is nothing "too heavy" for everyone when it comes to the DX or "too small" for everyone when it comes to the K2 (though many come to feel that way after using the DX).    And if you're one to get information from the Net in PDF format (many academic and business sites offer information in PDF format, and Google often leads us to them), you'll be glad the screen is that much larger.  In either case, for PDFs, it's best to read those in Landscape orientation.   - Andrys

Comment: B.Jett,   Many of us just adapt to it the way we adapt to physical books, we get external light.  Use a lamp or good lighting in some cases. Author: Maria Lourdes Barcelon Locsin
Comment: That the controls to turn the page, etc., are on only one side is a serious oversight because if you are a righthanded person you will hold the Kindle with your left and use your right to insert your Metro pass after boarding the bus. I also have a probably unfounded fear that if you use any button too much, it will wear out its function and finally collapse because all springs sag. But with the Kindle 2's two sided controls, you feel you are evenly distributing the use or abuse and extending the life of the controls  two times. All of this may just be baseless fears but then I am totally ignorant of technology and so am afraid. I want to buy the DX, the price is cheap, and I will be able to read the tables that are now too small and obscure in the Kindle 2 as in Reinhardt and Rogoff's expensive kindle edition of This Time is Different on 800 years of financial crisis where I have to skip the tables which are the core of the book and which do not respond to expansion unlike the text. Maybe I will wait the DX out until controls on both sides are restored. Soon I hope. Because, although a proud Luddite, I am a writer, editor, ghostwriter and a congressman who has used the Mac extensively--having introduced Apple to the Presidential Palace after having helped topple the previous one by a revolution in 1986--it is for every conceivable purpose except drafting the speeches I wrote for the President, Corazon Aquino, for all succeeding presidents, except one jerk, and, finally, for myself when I entered Congress, with a Montblanc. You can write fast on a computer but elegantly only with a Montblanc. Teodoro L. Locsin, Jr.,

Author: Mars Velvet
Comment: The Kindle DX gives you the chance to organize your books etc. into folders called "Collections".  Press "menu".  Select "create a collection".  Name your collection (for example "Dickens") and move all books that fit into that category into your new collection titled "Dickens".  You can create as many collections as you wish.  Then if you are in the mood for a scary story...  highlight "Thrillers" with the 5-way button and move it right to see books in that collection.    I made several collections and next to each is the number of books therein.   I hope this was helpful for those wishing to organize!  -MV

Author: Susan Lynn Umpleby
Comment: I AM THE REVIEWER.  And I just want to remind everyone that my review was for the original Kindle DX and was posted over a year ago.  A couple of things have changed since that time:  1)  Software updates now allow the users of the DX (& the regular Kindle) create folders to organize their books in, which is a big improvement.  2) Those software updates also have improved the functioning of PDF files on the Kindle, allowing zoom in, notes, highlights, etc.  3) The price has dropped from $489 to $379.  However, regarding awkwardness of the DX itself, the placement of page turn buttons and the like, my opinion still stands.

Author: Sooz
Comment: Not sure if anyone answered you, but the text gets really large.  I don't know the font number, but its big enough that my little ones can see it when I use it for group reading time (they have so many awesome preschool books on ebooks).  It can be a bit to sit and hold it, but if you have a place where you prop your books normally, you can do the same with this kindle, its about 8x10 dimensions.  Then you don't have to hold flopping pages, you just reach up and hit the next button.  It works GREAT on a treadmill or stationary bike, so I can imagine you could set up (if you don't have it already) a place to prop it so you do not have to hold it.  The graphics are AMAZING.  I am astonished at how easy it is to read, so clear, and light angles don't get in the way - sun, bright white lights, etc.  Good luck.  It is an expensive reader, but I'm loving mine!  Best anniversary gift I've ever received.

Author: Jill Chesrow
Comment: Hi,  I am visually impaired and so is my 16 year old son.  We have a juvenile form of Macular Degeneration called Best's Disease.  My brother borrowed me his Kindle to see if it would help my son with his reading in school.  The largest font on the version his has, which I think is the original, is called a 6 but I do not know what that translates to as far as font size usually goes by.  My son could read it and I could read it easily.  His vision is worse than mine.  My mom also has the eye disorder and she could not see it very well.   So here is my thought.  If your vision is around 20/200 it would probably be a good thing for you.  If it is worse than that then I would look into other specific low vision stuff from a Low Vision Center.  What I really liked about it was that the screen was illuminated as light is key for us to be able to read well.  I am looking forward to getting the Kindle DX :)  Best of Luck,  Jill Marie

Author: Kjetil Kringlebotten
Comment: Susan Umpleby, you have some valid points, but I disagree with some.  1) "You can't change the font size on PDFs." Yes, just as any other reading device or computer. Many people complain about this, but to change font size on a PDF document is impossible. It cannot be done. It lies in the very nature of PDF, as it is a fixed format. You cannot change font size in Adobe Acrobat Reader or Adobe Acrobat Professional either. The only thing that is possible, which can be done on the Kindle, is to zoom in or out. I agree that the zoom could be much better, but that is another question.  7) "Still no folders." Yes, no folders. But they do have collection. I don't see the problem.

Author: Susan Lynn Umpleby
Comment: Kjetil Kringlebotten:  If you look at the date of my review, you will find it was written when the DX was first released.  Much has changed since then, as I have already posted.  For instance, Collections did not exist.  And now the user is given the ability to zoom in on PDFs whereas before they were almost impossible to read--which is why I mentioned that one should make sure the font in the original document was *very* large before converting to to PDF for it to be readable on the DX.

Author: Arts&HistoryFan
Comment: Susan,    Amazon allows all of us to edit our reviews after the fact, and most who find that Amazon has changed the model's capabilities after the review, often in response to requests, will ADD an update to the bottom of the *actual* review so that new readers can see them up front.     Hardly anyone would take the time to go through 20 pages of comments to find your posting as you suggest to Kjetil K saying you'd "already posted" changes.     I think it's fairer if you post them to your review at the bottom so people know upfront without plowing through the humongous series of replies to try to find any updates since no one is going to be buying the old model of the DX.    You can edit by going to your profile and going to your review.  It's really a great feature.      Then we'll also have a good history of the DX in how it disappointed you and how the latest version may have corrected this or that failing that had been a problem for you and some others.

Author: Wendy
Comment: Thank you for your review covering non-Kindle readers.  I've been torn between Kindle and Sony and found this quite helpful.  One thing I am interested in: the Sony Reader has a bookmark feature that I haven't seen listed as a Kindle feature.  Does Kindle have this as well?

Author: Mahlers2nd
Comment: Hi Wendy,  Thanks for your comment -- the Kindle does do bookmarks as well.  It automatically remembers what page you were on so if the reader goes to sleep while you are in the middle of the book, when you turn it back on, it goes right back to that page.  The Sony works the same as well.  I would say both bookmark and "place-saving" (keeping track of where you are in a book without explicitly setting a bookmark) work comparably on both readers.  The exception to this (and again, this applies to both readers) is if the reader goes through a hard reboot.  In that situation, it will save your bookmarks but may lose your place if you didn't set an explicit bookmark.  Hope this makes sense.  Best regards,

Author: Mahlers2nd
Comment: Hi B.C.  Thanks for your nice comments.    In answer to your question -- the browser is more limited than an iPad or a netbook.  However, it is serviceable for looking up google maps and wikipedia etc.  Navigation is a bit trickier because of the fact that you don't have a mouse.  But yes, the data plan is completely free.  No contract required.  Recently, when we were on a long drive to go on vacation, I let my boys use the Kindle browser to look stuff up on Wikipedia and do some surfing.  While neither of them were going to trade in their laptops for a Kindle, it was good to have this option available as they were getting board and they could pass the time doing some surfing.  I think the biggest problem you will find is that the browser is not fully functional in being able to render some of the more complicated and dynamic web pages which rely on a lot of Java/Javascript/Flash.  But for stuff that is more static, it works pretty well.  I hope that helps answer your questions a bit.    Best regards and thanks again for taking the time to comment.

Author: las cosas
Comment: The surprising thing is how undependable the Kindle features are with .pdf files.  All I can say is that documents created as .pdf tended to use the full screen size more than scanned documents.  I know, "tended to" isn't much help, but there was little consistency.  And sometimes, particularly with scanned items (though again, sometimes not) you not only have the margin, but the entire document has a "frame" around it further lessening the page size.  In several cases the end result was type font, in portrait mode, of not more than half the size of the printed page.  In many cases this was considerably better with landscape, in a few cases it was worse.  This same lack of consistency was also true of the search feature.    But font size is the big issue for .pdf.  This morning I have a headache from reading small Kindle font.

Author: R. Morris
Comment: I was planning on using my DX to view PDFs, so thanks for this review! (However, I have already ordered mine, so we'll see... :))  Also, "printing" a document as a PDF does not (necessarily) make it an "image." In most cases, you should find that it is quite similar to a PDF created by other means. Most PDF printing drivers create PDFs for most documents using the same language (this being PDF's page description language, which includes commands for things like lines, curves, embedded fonts, embedded graphics, etc.)--I don't think any would actually convert it to an image for typical documents.  EDIT: I should note, of course, that this does not apply to PDFs created from books, images, etc. that were scanned and, thus, were an image even before the PDF creation process. :) (Although I'd be tempted to try OCR if it's mostly normal text...)

Author: Eugen Paval

Author: Michael J. Cresci
Comment: First all of, thank you for saving me $500. I cannot personally justify paying that much for a book reader for most of the reasons commented on by other posters. Having said that, I  believed that the power of this device is in the other applications. PDF's are much more powerful than most people know. Embedding video, audio, hot links (both within the document and to webpages) are powerful Acrobat PDF features. Also,the sticky notes, editing features and typewriter tool which allows you to fill out forms are other very important  Adobe Acrobat PDF features.   I feel that Amazon should partner up with the Adobe people and see if Acrobat reader could be included as with the PDF reader function in the Kindle. No matter how wonderful and exciting the technology is, it is just a useless expensive toy if you don;t get to use it all the time. The technology should serve us and make our life easier.  I also wanted to comment about what PDF's actually are and are not.  PDF's can consist of Raster (bitmap) images, objects (vector) , video and audio. When a document is converted into a PDF, the text is outlined - it is made into an object or vector illustration. If you opened a PDF document with Adobe Illustrator, you would see that each letter of the type is an individual object or illustration which you can change any number of ways graphically. However, you cannot click and drag and change the font because the words are no longer type - they are made into  objects by the PDF conversion.  So in kindle you might be able to scale them up or down in size but that is about it. As far as the white margins go. It would seem that the Kindle reader cuts off the actual margin outside of the text frame. If you have white space inside the text frame, the reader probably cannot tell and that would be the reason why sometime the white space is cut and sometimes not. If you made your margins inside the text frame, the reader wouldn't see the margins.   I love the concept of an e-reader. But for $500 it better be a lot more than an electronic toy that allows me to buy books that I cannot share or download non-functional PDF's. This review is not meant as a dis to Amazon for making the Kindle.I think they have a big one up on Sony. If it was reasonable priced, I would have it tomorrow. But for the price, for me, it just needs to do more. Let's see some functionality on the PDF side of this device so we can do a whole a whole lot more with it than buy book.

Author: Stephen
Comment: This is an excellent post pointing out the deficiencies of the PDF format for portable devices. Unfortunately it does have a lot to do with PDF and very little to do with eBook readers (Kindle or others). While PDF is a powerful format for sharing documents among computer users, its original design was never intended to included smaller handheld readers. PDF is not intended to "reflow" to fit the display size. Unfortunately to get a true PDF reader, you have to abandon the concept of reading on a handheld. Consider, for example, the large number of PDF documents created for "side by side" page display. These documents are never going to work well on a small display where a single page is all that can be reasonably be displayed at one time.  Hopefully Adobe will someday address this shortcoming of the PDF format. In the meantime, the Kindle DX is a fair step in providing users a way to read PDF documents without a larger Laptop computer. Until Adobe addresses the issue of PDF documents.  For myself, what I do with many of my older PDF documents is to dump them to HTML and then re-compile them to Mobi format for reading on my ebook readers (of which the Kindle DX is the latest). This gives me the most flexibility for reading these documents on the small screen, and I can highlight and annotate the Mobi formatted documents on my DX. It takes a couple of minutes per document, but it works very well for me.

Author: Diana Hayes
Comment: I have been so satisfied with Kindle 2 that I immediately went to a good many of the reviews to see why I should, (having '2' for only 4 months), look at the DX.  Color might have moved me in that direction due to blog reading and web links, but being unable to increase the print size on pdf files, unable to go to text to speech and most notably the inability to make notations convinced me to wait for yet another iteration of Kindle before trading in my beloved '2' for a new model.  The crisper text would be a plus, I'll agree, but was also put off a bit by the increase in weight and the weightier price!  Please work on a better e-mail program.  Would love to email those notations and clippings while reading!

Author: Edward Stockton
