Author: R. Morris
Comment: If you already have a PDF, you can transfer it directly to your Kindle by attaching it to a computer using the included USB cable. Windows and OS X (and presumably any other OS) should recognize the Kindle as a removable drive. Just copy any files to the 'documents' folder on the Kindle, and you will see them along side your books and other documents on the Kindle.  If the files aren't PDFs but they are files that Amazon can convert for you to Kindle-readable format via their e-mail service (e.g., Word .DOC files), send them to your Kindle address @free.kindle.com instead of @kindle.com. Then, after conversion, Amazon will e-mail a Kindle-readable file to you at your registered e-mail address that you can drag and drop to your Kindle's 'documents' folder as described above. If you don't use the free conversion (that is, if you send it to @kindle.com), it will automatically send it to your Kindle via Whispernet, but it will cost you a small fee, currently 15 cents per MB.  (Also, if Amazon can't convert them--or even if it can--you can use a free PDF converter such as Cute PDF Writer for Windows or the built-in PDF-saver in OS X to save any file you can print as a PDF, then transfer the created PDF to your Kindle via the USB connection.)  Hope this helps!

If it is not currently being read, it is in my purse waiting to go with me and I have never had a problem with it being damaged. I have dropped my Kindle in its case several times and it had no problems after. One time after being dropped, the corner of my Kindle did crack open.  The device still worked but I was worried the crack would let in moisture so I called customer support to ask if there was somewhere I could take it to be repaired, on my dime.  I was told that they would replace my Kindle for free, even though the damage was completely my fault, and I recieved a brand new Kindle in the mail the very next day. I didnt even pay shipping to return the broken one.  I thought Amazon had amazing customer service, well above and beyond what I expected.

Author: Johnny Woo

It usually acquires a good signal in 1 to 2 minutes.  Maybe you happen to live in a particularly bad area for satellite coverage.  Also, if you stand in one place, rather than begin running, the satellites will be acquired quicker.  Again, I only wait about 1 minute and then I'm able to run.  I think you should give this another try - particularly since it isn't too cheap!

Oh, and the screen may be more difficult to see if you are wearing polarized sunglasses.  I have never had a visibility problem and I run in ALL conditions, 10__F (WC >0__), rainy, 80__+F, sunny, cloudy.  Never an issue. However, I did learn that you can move to another screen before it acquires the satellites.  So I can at least start the timer.  It is true that my polarized sunglasses make it difficult to read.  When I remove my sunglasses, I have no difficulty reading the screen in most conditions.  Operator error.  It is still frustraitingly slow acquiring satellites when first booting it up.  I usually lose the first quarter mile or so on my runs.  I still start the timer when I start running and just adjust mentally as I know the distance of my usual runs.    I have grown to love the ability to download my workouts.  It's kind of like getting a receipt for working out.  I have also captured some epic runs and climbs and the ability to map with Google Earth is very cool.  I wore it on a climb of Longs Peak summer before last and it was really fun to be able to see the satellite image of the climb.  As for selling it - I appreciate the offer.  I don't imagine that it would bring more than a few bucks, and for that, I'll just hang on to it.  While it is frustrating that it takes forever to acquire the satellites, I have found a comfortable peace with it and I do use it regularly.

Author: ~Z~
Comment: Thanks Matthew for the kind words.  I use Yahoo messenger.  From the camera menu I can launch Yahoo Messenger or Windows Live Messenger. There is also an option to add more apps.  You can choose to add Logitech VID, Skype, Gmail Voice and Chat.   With Yahoo messenger I had to go through the the steps of setting up a video call (microphone and camera test).  Once I was done with those steps it was up and working.  In comparison with with Logitech Quickcam Pro the picture was more true to colors and a lot clearer.  It is not as "crisp" as the resolution when I took recorded the video, but I can't complain - the resolution is pretty good, much better than the than what I was using before.  The sound is crystal clear.  During video chats it sometimes becomes jerky and slow moving but I believe that has to do with my network and how many PCs/Games/etc are connected at the same time.  I am using a wireless Broadband signal.

Author: Sheep To Be Shorn
Comment: I'm curious about the magical 5 megapixel sensor.  How is it that it can suddenly create 10 megapix images?  How can it produce 1080p video which contains 6.22 megapixels per frame?  Seems like magic!  Or interpolation.  Why stop at 10 megapix? Why not advertise 1000 megapixel images?  It's all the same math, and contains no new information either way.  It's all in the extra bloatware that must be loaded on to your system to make the "magic" happen because it's certainly not in the hardware. Cell phones have the same or bigger image sensors these days.  And when describing your antique digital camera, the word you're looking for is "resolution."

Comment: Amanda - I was not sure about your question and searched the owner's manual for an answer since I really do not use the "Motion Sensor Detector" feature.    This is what is listed: *Setup your webcam to record video when it detects movement. *Adjust captured video duration and detection sensibility. *Captured video is automatically saved to your computer. *View content in Gallery or upload it using the One-Touch Upload window.   The One-Touch Upload is used for Facebook and Youtube.  After reading the above I would assume that live streaming for the motion sensor is not an option, but I could be wrong.  You may want to email that question to Logitech or call them directly.  Hope this helps.  :-)

Frankly, if the autofocus on the 910 works and I can adjust the exposure settings with iGlasses (have you tried that?) I should be good to go. That's pretty much how the iSight worked for me, but now I should have a clearer and sharper image for all my admirers (Ha!).

Author: Qrysta White
Comment: Thank YOU!  I'll have to go grab iGlasses right now to see what that is.  There doesn't seem to be much of a need to do anything to the exposure except I'd say if you have a bright light on one side of your head (and little light on the other side of your noggin') it would be nice to balance that a bit.  My guess though is it takes moving the light source to alleviate the problem vs changing any exposure setting but I'll certainly go see what iGlasses can do.  The one complaint I do see about this camera is that it doesn't have a real clip.  Heaven knows what Logitech was thinking by omitting a good gripping mechanism.  So some with laptops say the thing slides off  too easily and when it comes to lenses they don't take to being dropped too well.  I'm using it on a desktop so it sits pretty without issue.  I think if I had a laptop, I'd just wad up some good tape on its bottom side and keep on trucking.

Author: Qrysta White
Comment: Me AGAIN,  I grabbed iGlasses.    It does work with this webcam but I think you're better off without it.  There wasn't one setting that made the image better than it was without it.  I do like the mirror image function and the zoom+pan.  Took me a second there to swish hard enough to get the image to pan.  Not worth buying if you have not bought iGlasses and I don't think anyone would bother to use it even if they do own the software already.  I deinstalled it and my image is still not back to being as good as it was.  Hopefully upon restart it'll be fine once again.  A natural appealing bright brilliant image is now too darned dark.  Upon Restsart YEP all is Well.  If iGlasses let us disable its image exposure controls while giving me just pan and zoom I'd be delighted.  I suppose its STANDARD setting is supposed to do just that but it doesn't.  Make a video without it and one with and see how it darkens the heck out of the image.  Seems the video industry thinks just making something black-er is better.  Mac has done with this Snow Leopard.  It is an eye straining horror.  Don't do the same to this nice little webcam.

Author: Qrysta White
Comment: Hello LongArm and Joakimsen.  First let me apologize.  I didn't know I had a Q waiting 6 wks.  Lousy Email.  Any usb webcam that works on a Mac is using usb 2.0 high speed technology and Apple's pretty vanilla UVC - USB Video software.  That software isn't up to date enough give us macites fancy video tools yet.  That's why simple shooting is all we can do.  It is not the camera's fault.  Given that, any webcam software that runs on the apple platform can use the camera you attach.  So if the camera works with one software it works with the rest as they all depend upon UVC.  It works just fine with Skype (which was probably its main app focus), iChat, Photo Booth and new beta Facetime.  My newer and perhaps better review might explain things better.  http://www.viewpoints.com/Logitech-HD-Pro-Webcam-C910-with-1080p-Video-review-65eb7

Comment: Considering purchasing this for my husband, but I have a couple questions:  1.  Do you have to have a Mac to make this work?  I have a Mac, but he's a PC guy. 2. This may be a gift for him, but it is actually for the whole family to use... :)  Thank you for your help.

Author: A. Hall
Comment: The Apple TV is for Mac and/or PC. You need iTunes installed on your PC and an iTunes account for the Apple TV to work seamlessly on your PC.  2. Yes. You can use multiple iTunes accounts, but not at the same time. You will have to sign-in and out of separate iTunes accounts to access your iTunes Libraries. You will also need to Turn on Home Sharing inside iTunes preferences.  3. HDMi is the only way you can connect this new Apple TV to your HDTV unless you somehow find an HDMI to component cable or adapter. If you have a DVI port on the back of your HDTV you can use an HDMI to DVI cable. DVI = Digital Video Interface that outputs HD video without audio. You will also need to use the optical audio port to connect the Apple TV to your home theater receiver to get sound for the HDMI to DVI connection.  I hope this information helps.

Author: D. Barnes
Comment: Your CON about Home Sharing is completely wrong.  You need to use one iTunes account to set up Home Sharing on each computer but that is only for authorization purposes.  Each person still has access to their own iTunes account on their computer and the Apple TV will show each person's own iTunes library with their own media.  Yes, you can have multiple different iTunes libraries owned by different people showing up on the new Apple TV.    Also, most people report that everything "loads" extremely fast and the caching is very well done for videos, artwork, photos, and icons.  I believe the difference is you only have a slow 1.5mbps DSL connection when the average in the U.S. is over 5mbps.  So your connection is well below average but people see your review and might not realize that.  You might want to update your post to not lead people wrongly and give them the wrong idea about this device.

Author: Santiago M. Taveras

Author: Bonds
Comment: A Pro should be streaming from local computer outta the box.  It's something Roku isn't set up to do.    You can stream movies, tv shows, podcasts, music and photos out of the box.  Makes a great digital picture frame actually.  You put music to slideshows and choose from a handful of effects.  Netflix has search which not many implementations have.  Also has actor/director movie cross-referencing (hit the "more" button on a Netflix movie listing.)  My Netflix cover art did take awhile to cache at least once.  Forget if it occurs everytime.  1080p not much of a con when 1080p content  is only found on BR discs and ripped BR discs take up way too many GBs.  A bit ironic it's a con given the reviewer has a 1.5mbps internet connection.  :)  btw, Netflix HD isn't any better than DVD quality really.    Local networks could handle 1080p files better than most internet connections, but still too many wireless networks would sputter and cough when streaming those files (imagine if 2 in the house streamed 1080p?  Not good.)  Plus it would take even longer to cache a 1080p movie which ironically is another con by the reviewer.  The reviewer wants shorter load times, but also wants higher resolution content that would give him longer load times.   Make up your mind.  Besides what really matters is bit rate.  It's a better indicator of picture quality than resolution is.  And let me say no complaints here about picture quality.  Content on ATV looks great!  Haven't experienced the loading screens.  Author wasn't very specific where he saw them.  Netflix is always going to have brief loading screens when accessing the service in a few spots.  I will say Netflix loads too much.  Select a movie to view its description and then go back to your instant queue and you see a loading screen.  The ATV should cache your Netflix instant queue when accessing it, but that doesn't appear the to be the case right now.  Loading screens have been brief to non-existent when streaming media from my computer.  No lag here either on my wireless network.   Probably a fault of the reviewer's network.  Netflix has its own rating system.  I've used 4 implementations of Netflix and none have had Rotten Tomatoes ratings.  And I would say ATV's is the top implementation among the 4 I've used.  Wii has a nice interface, but can only play SD and needs a disc.  360's doesn't have search so far and controls are a bit clumsy with controller.  360 also requires the 360 to be on which is power inefficient and loud and it takes awhile from boot-up to get into the Netflix screen.  No app support is a con?  Not sure how that's a con when no else does apps on their tv device.   The ATV certainly isn't missing a killer app.  Sure there is some potential there, but wake me up when it is realized.  ATV does plenty now.  And I'm sure Apple will update it even if it doesn't become a full-blown app store.  Also Pandora should be under no app support not listed as another con.  I guess it helps pad your con list though.  IR sensor works fine.    The ATV is so small that the line of sight to the sensor can be cut off if you're not paying attention to its placement.  My cons would be no volume on the remote.  I would kill for that.  I rather like the tiny slick aluminum remote, and so it sucks having to keep the beastly tv remote next to me to change volume.  And with today's movies and a wife and kids I have to constantly change volume.  Whispers are too soft and special effects are too loud.  The other con is its a new 1st-gen product type of conduct.  There are a few bugs in the initial release.  No show stoppers given their rare occurence in my experience so far.  But I have had a hiccup with streaming where it doesn't see my computer even though it's on and iTunes is open.      No local storage isn't a con.  First, with the local streaming, there is little to no need to have local storage.  Local streaming is quite responsive.  And with easily installed wired networking technologies out there  like PowerLine and MOCA it only gets better.  Second, local storage would be a hassle with multiple tvs and atvs.  3rd, according to Apple not many want to manage the storage of their own tv shows and movies.  Hence the new ATV is a cheaper streaming model.

Author: Robert Latter
Comment: I think most of the cons can be overcome using an iPhone, iPad or iPod Touch.   *It is not 160G, but you can get up to 64G on iPad *Uses WiFi. No IR required. And you can use the device for text entry rather than the remote. *Can use the Netflix App; no problem with artwork icons *Use the Pandora App to stream Pandora *250K Apps available *Use the Flixster App for Rotten Tomatoes *Remote not needed *Can use two devices to sync to two different accounts  Not perfect, but there is a solution for almost every objection, and the iPod Touch is not very expensive.

Author: Tracy Newhouse
Comment: The average DSL speed in the US is approx 3 Mbs, not 5. And if you have ATT and they are having a bad day, it can be as slow as 1.5Mbs.   Most streaming devices should not be run at less than 3Mbs, so go to a DSL speed test site like dslreports.com and check your speed before attempting to either stream content. As for streaming from a Home Library your connectivity will be affected not only by the speed of your connection, but the location of your router and the location of your computer in relation to your router. Also, don't let your computer go into sleep mode while streaming. i.e, home streaming is useful and neat - when it doesn't suck.  Personally, since Apple keeps tabs on everything you have EVER purchased, they should have a list of your purchased content and allow you to stream it for free without having to have your computer on. But then, I think logically...

It crept up with me slowly overtime and I ran a speed test that was equal to dial-up!! I then remembered that the first thing tech support tells you to do is reset the modem.

Author: Netizen
Comment: Jailbreaking is a pain at the time of this writing, with only a tethered jailbreak possible, but once done, Grooveshark is available. With Ooradio app you can stream your favorite radio stations to the ATV 2g easily. Also, with Plex you can stream different video formats directly from your network (Mac or NAS) without the painful step of converting to an iTunes-friendly format. This saves having two copies of any given video taking up space on your network/local HD and also saves time as ripping one DVD generally takes over an hour of intensive CPU activity. If you do need to rip (i.e. not ready to jailbreak) try HandBrake. TubeTV is also useful for rendering video into usable format for iTunes.

Author: Netizen
Comment: If you have an 802.11n network, you can stream video from your MBP or from your NAS as long as you've stored it in your iTunes library. If you jailbreak, you can use Plex to gain access to a wider variety of formats, but, be warned. Jailbreaking right now is a PITA. Can be done, but, whew! (Hint: You'll need a USB A to micro cable. Micro is the smallest, flattest plug and it will go into the ATV2's usb connection above the HDMI connection. For further details, Google "Season Pass download.")  :o)

Author: Netizen
Comment: Hmmm. Odd, indeed. I'm on broadband wireless with 3Mbs and have no trouble whatsoever with Netflix. I had trouble with iTunes videos in the beginning-- absolutely could not watch them. Two things. 1. Don't try to stream HD if your connection is only 3 Mbps (Go to settings to change the default HD preference.) But still had trouble, so (2) contacted Apple. They were immediately responsive and asked the name of my ISP. I told them. I don't know what then transpired, but within 24 hours the problem was gone. Now I can stream either without much problem. I will say that if the network is experiencing heavy traffic-- like at 6 pm on Saturday-- things go more slowly. The issue really does seem to be bandwidth here. 10 MBps should be more than enough, but is it a steady 10 MBps? Also, on 2.4 Ghz other radio activity can be an issue if you live in a densely populated area. Microwave, bluetooth, many mobile handsets, etc. can interfere with the signal from your router to your ATV.  :o)

Author: Netizen
Comment: Watch for an untethered jailbreak. Right now it's somewhat cumbersome, but there are a couple of apps in beta out there-- Plex, XBMC, Groovy, etc. Hopefully some others will appear over time.

Author: TomK1
Comment: Yes, I didn't really see a distinction between the two, but I want to rephrase the question.  Does 256MB refer to the process execution space as compared with the 8/32/64GB of permanent storage?

Author: Ross
Comment: yes 256mb of runtime memory (execution space as you put it).  the iPhone 4 has 512mb.  RAM stands for random access memory.  the 32gb is flash memory in this case and that is the amount of storage space you have for songs, movies, apps, etc...

Author: TomK1
Comment: Define "useless".  An ipod touch is... an iPod with the ability to use applications, connect to the internet via WiFi hotspots and it has a camera.  Some applications require a constant connection, others do not, they are stand-alone.  Games are primarily stand-alone.  An application that scans a bar-code and looks it up on the internet is clearly not stand-alone, you need an internet connection.  Your question about how to "get internet on the iPod Touch" is a little confusing.  Perhaps you don't realize that it only connects via WiFi like a laptop computer?  It has no ability to use the Cellular/3G connections like the iPhone or certain iPads.     To answer you very literally, it costs nothing to get internet on the iPod Touch.  However, it has to be at a location that has WiFi (like a starbucks, at home, at a barnes & noble etc.).   You can't expect to have it anywhere you go.

Author: ThomShap
Comment: See Tom1's reply.  You have to be in a place where there is wifi - bookstore, your place of employment, maybe, McDonald's.  There is free wireless all over the place.  If you want more portability and usability, get a wifi card (like Verizon's MiFi) which will allow you to use a cell phone company's 3G network to get internet access when you are not in an area with free wifi.  Monthly service fees are MUCH cheaper than data plans for smart phone service.  For example, I have a wireless router at home so my whole family has access to the internet in my house.  I also have wireless at the school where I teach.  Most places you might shop (malls, Borders bookstores) have a wifi area and so do a lot of restaurants.  Most of the time, I can get the internet for free.  When I am driving somewhere, and I want to use the map function or make a restaurant reservation, I am out of luck, so I actually did get a MiFi card (a little bigger than a credit card) and for 35 bucks a month, I have wireless access anywhere.  For a LOT less than an iPhone.

Author: F. Lai
Comment: Yes, I agree it is better than the previous generation. However, this camera feature was long rumored after 2nd generation ipod touch. Not to mention that the 3rd generation 8gb Ipod touch is basically a rebadged 2nd generation Ipod Touch. Last year's model was a huge disappointment. Therefore, this year, people expected the ipod touch to be a lot better than the previous generation, including a better resolution camera. People expected an ipod touch with a camera in the last generation ipod touch. After being hyped up for so long, people are disappointed that this ipod touch was not a remarkable upgrade, considering that it took Apple two years to develop a camera that had a terrible resolution. I also expected a memory increase, considering the high price, but it did not happen. I think that was why people were disappointed. Apple always touted its products as magical and revolutionary. The ipod nano was worse than the previous generation in the fact that it got rid of video and the camera.  Also, Apple touts this as an awesome camera, which led people to believe that this ipod has a good enough camera to take nice pictures when clearly, it isn't good enough for stills compared to my cell phone. Apple cleverly makes its products sound really awesome, and lures poor unsuspecting people to believe something when it isn't. Steve Jobs during the event praised the camera of the ipod touch, saying it is good to take stills and videos.  I also don't believe ATT pays apple for the full price difference of the iPhone (400 dollar difference) since they subsidize the phone. It is about how much consumers pay and what they get, not what happens behind the scenes between Apple and ATT. Therefore, the consumer technically only spent 200-300 on the iPhone and pays for the data plan.  @ Jen: What about using your cell phone with a better resolution camera? That would probably be a better alternative than your ipod touch, since people always almost remember carrying their phone rather than their ipod touch.  Unfortunately nowadays, Apple has made the decision for the consumer what he/she wants. I am very appalled at Apple for being the only company where consumers would forgive even with their mishaps (iPhone 4 reception). People have been giving Apple too much slack.  Another example is the 13 inch macbook pro. I am utterly disgusted how they still only feature Core 2 Duo processors even though their computers cost 1300 dollars. I could get the Core i7 processor laptop for less than 900 dollars with better specs.  EDIT: I also believe that Apple puts design over hardware/function (look at the iPhone 4 antenna issue, macbook pro 13 inch, the new Apple TV (does not support 1080p when the previous generation did)). I think they are the only company to do that, most other manufacturers prefer hardware/function over design. (Look at Zune HD's Nvidia Tegra, Motorola Droids, etc) I guess it depends on the public, but it seems to me that people prefer design over functionality. Apple has decided to merge almost all their products using their A4 processor (to cut costs, make more profit of their own processor design, but willing to sacrifice some features that were important before). Even with Apple's backwards generation hardware capability, how much do you wanna bet that people still will flock to Apple? As long as Apple keeps everything pretty and small, people will buy it. It feels like Apple is going back into the early 2000's with their G4/G5 processors featured on every computer whereas Intel provided the much superior chip. They seem to be redoing what they did back in the 1990's when they were failing.  I think the consumer needs to be well informed of everything and to take anything what Steve Jobs says with a grain of salt.

Author: T. Jackman
Comment: What "rights" do I have as a consumer exactly?  The only right I can think applies here is the right to get a product that matches what was advertised.  Apple does not even mention (except in fine print) that rear lens can even take photos.  This is being put out as an HD video solution.  If you don't like it, then you can exercise your "right" not to buy it.  "I would be grateful if the new iPod touch was free."  - Yeah and I would be grateful if it did my dishes, cooked me dinner, and Apple paid me to pick one up.  Perhaps my use of the term "grateful" was not the best choice.  What I meant to imply was that this is a lot of device for the money if you think about it.  Yes, I wish it had a better sensor, but considering the realities of cost and the physical constraints of the ultra slim case (as I pointed out in my review) and you start to realize that this is a pretty amazing little gadget.  Show me another $229/$299 device that has the functionality and feature set of the latest iPod Touch and I will concede that you have any kind of point.

Author: T. Jackman
Comment: Also, Apple touts this as an awesome VIDEO camera - corrected.  Nowhere on Apple's product page or commercial does Apple present this as a device intended to take photos.  The only way you find out about it is if you look at the detailed specification sheet.  This is being sold as a device that can do video calling or shoot HD video.

Author: F. Lai
Comment: Yeah, this is the reason why Americans put themselves into debt. On TV, all you see is debt settlement commercials and ways to get yourself out of massive amounts of credit card debts. I'm not saying Apple products are crappy, just that they are overpriced. I am not trolling either, just speaking my opinions on a particular product and the ethics of a particular company. I have nothing against Apple, but what I am against is that people are being misled into buying products that cost significantly a lot thinking that they work a million times better. You have no idea how many people have become Apple drones. I just want people to open their eyes to see that there may be other alternatives besides what Apple has to offer for a cheaper price.  For example, a Zune HD 32GB only costs 216 dollars right now (84 bucks cheaper), and can do almost everything an Ipod Touch can, (with the exception of a large selection of apps, but you have to pay for those apps, and has no camera). It also includes HD Radio, OLED screen, Xvid/DivX support, Nvida Tegra for HD output, etc...Keep in mind that this Zune HD was built to compete against the third generation Ipod Touch. How much of the population have even heard of the Zune HD?  I'm not trolling, I also own an Ipod Touch 16gb 2nd Generation for free which I think works very well, like you. Author: wq
Comment: For all the people out there that are complaining...I work in the electronics department of a retail store and am not allowed to favour one product brand over another.  From what I have been reading and seeing of this product, people will probably flock by the dozens to get this new product, and there may be others who even protest against it. With all of the new specks that apple has put into this product I believe that it is worth the extra money, but there are many people out there that don't care much about the detailed specks because they don't understand them.  The majority of consumers know what they want in a device and they will most likely have to sacrifice one feature for another. They generally don't know what the difference between LCD, LED, or OLED screens. I answer questions about them on a daily basis along with what hz means and ratio means. A lot of people just don't know and don't really care what is inside the device as long as it works the way they want it to.  These type of people just want the best features (that they can see/use) for the price they pay. They don't care much about the internal stuff because of their lack of understanding. They really only care if it works and it's the way they want it to work.  I have a lot of people that come into the store wanting an MP3 player (of any brand) and generally decide on an iPod because of the features it has. In the past year I have had more people get the iPod Nano and iPod Touch than any other type of MP3 player (including the generic MP3 players) because of all the features they have. I high selling point on the Nano was actually the camera and the FM radio.  I don't generally do these posts, but it surely sounded to me like almost everyone here is either spoiled rotten by getting what they want all the time and have a choice to get a new music player whenever they want or they just dislike Apple because of a bad experience or the cost of a product that they ended up not liking. (I'm sorry if I offended anyone.)  I am neither against nor for Apple devices in general, but I do find that the iPod devices are more user friendly for Windows, Mac, or any other computer operating systems and their users. They are easy to update but at the same time, if you purchase a song in iTunes, it is very hard to get it to transfer to another programme such as Windows Media Player and others.  Feel free to comment, I just wanted to share my opinion with everyone that whatever the device may have, people will refuse to buy the product or they will go straight for it. We have the right to express our opinions and buy whatever we can afford. There is no law saying that we cannot exercise our right buy what we want. People do that everyday.

Author: MWebb
Comment: Anandtech has a detailed technical review-  www anandtech dot com - and apparently the iPhone is the "gold standard" in terms of materials and implementation - the iPhone screen has a much greater brightness range and a much greater viewing angle, also a much wider viewing angle due to some trick technology in the screen. And of course the iPhone has a much better rear camera, not only capable of much higher resolution for still photography but also capable of autofocus and flash. The built in speaker is capable of 90 db, the Touch can only make it to 78 db. Finally the iPod touch has 1/2 the RAM of the iPhone (256 vs 512).  So the iPod Touch is "NOT" an iPhone without the phone.  On the other hand, the iPod Touch is MUCH less expensive than the iPhone (about half the price!), is MUCH thinner and somewhat shorter, and includes most of the feature set - of particular interest to me is the now BUILT-IN microphone, the "Face Time" (or Skype video conference) front camera, the rear video camera, the same processor (A4) as the iPad, iPhone, the SAME RESOLUTION as the iPad, the SAME RAM as the iPad (yes the iPad also has 256mb RAM!). And the same improved motion detector.  The resolution is really important, because now it can run ALL THE iPAD apps! That's huge! Download and play video in MUCH better resolution. Netflix stream to it. You can download and view the same video content as the iPad.  What about the lower contrast and lesser viewing angle?  Anandtech is undoubtedly correct in their measurements, and correct in giving the nod to the iPhone in side by side comparison. BUT they say the Asus netbook I own has much better contrast than the HP I also own, and quite frankly as an average viewer there is no noticeable difference. Better is always better, but with my budget constraints I am happy to have the Touch.  So which models to buy? My music collection is 5 gb, with some instructional videos downloaded that's another 3 gb, so right there I can tell I need a at least the 32 gb model, and the 32 gb model would allow me to haul around the UNCOMPRESSED music collection AND still have room left for some videos to go.  There is only a $60 difference between the 8 gb and the 32 gb.  HOWEVER what I mostly use my Touch for is Skype, NY Times stories, USA Today stories, accessing Fidelity Brokerage, web browsing, email checking, Facebook checking. And reading an Amazon book via the Kindle app (I prefer Kindle app to the new Apple app because I can have two Apple accounts but view the book on my old or new Touch - when it arrives - but with Apple I can't log in under two accounts - Amazon will let me download to different devices). These apps and the associated content take very, very little space compared to music and videos. So it looks like I could also get away with an 8 gb Touch if I wanted to - if I selectively downloaded only a few play lists and videos. Thus the 8gb appeals to the minimalist in me. Compared to the last generation, you don't get shafted with a slower processor, and the 8 gb therefore has some potential for gaming, if you play limited numbers of games.  It is hard to justify the 64 gb version. $399 adds up. Although the cost of SSD memory is still expensive.  But I imagine in 2 years these things will be minimum 16gb, 32 gb, and 128 gb.

Author: J. Austin
Comment: Timothy, I agree. Not sure what Apple was thinking with such a low res camera. Especially given how nice the other features are.  According to some Apple insiders, the original design was to make the iPod Touch a little bigger, the same form factor as the iPhone, with a rectangular bottom made out of the same material as the Macbook Pro (scratch resistant).  That would have given them plenty of room to incorporate a 5MP camera and other features. They opted instead to make it smaller and lighter (and very easy to slip out of your hand according to one review I saw) with a thin aluminum backing that is very prone to scratches. It is possible that being so thin at the top limited the type of sensor they could use ... or maybe it was just to prevent any impact to their very profitable iPhone sales.   Too bad we can't just get an unlocked iPhone 4 for a reasonable price to use as an iPod/camera and use it with another carrier or even a pre-paid plan versus getting stuck with an expensive AT&T contract.  If you read the comments on cnet.com, you'll find that people there are also very turned off by what apple did w/ the camera in this version.

Author: Dusty Kothenbeutel
Comment: The front facing camera captures 640x480, as it is intended solely for videoconferencing use. The rear-facing camera captures 960x720, which can legally be called 720p HD because it only refers to the horizontal resolution, not the width. The video & photos captured by the iPod Touch will only be 960 pixels wide, which is a standard 4:3 aspect ratio, not a "widescreen" image. Just because video is HD doesn't automatically require it to be any specific aspect ratio. HD is definied by horizontal lines of resolution; HD videos are available in aspect ratios ranging from 4:3 to 16:9 to 21:7 and beyond. There is no singular standard, only a "most common" that people may be used to just from seeing it frequently. For example, many TV shows available on Blu-Ray are in HD despite the fact that they were not originally created in widescreen ratio, so you still get black bars at the left & right sides, even though the video is indeed at HD resolution and looking much better for it.

Author: James Greer

That appears to not be the case and consumers have a right to know that.  If you owned a 3rd generation ipod touch and were about to spend $230 - $400 to upgrade because you thought you'd be able to take quality pictures with this thing then this information is very helpful.  It may cause you to rethink your decision to upgrade.  I will still most likely upgrade because it is still a far superior device than the last generation ipod touch, but at least the review helped me make an informed decision.  That is what reviews are all about.

Author: Chase S.
Comment: Now that it has been established that Apple did indeed note the picture resolution on the product's spec sheet, is it truely right to say that the device doesn't perform "as advertised"?  While they didn't expressly mention it, this wasn't a hidden flaw, and shouldn't treated like one.  Since this is not a feature that Apple hid from their customers, and you have no way of actually testing the camera quality given that the product isn't out yet, it's not right to give a low score for a single feature that has not been proven to actually malfunction or fall below specifications in any way.

Author: Quan Masiello
Comment: Read this from Apple's discussion page at apple.com  http://discussions.apple.com/thread.jspa?threadID=2564264&tstart=0 -----------       Giant Apple 1  Posts: 1 From: Midwest Registered: Sep 2, 2010   New!  Re: NEW iPOD Touch Released 2Day, Problem with Statement Made??? . . . Posted: Sep 2, 2010 11:29 AM   in response to: ScottG         Click to reply to this topic  Reply  email  Email  hey forum members, my 1st post!  to begin with, thank you for calling my attention to this question around the outward-facing camera on the new iPOD Touch. the current Apple spec sheet at this time does indeed appear CONFUSING with regard to photo quality, and upon reflection, I decided it must be misstated/misleading.  so, i just spent about 30 minutes with the Apple Tech support for iPODS/Touch, and after they checked at length with several experts at their end, they were able to ASSURE ME that the OUTWARD-FACING camera is indeed a 5MP sensor! YEAH!  what i think is happening is that someone in charge of mktg communications (incl spec sheets) is confusing the two cameras on the Touch, and also confusing video vs photo/still resolutions.  eg, the reference to "VGA quality" is terminology usually applied to video quality. in this case, i believe it is meant to describe only the video quality of the forward-facing camera. This camera is used by Facetime, which is bandwidth-limited to operate only over wi-fi at this time - not a 3G connection. I believe Facetime can only process VGA quality (correct me if that is wrong).  on the other hand, the outward-facing camera claims "720p-HD video." and what i struggled with here is how a sensor that is capable of HD video can only capture a 1MP photo, as some have suggested here. that just does not seem consistent to me.  now overlay that with the new iOS version announced yesterday which builds in the HDR feature - an image capture and algorithm technique intended to boost image quality. this feature suggests a dedication to image quality, which would be at odds with supplying only a 1MP sensor for the outward-facing camera! a cheap sensor would produce horrible results, and undermine Apple's messaging around the Touch's first-rate image quality (eg, HD video, retina display, etc).  therefore, I am convinced that the Apple techs are correct in assuring me that this is a 5MP sensor (outward-facing camera).  Lastly, i encouraged the techs to ask their contacts in the mktg communications dept to rewrite the specs sheet on video/photo resolutions, clearly distinguishing between the outward-facing and inward-facing cameras.  hope this helps everyone! ---------------------------------------

Author: J. Austin
Comment: Hello Quan, Thanks for contacting Apple. I notice in your website post follow-up that you contacted them again and found out that it is NOT a 5MP camera, but is a 0.7 MP camera as the specs say.  I had a similar situation with Apple. The first time I contacted them they assured me it was the same 5mp sensor, as Steve Jobs said, "An iPhone w/o a phone and contract".  The second person I talked to said the specs on the web are correct, it is a .7 MP camera and both the processor and lens are different than the one on the iPhone. And there is no flash so the user will need really good light to use it.  The original plan was to make it the same shape (rectangular) as the iPhone w/ a similar camera sensor. The back was to be made of scratch resistant aluminum like the MB Pro body. Somewhere along the way someone decided to go w/ the same, though slimmer and lighter, body as the 3rd generation and put a minimal camera in it.  My thoughts: Anyone who has used a digital camera in dark settings knows how poor (grainy, noisy) the images turn out. The HD video on the apple web site was shot in bright sunlight and the panning is so smooth and slow I have to think it was mounted on a tripod. I greatly suspect when people starting taking stills and video with this, they will be greatly disappointed.  Ironically, I would have better feelings towards apple if they had not put a camera in there at all versus putting a low quality camera in it and trying to spin the iPod as being the same as the iPhone w/o a phone. The other features make it (almost) worth the upgrade, but the way they are doing this has really turned me off to them.   The sales rep said most of the calls they are getting are about this very issue. Lots of people changing their mind and not placing orders or canceling their existing orders. Not exactly what Apple needs heading into the Holiday season during bad economic times.

Author: Robert Fong
Comment: I think that this is a very valid review because it provides some insight on something that would be a determining factor on whether or not to purchase this item - especially if the camera is an important feature for a prospective buyer. Some, like me, may opt to wait for a better version.   Also, please learn to read between the lines, the reviewer didn't go and say "Don't Buy it," He merely reported another site's summarized review of the camera - His 3 Star Review is Spot On, just a neutral sharing of information; the fact that 70% of the people that read his review found it helpful should tell you something, shouldn't it?

Author: Donald C. Allen

Author: J. Donaldson
Comment: Nice review. Thanks. I have the 3G model and intend to buy the 4G. I'll post my review when I have it in hand but really it is just an upgrade and much of the value is in the apps so I think it is reasonable to comment on the new features without having one yet. You did a good job.  Having a rear facing camera is good but as I choose NOT to buy an iPhone, due to the forced data plan, I also carry a phone with a decent camera so the Touch camera isn't a big deal to me. I've had video capability for a few years but don't use it much so that isn't a big focus for me either.  What I'm looking forward to is the built in microphone. I have a couple of external microphones but having one built in will simplify my needs. I'm glad the 4G has one. With that I can use Skype, and Dragon to have Speech to Text entry to also.  Another thing I'm looking forward to is the faster processor and longer battery life.  Thickness isn't that big a deal. I have a snap on case that makes my 3g thicker. If Apple wanted to make it smaller in my pocket I wish they would have a different finish on the back that didn't take on fingerprints and wasn't smooth. If they changed the back I wouldn't have to buy a case and it would be thinner!  The forward facing camera is interesting if Skype would be able to use it so I can call people that have video capability on their PC or Mac. I don't know many people I'd want to video chat that have an Apple handheld and are on WiFi.  Perhaps I'll like the retina display but frankly the 3G display is so good I'm not seeking a better display.  Sept 6 added comment. I've decided not to purchase at this time. The new features would be nice but not worth the cost of the upgrade to me. What I will wait for is Skype video to work on the iPod Touch before I upgrade.

Author: Filippo Neri
Comment: When discussing "MP3" players, the subject of sound quality is often overlooked. This is a disgrace, because the primary function of a player is to play music. I have done listening tests comparing a gen 4 (photo) iPod to a gen 2 iPod touch. I did not use headphones, but a high-end stereo system.  The results have been shocking: the old iPod sounds incredibly better than the new one.  For the comparison I used classical recordings with low or no compression. I have to agree that the new iPod sound is inferior to the sound of some older models.  The "photo" iPod spends most of its time in the glove compartment of my BMW, where is used as a massive-capacity CD changer. The touch is mostly used as a PDA (including as a Kindle ebook reader,) so the sound quality issue is not crucial.  I was planning to get an iPod classic as a music listening device. The reason for choosing a classic is the availability of ALE. ALE (or Apple Lossless Encoding) allows to compress CDs without any loss of information. With ALE a 120 GB classic can store 400 CDs without any information loss: the digital stream is identical to the content of the CDs down to the last bit.  A perfect digital bitstream, however, will not help if the analog section of the classic is as bad as the analog section of the gen 2 touch. I want to thank to author of this post for his attention to sound-quality issues. They are of primary importance for me, too.  PS It is, of course, possible to use docks that extract the digital bitstream from an iPod and then route the digital signal to a high-quality Digital to Analog Converter (DAC.) This solution is very expensive and I don't see any advantage in using it rather than sending the digital output from, say, a Mac Mini directly to the DAC. With an external 1 GB HD a Mac Mini can store thousands of ALE-compressed CDs. The point of the iPod classic should be to get high quality music in a compact format: solutions using large docks are not acceptable.

I hate the sound of the Burr Browns that are now used in most AV receivers etc. They must have cut the cost and you find them in everything now. Those concerned should email Apple and let them know we are paying attention to the sound quality.

I have my cd's and files at home on my computer. Use your computer to make smart playlists. It's not apples job to consolidate your library for you. There are programs that do that outside of itunes and an ipod. I don't keep all my files on my computer because frankly, not everything in my library is worth listening to in lossless, not to mention I would need about 4 terabytes just to fit all my music uncompressed on my computer. You don't own one, it is a great product made for a specific (if limited) purpose.

Author: Richard Simpson
Comment: Yes martin, tech nerds and even other kinds of people realize that a portable media player, i.e. an ipod, was designed to play compressed files due to limitations of the hardware storage capacity.  I was pumped and still own my 3G 20GB iPod and now with 120 GB; that is a very respectable amount of storage IMO.  Eventhough I like apple's included earbuds, this is just the first in a longer list of factors (environmental noise, DA converters, codecs, your attention to your surroundings...) that degrade the music quality beyond being able to appreciate the difference between ALE and a properly encoded mp3 on your iPod.  Not to mention the incredible compression you can achieve for audio books ~25:1, and I would take the pepsi challenge with any audio file (probably not including yourself) to tell the difference between a properly encoded mp3 vs ALE vs the orignal .wav file on an iPod.    I'll take my ubiquitous lame 3.98 V2 mp3 encoded music files and V6 encoded audio books ripped with EAC any day over my old cassette tapes or your DRM protected .m4a files thank you very much.  And its Apple Lossless Encoder ALE not Apple Loss -> DA. And by the way you are now allowed to put Apples's lossless .m4a files on your iPod if you want to, but why would you? You can't hear the difference and with DRM you can't even share them with your friends. And why would you think downconverting a lossless file would be the best way to put music on your iPod?  Lossless is still compression (not arguing the quality, its very good) so now your going to "downconvert" one form of compression to another literally guaranteeing a worse final product (and I thought you were an audiophile with your apple loss...)  Put the Apple Pipe down, you don't even have to be a nerd to realize that "downconverting" is not the best way to go.  It soulds like you have probably chosen the wrong file format(s) to standardize on.  You may have chosen ALE or AIFF from a purist perspective which is admirable, but you have a file format that is not portable friendly.  And just because iTunes may not "downconvert" your music for you doesn't mean other software can't.  I don't believe I'm going to let Apple allow me to do something or not and neither should anyone else.  iPods are great and this "Classic" is a great improvement. Allowing yourself to be brainwashed by Apple - not so great.  P.S.  it's what's in the music that counts

Author: John E. Mcknight
Comment: Good review. I wanted to point out to you that your statement about the iPod will 'never be a replacement for killer home fi' may no longer be accurate. For the past 8 months or so, Wadia has given us the 170i Transport which overrides the digital output for the iPod for a vastly improved digital signal.  I don't know if you know much about Wadia, but this Transport for the iPod is probably the only hi-fi device of theirs that I could afford.  So the iPod classic is making its way in there.  Also for other comments here about iRivers & other products not making it to the starting line, well I've owned an iRiver for the past 6 years, but one thing I haven't seen with iRivers or the others are these great support accessories. Besides the Wadia, several aftermarket car stereos offer a good deal of iPod support, including tagging tracks to the iPod when listening to the radio for example, or running the iPod's output into the same DAC used by the car receiver's cd player.  My poor iRiver currently runs through the aux jack on a factory stereo & it just can't get the same kind of loudness that I could get from the iPod classic.  A thumb drive of music hooked to an aftermarket car receiver's usb jack can get a louder sound than my iRiver.  The iRiver, at least my generation needs to have its drive mounted & closed properly when hooked into USB on the PC, so I wouldn't trust to hook it into a car stereo receiver.  The bottom line is that it seems the iPod has really taken off & I'm ready to make the switch.  My iRiver will remain as a backup player for as long as continues to function.

Author: Barrett Benton
Comment: John: Thanks for cluing me in on the Wadia transport...I've been largely out of the high-end audio loop for a while, and this is truly good news for those of us who *know* the difference between formats, but find the utter convenience of the iPod too alluring to ignore. That's the kind of "convergence" I can get behind. :-)

Author: I. Gross Georg
Comment: It's exactly for those of us who relish high fidelity as well as no longer feel the need to own and store media. Get caught in a fire, hurricane, or tornado and you'll see what I mean. iPod Classic is just the ticket. Instead of hundreds of heavy LPs and cumbersome CDs, just call 911, grab the iPod, and go. Furthermore, just because YOU may not hear the difference on cheap grade headphones or audio equipment, doesn't mean there isn't one. Some people don't really care that much for fidelity, and there's nothing wrong with that. All they want is an electronic boombox where they're not listening to quality music in the first place. The rest of us are willing to pay the 1.30 for high-res music files and put them on a high capacity player like the iPod classic.

Author: Samuel Chell
Comment: I respect the POV and expertise of a committed audiophile (I once spent 500 just on a phonograph cartridge and know of someone who paid 4X as much), but buyers with that kind of discernment have never been Apple's market.  I don't even know of any downloading services that offer non-compressed files.  It's a trade-off--pristine fidelity (often measurable only by electronic instruments) vs. speed, storage, convenience, versatility, and expense.  And I can't say that I fault Apple for electing not to go after the comparatively small market for hi-end equipment and sound (though I'd agree that even if a "blindfold test" is inconclusive, quality itself remains an issue).  Unfortunately, most of the public is more easily impressed by thunderous sound and sweeping sonics coming from five different directions, whipping up their hair and massaging their feet, than by audio reproduction that's absolutely faithful to the source.

Author: Mark Blackburn
Comment: Terrific review! Not least for the informed response it elicited, and your additional thoughts (above)

Sure, a lot of boneheads buy iPods b/c they want to look cool at the gym, but who cares. I buy it for the quality and the best interface and performance of all the music players. But if I'm not officially Apple's market, I guess it doesn't matter much.  ;O)

Author: Samuel Chell

I think of most iPod users as content with ear buds or an Altec Lansing im600, but I have no doubt that it's capable of producing quality audio second to no other digital source (I see lots of claims on behalf of other players' superior sounds, which are nothing more than references to extra EQ settings or gadgetry). Personally, I'm still partial to optimally "tuned" and maintained analog equipment and well-made LPs.

Author: Matt
Comment: the difference between lossless (WAV, AIFF, FLAC, etc.) and lossy (MP3, AAC, etc.) depends on the encoding process. an mp3 at 320kbps is a solid representation of the source. i think if people participated in a double-blind test, i doubt most of them would be able to tell when the lossless source is playing versus the mp3 encoding. but if we compared a lossless source to an mp3 at 128kbps, more people would pick up on the differences, especially on better playback equipment. however, the listening environment also effects perception. if you listen to your ipod while jogging along the highway, the noise is going to cancel out a lot of the nuance and subtlety of the music and you will be much less likely to perceive a difference between mp3 @ 128 and it's lossless source. but if you listen to your ipod with high-end headphones in a quiet room, you'll hear all the nuance and subtlety and therefor will be more likely to perceive a difference between mp3 and it's lossless source.  a hard drive with over 100 GBs of space allows for the storage of lossless and high bit-rate encoded songs, which appeals to people who prefer (and listen in the right environment) higher quality files over lower quality encodes.

I am going on 8 minutes of syncing and I only added 3 cds.  It's this way every freaking time.  No wonder they discontinued the 160gb model.  I like how every post on here by people that are positive comments gets a positive click.  I however who probably am the only person that owns more than 20gb and has a real review on this product once it's maxed out gets a negative review. Since this is the only ipod with a decent amount of storage I have to buy it and will continue to use it, but I think people should know that once (for many of you it will take years) people get close to the 148gb this ipod allows, syncing it will be unbelievably slow.  That's the truth like it or not.  Also be warned that the more times you sync this thing your "other" storage will continue to grow.  I recently had to reset my other 160gb ipod (yes I own two) because it had grown to 7gb.  I am not sure why this is, but it has now happened to both.  Once again this is truth and I feel adds to the discussion.

Author: M. Clark
Comment: If your MP3 collection is tagged properly (specifically the "genre"), an ipod easily distinguishes them. So if you wanted to play your classical music, provided it's all classified as "classical", you could just select that genre. To play more than one genre (e.g. your "symphonic" music), you'd have to create playlists in iTunes first. You could create a playlist called symphonic, and add any or all of your music that falls into that category to the playlist.

Author: M. Clark
Comment: I used to rip 128kbps AAC (see below as to why), but the music sounded horrible. I find that a good balance between space usage and sound quality is 192kbps VBR (Variable Bit Rate). Most MP3s come out averaging between 200 and 230. The real key is using VBR, not CBR (Constant Bit Rate). I have a bunch of CBR files @320 that don't sound half as good as my VBR files @192. For anyone that may not know what VBR and CBR is, it's basically that VBR varies the amount of compression depending on the complexity of the data (music) so as not to lose too much of the sound stage. CBR is just what it says...constant. Same compression from start to finish, with no regard for how much or how little data is in any given part of the song. CBR should never be used for music files as far as I'm concerned. Btw, CNET also said that 128kbps AAC files sounded as good as the CD itself, so take their opinion for what it's worth.

Author: H. Tapia
Comment: RobS, I hate iTunes but only keep it installed on my PC for firmware updates and for properly setting up the chapter marks in my home-made mp3 books. (These "books" are actually recorded lectures.)  I use "Media Monkey" to maintain my music and sync with the iPod.  I have a rather involved process of ripping CDs which consists of using EAC in secure mode to create a flawless digital duplicate of the CD (takes nearly 4-5 min per CD...longer for CDs in bad condition) which are stored in a lossless format (WavPack, but you could easily use FLAC and probably be better off for it).  I then use these lossless "masters" to compress down to 192kbs VBR MP3s which I then load up via Media Monkey to the iPod.  The beauty of digital masters is that you can redo your entire MP3s as one big overnight batch process if you get an itch to try out a different compression setting or other tweak.  As for your last point, your vinyl 1977 recording did in fact sound as good as you remembered!  This isn't nearly as much the digital equipments fault as it is the mastering engineer's fault.  Look up "loudness war" to read about the trend over the years to make songs louder by compressing the dynamic range. (Wikipedia has a very nice graphic to illustrate the trend.) Modern recordings have almost no depth which is why you can't tell the difference between a CD and a 128kbs MP3.  It's not the equipment's fault...the recordings are fatally flawed.  Very sad.

Author: RobS
Comment: When I get the itch, I'll keep what you said about ripping in mind (if I can figure it out, LOL!). I need a new computer first. This one is a 933MHz PIII and quite slow for ripping en mass.  I understand a lot of the earlier CD catalogs were mastered rather poorly (some of my early CDs sound like crap), but  how about of the new "remastered" versions? When I buy new CDs, I try and make sure they are the most recent mastering, and if possible, I buy the SACD version (I've never A/Bd them to see if they are THAT much better).  I usually listen to my iPod through $25 earbuds, and gave my old Sony MDR-V2 headphones a listen to the old ELO Out of the Blue album, which was engineered pretty good back in "77. It did sound better (duh), though not AS good as I remember. Maybe I need to upgrade to the MDR-V6s.

Author: H. Tapia
Comment: RobS,  I think the problem with earlier CDs was that they were too quiet at times even tho they were applying the same technique they used for vinyl recording.  From what I gather, each remastering produces a louder product with lower dynamics.  Given that, I avoid re-released, remastered CDs (unless it includes some new must-have material) and go after earlier releases and just fix the volume issue when i compress down to MP3.  Go to the Wikipedia entry for "loudness war" and then click the link for reference #33 at the bottom.  That will take you to a great article written by a recording engineer about Rush's "Vapor Trails" album and how it got butchered in order to make it louder.  It's well written so anyone can understand what is going on.  For additional help for making quality MP3s as well as answering your other questions about SACD, go look up 'hydrogenaudio' and visit their forum and wiki pages for some great guides and resources.  It's where I learned a lot of this.
